column1: text

Conrad said: "It's them.  They did this."
Nicholas said: "It's a flat tire.  That's all."
Conrad said: "How do you know?"
Nicholas said: "We're going to figure this out.  Get a grip on yourself."
Conrad said: "Okay... okay."

Nicholas said: "The phone's dead."
Conrad said: "Really?"
Nicholas said: "Do you know how to change a tire?"
Conrad said: "No.  Do you?  Can't be too hard, can it?  I don't think we should be here out in the open like this."

Nicholas said: "How did those... ?"
Conrad said: "You're part of it..."
Nicholas said: "What?  Connie..."

Conrad said: "No!  You're one of them.  Of course, it makes perfect sense!"
Nicholas said: "No, it doesn't!  Those keys were put there.  I didn't even know..."
Conrad said: "You're behind this, aren't you?  You and your sick friends.  Well, make it stop!"
Nicholas said: "Listen to yourself.   Why would I do anything like what you're describing?"
Conrad said: "Because you hate me.  Because you had to be here, when mom died.  Because you had to do it alone.  Well, don't you think if I'd known... I'd've been here too.  I'd have been here..."
Nicholas said: "Stop this.  It's not true..."
Conrad said: "I'm sorry, Christ, I'm sorry!  How many more times do I have to say I'm sorry before you forgive me... ?"
Nicholas said: "Stop it!"

Nicholas said: "You know... how'd you manage the gun? I mean..."
Conrad said: "Baby, they were all over the house with metal detectors.  They switched your gun with a look-alike, rigged barrel, loaded with blanks.  Pop-gun."

Nicholas said: "What?"
Conrad said: "This... ?  Oh, this is just... this is the bill."

Nicholas said: "Really?"
Conrad said: "Yeah."
Nicholas said: "Split it?"
Conrad said: "Oh, God yes please.  Thanks, man. I'll take you up on that."
Nicholas said: "Where's Christine?  The waitress."
Conrad said: "Yeah, yeah.  She called a cab. Said something about catching a plane."
Nicholas said: "Did she?"

Counselor said: "No money, no identification or passport.  You are in a fix.  What did happen to you?"
Nicholas said: "Well, where to begin.  It's complicated..."
Counselor said: "It always is."

Nicholas said: "What happened was, I'm on vacation, alone... I was robbed, at gunpoint. They hit me and ran.  Two men, a few blocks away.  They took my wallet, money... all of it.  So..."
Counselor said: "Robbed?"
Nicholas said: "Yes."
Counselor said: "Have you gone to the police?"
Nicholas said: "I don't speak Spanish.  All I need is to get back... just enough for that."

Counselor said: "We'll help with the police, if you want to bother.  As far as money goes... can I make a suggestion?  You say you were mugged?"
Nicholas said: "Yes."
Counselor said: "And, they didn't take that watch?"

Counselor said: "How much is it?  A few thousand, at least.  A Rolex like that... lucky for you they missed it."
Nicholas said: "Yes, very lucky."

Nicholas said: "I need your car, Elizabeth."
Elizabeth said: "What happened to you, Nick?  I mean, look at yourself..."
Nicholas said: "I know, look at me, well...  What happened?  I don't know.  I don't even really know.  I have some things to try to take care of... I need the car a little while."
Elizabeth said: "Of course you can have it if you need it.  Can I get you something to eat?"

Nicholas said: "The last few days, um... I've been thinking... had a lot of spare time.  I want to tell you... I'm starting to understand why you left me.  I've been resenting you for it, maybe, but ... I want to apologize, for all of it.  For shutting you out, for not being there.  I...  Anyway, I hope you can forgive me."
Elizabeth said: "There's nothing to forgive."
Nicholas said: "It would mean a lot to me... if you and I could be friends.  If I could have you back in my life... in some small way.  It would be important."
Elizabeth said: "Of course, Nick..."

Nicholas said: "It's just a t.v.  He's just an actor."
Elizabeth said: "Yes."

Nicholas said: "I'll explain someday."
Elizabeth said: "I hope."

Elizabeth said: "We have to head out... just wanted to say goodbye."
Nicholas said: "You're going?  Well, thanks again.  Good to see you, Rachel...  Thanks for coming, Mel.  I'll get your car back.  Right now it's, uh... at the zoo.  Sorry."
Elizabeth said: "Happy Birthday, Nicholas."
Nicholas said: "I'll call.  I really will."
Elizabeth said: "I know."

Feingold said: "Jim Feingold, V.P., E.D.A. Engineering and Data Analysis."
Nicholas said: "I'm not quite sure how this works. My brother..."
Feingold said: "Oh, here we go..."

Feingold said: "V-A-N... O-R-T-O-N...  A gift from Conrad Van Orton. Interesting..."
Nicholas said: "What is?"

Feingold said: "Your brother was a client with our London branch.  We do a sort of informal scoring.  His numbers were outstanding.  Sure you're not hungry at all... ? Tung Hoy, best in Chinatown..."
Nicholas said: "No, thank you."
Feingold said: "You need to fill out those forms. Application, psych-tests: M.M.P.I. and T.A.T.  For the financial questionnaire, don't answer anything you don't feel like.  We'll run a T.R.W...."

Feingold said: "I don't write the questions.  I just review them."
Nicholas said: "What's all this for?"
Feingold said: "We want a sense of your overall capabilities, limitations, turn-ons, turn-offs..."
Nicholas said: "No, I mean, what is it FOR?  What are you selling?"
Feingold said: "Oh... it's a game."
Nicholas said: "A game?"
Feingold said: "Tailored specifically to each participant.  Think of it as a great vacation, except you don't go to it, it comes to you."
Nicholas said: "What kind of vacation?"
Feingold said: "It's different every time."
Nicholas said: "Humor me with specifics."
Feingold said: "We provide whatever's lacking."
Nicholas said: "And if nothing's lacking?"
Feingold said: "May I make two suggestions... ?"
Nicholas said: "Do you really expect me to participate without knowing a single thing?"
Feingold said: "First, admit to yourself that it sounds intriguing.  Second, you don't have to decide today.  Take the silly tests, fill out the forms.  One day, the game begins.  You either love it or hate it.  Decide then.  We're like an experimental Book-of-the-Month- Club; drop out at any time with no further obligation.  That was my sales pitch."

Nicholas said: "How long will these take?"
Feingold said: "An hour for those... maybe another for the physical."
Nicholas said: "Physical?"
Feingold said: "Cursory examination.  Turn-your-head- and-cough sort of thing.  You'll be out of here in no time."

Feingold said: "Sorry to keep you waiting."
Nicholas said: "Don't worry.  It's been terrific spending the entire day with your "crack team"."
Feingold said: "It's all down to this..."

Feingold said: "One guarantee.  Payment's entirely at your brother's discretion and, as a gift, dependent on your satisfaction."
Nicholas said: "You mean, I don't like it, he doesn't pay?"
Feingold said: "It's never happened.  We've never had an unsatisfied customer."
Nicholas said: "You mean, <u>dis</u>satisfied."
Feingold said: "That's right -- you're a left-brain word fetishist."

Nicholas said: "Get rid of them."
Feingold said: "Hey, everyone -- snack time!  Here... here you go..."

Feingold said: "Look, it was just a job.  Nothing personal, ya know?  I play my part, improvise a little.  That's what I'm good at."
Nicholas said: "I'm tired of dealing with peons.  I need to get to whoever's in charge."
Feingold said: "Nobody knows, pal.  Nobody gets the big picture...  Jason, Tommy, cut it out!"

Feingold said: "Goddamnit, why do they do that?"
Nicholas said: "How do I find them?  Their offices are empty."
Feingold said: "They own the whole building.  They just move from floor to floor."

Nicholas said: "They know you... you worked for them. You can get me in."
Feingold said: "No, I can't.  I'm sorry and all, but..."
Nicholas said: "Tell them the cops are after you... tell them you've got to talk to someone, I'm threatening to blow the whistle."
Feingold said: "What whistle?  There's no fucking whistle.  This is fucking dangerous."

Nicholas said: "Drive in."
Feingold said: "What are you gonna do anyway?  You won't get your money back."
Nicholas said: "I don't want money.  I'm pulling back the curtain.  I'm here to meet the wizard."

Feingold said: "You don't need me..."
Nicholas said: "Shut up.  Cuff him to the rail."

Nicholas said: "Where?"
Feingold said: "I told you, they hired me over the phone.  I never met anyone."
Nicholas said: "Where'd you pick up your checks?"
Feingold said: "It was a different floor then..."
Nicholas said: "Guess!"
Feingold said: "Like, this way... sort of..."

Nicholas said: "I need the police."
Girl said: "Let's get you dried off first.  I might have some clothes below."

Nicholas said: "You know, these fit... perfectly."
Girl said: "They were my husband's.  My late husband... may he rest in peace."

Girl said: "I've been so lonely."
Nicholas said: "I can't tell you how <u>not</u> interested I am."
Girl said: "Don't be nervous.  They said you'd be nervous."
Nicholas said: "Don't take another step."

Girl said: "Isn't this what you like?  They told me you had a thing for boats."
Nicholas said: "First they try to kill me, now you?  Put your damn clothes back on."

Hotel Manager said: "Ah, Mr. Van Orton.  Here you go..."
Nicholas said: "Have we met?"

Hotel Manager said: "Show Mr. Van Orton to his room."
Nicholas said: "The key?"
Hotel Manager said: "Hm?"
Nicholas said: "Is there a room key?"
Hotel Manager said: "Didn't I give you two?"
Nicholas said: "No, you didn't..."

Nicholas said: "Thank you."
Ilsa said: "Have a nice day."

Ilsa said: "Dinner's in the oven."
Nicholas said: "Thank you.  Goodnight."

Ilsa said: "You did?  How is he?"
Nicholas said: "Okay.  I think he's into some sort of new personal improvement cult."
Ilsa said: "Well... send my love, if you see him again."

Ilsa said: "Is everything alright?"
Nicholas said: "Fine."
Ilsa said: "I've finished for the evening.  Will you be needing anything else?"
Nicholas said: "No, thank you.  Goodnight."
Ilsa said: "Goodnight then."

Ilsa said: "Mr. Van Orton... ?"
Nicholas said: "Ilsa... you're alright?"
Ilsa said: "Yes. What do you mean?  What's wrong?"
Nicholas said: "Did the alarm go off?  The house... they... you didn't see... ?"
Ilsa said: "I don't know what you're talking about.  What's happened?"
Nicholas said: "There's been a break in.  Lock this door and stay here.  Don't move a muscle."

Ilsa said: "What makes you ask?"
Nicholas said: "I'm not sure."

Ilsa said: "All the time I've known you, you've never once asked about him."
Nicholas said: "He came to my mind recently, that's all."

Ilsa said: "Your mother thought he was a good man.  He worked very hard.  What I remember most was his manner was so... slight.  It was easy to spend time in a room, and not realize he'd been there the whole time."
Nicholas said: "Was he morose, or...?  I mean..."
Ilsa said: "No.  What happened... no one expected it."
Nicholas said: "Sometimes I wonder how much of him there is in me."
Ilsa said: "Not much, I think."
Nicholas said: "I'm just like him."
Ilsa said: "You're not like him at all.  I don't know exactly what's going on around here lately, but don't make me start worrying about you."
Nicholas said: "Did you worry about him?"
Ilsa said: "Nobody worried about your father."

Ilsa said: "Goodnight.  See you home."
Nicholas said: "Goodnight.  Where was she?"

Nicholas said: "What's the trouble?"
Manager said: "You're here for Conrad Van Orton? I'm the hotel manager..."

Nicholas said: "Pleasure to meet you, I'd like to see my brother, thank you."
Manager said: "Your brother.  Will you come with me?"
Nicholas said: "What's this about?"
Manager said: "It's a private matter, for you... I think you'll be more comfortable..."
Nicholas said: "Where's my brother?"

Manager said: "There were complaints by other guests, and damage to his room.  We did the best we could to accommodate his behavior."
Nicholas said: "His behavior... ?"
Manager said: "He couldn't, or refused to pay.  We extended credit..."
Nicholas said: "Look, where is he?!"
Manager said: "There was an incident a few days ago... a nervous breakdown, they said.  The police took him.  They left this address, in case anyone..."

Maria said: "Invitations: the Museum Gala."
Nicholas said: "No."
Nicholas said: "The Fitzwilliam Botanical Garden Annual Fundraiser."
Nicholas said: "No."
Nicholas said: "The Hinchberger wedding."
Nicholas said: "Let me think...  Hordes of men in tuxedos.  Everyone's droning.  Ludwell's trying to break the ice by reciting an off-color limerick..."
Maria said: "I'll send your regrets.  Honestly, why must I even bother?"
Nicholas said: "Because, if you don't know about society, you don't have the satisfaction of avoiding it."

Maria said: "Your ex-wife."
Nicholas said: "I know who she is.  Take a message."

Nicholas said: "I don't like her."
Maria said: "I wouldn't mention the following, except he was very insistent.  It's obviously some sort of prank..."
Nicholas said: "What?"
Maria said: "A gentleman left a message requesting a lunch, but I assured him..."
Nicholas said: "What gentleman, Maria?"
Maria said: "A Mister... Seymour Butts."

Nicholas said: ""Under the Bleachers"... by Seymour Butts."
Maria said: "Pardon me?  I'm afraid I don't..."
Nicholas said: "Cancel lunch.  Make reservations at Campton Place for me and Mr. Butts."

Plump Guy said: "What the fuck... ?!"
Nicholas said: "Why are you following me?"
Plump Guy said: "I don't know what you're talking about.  I'm just driving..."

Plump Guy said: "Look... what I'm doing is none of your business..."
Nicholas said: "Is Alan Baer "the Game?"  Is that what this is?"
Plump Guy said: "Friend... why don't you back off."

Plump Guy said: "Hey... !"
Nicholas said: "Nice touch.  Does the game use real bullets... ?"

Sutherland said: "Anything wrong... ?"
Nicholas said: "Nothing.  Nothing at all."

Nicholas said: "I wasn't expecting you."
Sutherland said: "Wanted to wish you luck.  Not that you'll need it."

Sutherland said: "Attractive..."
Nicholas said: "Don't ask."
Sutherland said: "I checked it personally."

Sutherland said: "What's happened..."
Nicholas said: "Follow me."

Sutherland said: "Nicholas..."
Nicholas said: "That you've involved Conrad... is unforgivable.  I am now your enemy."

Sutherland said: "How concerned should I be?"
Nicholas said: "It was a misunderstanding."

Nicholas said: "Someone's playing hardball.  It's complicated.  Can I ask a favor?"
Sutherland said: "You know you can."
Nicholas said: "Find out about a company called C.R.S.  Consumer Recreation Services."
Sutherland said: "Sounds like they make tennis rackets. What do we know?"
Nicholas said: "Just what I told you."
Sutherland said: "Nothing else?"

Nicholas said: "Christ... I can't believe it... invisible ink?"
Sutherland said: "You're joking."
Nicholas said: "It's what they do.  It's like... being toyed with by a bunch of...  Depraved children."

Sutherland said: "Very well.  If you tell me not to worry, I shan't."
Nicholas said: "Sam...  Thank you."

Nicholas said: "He hasn't called back."
Sutherland said: "What about the house?"

Sutherland said: "Illegal surveillance, reckless endangerment..."
Nicholas said: "Attempted murder."

Sutherland said: "Bravo, young man.  you have to tell me what this was all about sometime.  I want you to know... when it looked there for awhile like you were going slowly insane... I was fully prepared to have you committed to the <u>finest</u> mental-health facility available.  I mean that sincerely, don't thank me."
Nicholas said: "You warm my heart."

Todd said: "Hi.  I'm Todd Aubochon."
Luke said: "Greetings fellow insomniac."
Todd said: "Greetings fellow sheep counter."

Todd said: "These old Victorian houses are great, aren't they?"
Luke said: "It's not Victorian, everyone thinks that the whole nineteenth century was Victorian.  This is gothic, this is English Craftsman, this is Romanesque.  This is... insane.  Who lives here?"

Luke said: "You know what I love about wine that comes in bottles like this?"
Todd said: "What?"
Luke said: "<u>Every</u> year is a good year."

Luke said: "Hi, Luke Sanderson, bad sleeper, I'm your basic tosser-turner, and you are..."
Nell said: "Uh... Nell Vance..."
Luke said: "And what kind of sleeper?"
Nell said: "Well, I... uh..."
Luke said: "Obsessive worrier.  Join the club.  And you?  I'd guess..."

Nell said: "I only saw Theo drive up."
Luke said: "Who's Watts?"

Nell said: "The children.  The children Hugh Crain built the house for.  The children he never had."
Luke said: "Come on.  These are the typically sentimental gestures of a depraved industrialist."

Nell said: "Couldn't get the last ones.  You?"
Luke said: "I did okay."

Nell said: "Welcome Home Eleanor.  Welcome Home?  I've never been here.  Who did this?"
Luke said: "It's somebody's idea of a joke."

Luke said: "Modelling small-group dynamics in the formation of narrative hallucinations.  You brought us here to scare us.  Insomnia, that was just a decoy issue.  You're disgusting."
Nell said: "Is this true?  I've been hypnotized?"

Marrow said: "And this is my assistant, Mary Lambretta."
Luke said: "Greetings."

Luke said: "So why did you need the Addam's Family mansion for a scientific test?"
Marrow said: "I thought it best to be isolated, to be in a location with a definite sense of history, and I wanted to make sure that it wasn't so pleasant you'd all sleep too easily.  You'll be taking a variety of tests, none of them harmful, and you've got the house, the grounds, and each other to keep you company."

Luke said: "That could have been worse."
Marrow said: "Yeah."

Marrow said: "Luke, can I talk to you?"
Luke said: "Sure."
Marrow said: "Because... well, I know I can trust you."
Luke said: "Why?"
Marrow said: "I've read your tests."

Luke said: "Do you need me anymore?  Cause I'm going to bed.  They can stay up talking another 45 minutes if they want, but I gotta try to get some sleep."
Marrow said: "Go ahead."

Marrow said: "And those are Luke's and mine."
Luke said: "There's a carriage house around back."

Marrow said: "I gave my key to the gate to Todd, but the Dudleys'll be here in the morning."
Luke said: "Do we still get paid for the week?"
Marrow said: "You get your money."

Luke said: "Is that the question of compassion or science?"
Marrow said: "It's a question."
Luke said: "She got the child labor stuff from me."

Luke said: "It's not going to hold your weight."
Marrow said: "Just stay there, Nell!"

Luke said: "You're not telling us something."
Marrow said: "Watts.  Those were his keys Nell found.  His roommate called and said Watts left when he was supposed to.  I think he's here."

Theo said: "The rest of you may hate your insomnia, but I find it the best time of the day for me.  I'm alone.  Nobody's talking to me but myself.  My mind is racing with ideas, and I can think."
Luke said: "Nah, you're going crazy with doubt, all of your mistakes are coming back up the pipes, and it's worse than a nightmare. --"

Luke said: "He said that Hugh Crain... Hugh Crain was a monster.  He said that he was a brutal, horrible man.  He told me that Crain drove his workers to early deaths.  Crain had children chained to the looms in his mill.  And listen to this: his beautiful Rene killed herself."
Theo said: "And why didn't Marrow tell <u>us</u>? Doesn't he trust women?  That fuck."

Luke said: "Hey!  I heard screaming..."
Theo said: "Luke."

Luke said: "Well, this lot is full!"
Theo said: "He must have left.  Didn't like the looks of the place or something."

Luke said: "I didn't do it."
Theo said: "You could have."
Luke said: "So could you!  Is this some fucked up idea of art, putting someone else's name to a painting?"
Theo said: "No."

Theo said: "Mister very talky, would you please say what it is about this study that bothers you?"
Luke said: "The whole thing feels like experimental misdirection.  Like he says it's about one thing, a psychological profile of environmental effects on insomnia... and that'd be a legitimate study, but I think that we've been subjected to an academic bait and switch; he's really looking at something else."

Theo said: "We're fucked.  We're in a haunted house and we can't get out until the morning."
Luke said: "You don't really believe it's haunted... Do you believe in ghosts?"
Theo said: "That depends on your definition of ghosts.  I'm going to check on her, and then I'm going to stay awake."
Luke said: "All night?"
Theo said: "Yeah."
Luke said: "You want company?"
Theo said: "Maybe someday."

Luke said: "You used the wrong test."
Theo said: "Will the two of you shut up!  God damn it!  Maybe the tests were right, Marrow.  She's sensitive, she's vulnerable, but I don't think she's suicidal and I didn't have to test her.  Maybe she wasn't trying to kill herself. Maybe she was really scared. Maybe she really heard voices."

Theo said: "Nell --"
Luke said: "-- how much is this car worth?"

Theo said: "Was sure she'd be in here."
Luke said: "Where in the hell can she be."

Theo said: "Nell!"
Luke said: "We can't stay here looking for her.  She doesn't want to be found..."

Malcolm said: "It's still an electric shock!"
Marrow said: "Come on Malcolm, it's only seven ohms, it's nothing, it's like a joy buzzer!  And it's not about the pain, it's about the interference with concentration..."

Marrow said: "Malcolm, this is essential work I'm doing.  Just think what my research can do for education. Elementary school classrooms near train tracks or airports, where loud noise is random; this helps to prove the need for sound insulation if the children are ever going to learn to read."
Malcolm said: "And that will be a good place to end this study."
Marrow said: "No, Malcolm!  Individual performance is only part of it.  I know why baseball players choke for no reason, I know why violinists throw up with fear before every concert, and need to, to give a great performance, but what I want to know is, how fear works in a group..."
Malcolm said: "Not the way you've constructed your group, it's just not ethical!"
Marrow said: "But if the group knows it's being studied as a group, you contaminate the results.  The deception is minor."

Malcolm said: "Are you working with her?"
Marrow said: "Mary, I'll meet you outside."

Malcolm said: "Why are you working with her? Mary Lambretta was thrown out of the department for trying to get a Ph.D. in psychic studies."
Marrow said: "And after she was thrown out, she needed a job."
Malcolm said: "You don't believe in the paranormal."
Marrow said: "No, but she does, and that's all that matters."
Malcolm said: "Does she know that's why you're using her?"
Marrow said: "No."
Malcolm said: "I, I just can't..."
Marrow said: "She needed a job, Malcolm.  And she's smart.  And she helps me."
Malcolm said: "I have a bad feeling about what you're doing."
Marrow said: "This is the last chapter.  Please, please give me clearance.  It's for science."

Marrow said: "Eleanor, how was the drive?"
Nell said: "You can call me Nell, Dr. Marrow."
Marrow said: "Nell.  Good enough.  And I'm Jim."
Nell said: "I'm really... honored to be part of this study, Jim."
Marrow said: "Well... we're glad to have you."

Marrow said: "You wrote that you had trouble sleeping."
Nell said: "Yes, because someone was always keeping me awake.  Ever since I was little.  That was my job.  I took care of my mother and I had to be there for her all night long, and she woke up all the time.  And after she died, well, it's been a few months, but I still, I still wake up, it's... a habit.  I know we've only known each other a couple of hours, but I'm really glad to be with people who let me talk about this.  I'm really happy to be here with you."

Nell said: "All the carvings."
Marrow said: "But there's a sad catch to the story."

Marrow said: "The cold sensation.  Who felt it first?"
Nell said: "Theo I think.  You've asked us that three times, Doctor Marrow. What's going on?"
Marrow said: "How do you feel about Luke's suggestion that it was just the old plumbing?  Water hammer, something like that?"

Nell said: "Sorry."
Marrow said: "For an American you do a good imitation of the British at their most apologetic.  Pardon me.  Excuse me, sorry, sorry..."

Marrow said: "Nell!  What's wrong?"
Nell said: "That smell... oh, God."

Marrow said: "What did it smell like?"
Nell said: "It was very specific."
Marrow said: "All right..."
Nell said: "In the bathroom in my mother's room, the toilet was next to an old wooden table.  It smelled like that wood."
Marrow said: "So... smell... is... Smell is the sense that triggers the most powerful memories.  And a memory can trigger a smell."
Nell said: "I wasn't thinking about my mother's bathroom."
Marrow said: "What happened after you smelled it?"
Nell said: "I looked at Theo.  She had a look on her face."
Marrow said: "Like she smelled it too?"
Nell said: "Yes."
Marrow said: "And then what happened?"
Nell said: "I got more scared."

Marrow said: "Hmm."
Nell said: "I'm sorry.  I'm messing up the study."
Marrow said: "No you're not.  Something moved you.  You saw something."

Nell said: "Are you coming to confess?"
Marrow said: "I wish I were.  I wish I had done it, then I could confess and you'd be at peace.  That great moral philosopher Frank Sinatra once said to someone he loved, I wish you had an enemy, so I could beat him up."

Nell said: "Let's say it wasn't you.  Who did it?"
Marrow said: "I don't know."
Nell said: "It was a stupid thing to do."
Marrow said: "It was."
Nell said: "Welcome Home."
Marrow said: "You'll never see it again.  Mr. Dudley's taking care of it.  I'm sorry, Nell.  Can I show you something you'd like to see?"
Nell said: "Sure."

Marrow said: "Someone is playing with you."
Nell said: "Why?"
Marrow said: "I don't know."
Nell said: "It doesn't matter.  Even if they're tormenting me, someone wants me.  What I do with this is up to me.  I can be a victim, or I can be a volunteer.  And I want to be the volunteer."

Marrow said: "What is that tune?"
Nell said: "I don't know.  A lullaby I guess. My mother used to hum it to me. And her mother before that, and so on.  Hugh Crain, would you care to dance?"

Marrow said: "Nell... please, Nell... take a deep breath..."
Nell said: "And they're all locked together in here... and he won't let go of them!"

But the point is that if Mr Prosecutor over there had devoted half the time he's spent persecuting *this* woman to even the most cursory investigation of this schmoe's past, then we might *know* who! But we can't *know* what really happened! Because of Fritz, or Werner, or whatever the hell his name is! And because Me Prosecutor is *also* a lazy fat-assed sonofabitch who decided it's easier to victimize your wife! Because it's easier *not* to look! Because the more you look, the less you know! But the beauty of it is, we don't *gotta* know! We just gotta show that, goddamnit, *they* don't know. Reasonable doubt. Science. The atom. *You* explain it to me. Go ahead. Try."

Riedenschneider said: "Not guilty, your honor..."
Ed said: "I tried to tell him the whole story, but Riedenschneider stopped me. He said the story made his head hurt, and anyway he didn't see any way of using it without putting me on the hot seat for the murder of Big Dave..."

Ed said: "...I gotta hand it to him, he tossed a lot of sand in their eyes. He talked about how I'd lost my place in the universe..."
Riedenschneider said: "...a puny player on the great world's stage..."
Ed said: "...how I was too ordinary to be the criminal mastermind the D.A. made me out to be, how there was some greater scheme at work that the state had yet to unravel, and he threw in some of the old truth stuff he hadn't had a chance to trot out for Doris..."
Riedenschneider said: "...who among us is in a position to say..."
Ed said: "...He told them to look at me--look at me close. That the closer they looked the less sense it would all make, that I wasn't the kind of guy to kill a guy, that I was the barber, for Christ's sake..."

Riedenschneider said: "...and inflame the passions of these twelve fine men and women..."
Ed said: "...Well, he got his mistrial, but the well had run dry. There was nothing left to mortgage; Riedenschneider went home and the court appointed Lloyd Garroway..."

Ed said: "Thanks. Thanks for seeing me, at home."
Walter said: "Oh, hell. Drink?"
Ed said: "No thanks."
Walter said: "Sure you don't need one?"
Ed said: "I'm fine."
Walter said: "OK. Boy. Jesus!"
Ed said: "Yeah. What do I, uh..."
Walter said: "Well, of course, I, uh, it's out of my league, criminal stuff. I do, uh, probate, real estate, title search, uh... I'd be absolutely worthless, something like this. Absolutely worthless."

Walter said: "'Scuse me, just finished dinner. Um. Frankly, Doris'd be better off with the county defender."
Ed said: "He a good man?"
Walter said: "Bert's OK, sure, he's a good man. I won't kid you though, Ed, nobody around here has any experience with this kind of, er... And I hear they're bringing a prosecutor up from Sacramento. Capital offense. Taking it seriously... Hmm..."
Ed said: "So--"
Walter said: "Taking it seriously."
Ed said: "So, who should I--"

Walter said: "Coffee, Ed?"
Ed said: "I'm fine. Thanks."
Walter said: "No thanks, honey."

Ed said: "...So, uh, who should I--"
Walter said: "Well, there's Lloyd Garroway in San Francisco. Probity--you know, no one ever said anything iffy about Lloyd Garroway. Conservative. Jury might like that. Might like that here."

Walter said: "...Probity."
Ed said: "Uh-huh. Is he the best then, for, uh..."
Walter said: "Well, the best, the money-is-no-object best, for a criminal case, any lawyer would tell you Freddy Riedenschneider. Out of Sacramento. 'Course, I don't know how you're fixed for money."
Ed said: "Uh-huh. He's the, uh..."
Walter said: "Yeah, the best."

Walter said: "Ed, how're you holding up?"
Ed said: "I'm OK, Walter, thanks."

Walter said: "I'm so damn sorry about your loss. Terrible thing. Just damn terrible."
Ed said: "Yeah."
Walter said: "Birdy's in the parlor--I'm on long distance here."
Ed said: "Sure, Walter. Thanks."

Ed said: "...Huh?"
Young Man said: "Haven't I seen you up in ladies' wear?"
Ed said: "I don't work here. My wife does."
Young Man said: "Uh-huh. Some beat, huh?"
Ed said: "Yeah."
Young Man said: "Check out the rack on that broad in the angora."
Ed said: "Uh-huh."

Ed said: "...Did you make that up?"
Young Woman said: "Oh, no. That was written by Mr Ludwig van Beethoven."

Ed said: "That was quite something."

Ed said: "That was something. I'm Ed Crane."
Young Woman said: "I know who you are, Mr Crane."

Young Woman said: "...I'm Rachel Abundas. Everyone calls me Birdy."

Frank said: "Says here that the Russians exploded n A-bomb and there's not a damn thing we can do about it."
Ed said: "Uh-huh."
Frank said: "How d'ya like them apples?"

Frank said: "...Ed?"
Ed said: "Huh?"
Frank said: "Russians exploded an A-bomb."
Ed said: "Yeah."
Frank said: "Jesus..."
Ed said: "Now, being a barber is a lot like being a barman or a soda-jerk; there's not much to it once you've learned the basic moves. For the kids there's the Butch, or the Heinie..."

Frank said: "...so you tie your own flies, Ed. I mean, if you're really serious. You tie your own flies, you do a--I know it's matickless, I know, people say, hey, you can buy flies at the store-- but you can buy your fish at the store, Ed, you see what I'm saying?"
Ed said: "Uh-huh."
Frank said: "The point is there's a certain art to the process. The point is not merely to provide, and let me point out, these fish are not as dumb as you might think."
Ed said: "Uh-huh."
Frank said: "Sportsmanship! That's my point. June fly, Ed? Mosquito? Which of these? Well, what fish do you seek?"
Ed said: "Yeah."
Frank said: "Sure, go to the store. Go there, describe to the man where you will be fishing, and for what, and the weather conditions, sun, no sun, whatnot, and so forth, and then you might as well have the man go ahead and sell you the goddamn FISH, Ed..."

Frank said: "...You sure, Eddie?"
Ed said: "Yeah, yeah--go home."

Ed said: "Frank."
Frank said: "Huh?"
Ed said: "This hair."
Frank said: "Yeah."
Ed said: "...You ever wonder about it?"
Frank said: "Whuddya mean?"
Ed said: "I don't know... How it keeps on coming. It just keeps growing."
Frank said: "Yeah--lucky for us, huh, pal?"
Ed said: "No, I mean it's growing, it's part of us. And we cut it off. And throw it away."
Frank said: "Come on, Eddie, you're gonna scare the kid."

Ed said: "...I'm gonna take his hair and throw it out in the dirt."
Frank said: "What the--"
Ed said: "I'm gonna mingle it with common house dirt."
Frank said: "What the hell are you talking about?"

Frank said: "...How you today, Ed?"
Ed said: "OK."
Frank said: "You don't got a headache?"
Ed said: "...Nah."
Frank said: "Damn, I got a headache to beat the band."

Frank said: "This is what family is for, Ed! This is when ya come together!"
Ed said: "Yeah."
Frank said: "Close ranks! Goddamnit! Those sons of bitches!"
Ed said: "Frank, uh, you know I'll try to contribute, but, uh--Freddy Riedenschneider--"
Frank said: "I don't care what it costs! This is when ya come together!"
Ed said: "That's very generous."
Frank said: "The hell with it, Eddie!"

Frank said: "They're just people like you and me, Ed. Remember that."
Ed said: "Uh-huh."
Frank said: "Just people. They gotta put up the big front so that people will trust them with their money. This is why the big lobby, Ed. But they put their pants on one leg at a time. Just like you and me."
Ed said: "Uh-huh."
Frank said: "They too use the toilet, Ed. In spite of appearances. And their money will be secured by the barbershop. A rock. A *rock*, the barbershop. I mean, how long has *this* place been here?"

Ed said: "...We goin'?"
Krebs said: "Huh? No."

Ed said: "Huh?"
Krebs said: "They sent us to tell ya. We pulled the detail."
Ed said: "My *wife*?"

Ed said: "I don't understand."
Krebs said: "He's the dead guy."

Ed said: "Birdy... I didn't mean to--"
Krebs said: "What'd he say?"
Ed said: "Birdy..."

Man said: "'Lo, Ed."
Ed said: "Hello, Walter."

Man said: "Mr...?"
Ed said: "Crane. Ed Crane."
Man said: "You also have an interest in the securing property?"

Man said: "...You're Ed Crane?"
Ed said: "Yeah--"
Man said: "Barber, right? I'm Freddy Riedenschneider. Hungry? They tell me the chow's OK here. I made some inquiries."
Ed said: "No thanks, I--"

Ed said: "...I'm Crane."
Man said: "My name is Diedrickson. County medical examiner."
Ed said: "Yeah?"

Man said: "Hello!"
Ed said: "Hello."

Ed said: "Doesn't bother me."
Man said: "Well, have you ever considered tar Macadam? People think it's just for public works and commercial purposes, roads, parking lots, so forth..."

Man said: "OK, boys, which of you gets the privilege?"
Frank said: "We're just closing, friend."
Man said: "Oh, happy days! I wish I was doing well enough to turn away business! More power to ya, brother! The public be damned!"
Frank said: "Hey, what's your problem, friend? This is a business establishment with posted hours--"

Frank said: "Yes, sir."
Man said: "Could you come with me please?"
Frank said: "Sure. Can Ed come too?"

Frank said: "He's a barber."
Man said: "Ah."
Frank said: "Second chair."
Man said: "Not an owner."
Frank said: "No, he's family, he's my brother-in- law."
Man said: "Ah-hah. It would be best if he waited here."

Krebs said: "...Look, pal, it's a tough break, but, uh... well damnit, your wife's been pinched."
Persky said: "They sent us to tell ya."

Krebs said: "You'll go to the prison hospital."

Persky said: "He said OK. Is that what he said?"

Bailey said: "Uh, Vince.  Sorry.  This won't wait."

Bailey said: "I'm in."

Cuthbert said: "Beauregard!  You scared me half to death."
Beauregard said: "I'm sorry, sir.  You okay?"
Cuthbert said: "Someone broke into this room."
Beauregard said: "Anything missin'?"
Cuthbert said: "Doesn't look like it.  We're damned lucky.  This statue is priceless."

Beauregard said: "Looks like the curse is still at work."
Cuthbert said: "The claws are sharp... I must have cut myself.  Better move these crates to the secure storage area where they'll be safe."

Beauregard said: "Don't know if it'll do any good, Mr. Cuthbert."
Cuthbert said: "Why not?"
Beauregard said: "No one broke into this room, sir. Someone broke out.  That lock was torn off from the <u>inside</u>."

D'Agosta said: "We all love the museum.  I come here myself with my kids.  We're trying to work with you."
Cuthbert said: "I appreciate that."

D'Agosta said: "I'm telling you, something's wrong. I still haven't heard from Pendergast.  I think you should call it off."
Cuthbert said: "It's too late now.  Guests are arriving.  The Mayor's car is pulling up."
D'Agosta said: "I'll go down and speak to him."
Cuthbert said: "You haven't got the authority.  Only Pendergast can pull the plug."
D'Agosta said: "Pendergast may be in trouble.  Don't you understand?  He still hasn't come back.  It's been over three hours --"
Cuthbert said: "He'll be back.  Relax.  We're in good shape.  Your security is air tight. There've been no more incidents, nothing suspicious.  There's no reason to call off the opening now."

Cuthbert said: "Sweet Jesus!"
D'Agosta said: "Get his gun and his walkie talkie, Jonathan.  Move."
Cuthbert said: "My office is on the third floor! There's a walk-in safe and a portable phone!  We can lock ourselves in the safe and call for help!"
D'Agosta said: "I have to help Pendergast.  Kawakita and Jonathan stay with me.  The rest of you can go with Cuthbert!"

Pendergast said: "I had no idea the Museum had a complete collection of Piranesi's Forum sketches."
Cuthbert said: "If you like them, they're for sale. Another day like yesterday and half the collection will be on the block."
Pendergast said: "I've read about the Museum's financial troubles."
Cuthbert said: "We've been operating in the red for years.  That was the whole idea behind the Superstition Exhibit.  It was designed to pull people in. We've spent every penny we have on advance publicity, betting everything on the opening's success. If we postpone at the last minute... No.  I don't want to think about that."

Pendergast said: "If the party goes forward, and that's a big if... I've arranged for a large police presence."
Cuthbert said: "Do they have to wear uniforms?"
Pendergast said: "Yes."
Cuthbert said: "I don't want to scare people."
Pendergast said: "I understand.  But Mr. Cuthbert, we've got bigger problems.  Depending on what we find today, we may have to shut you down."

Cuthbert said: "I got it after I was mugged in the subway last spring."
Jonathan said: "Where's the walk-in safe?"
Cuthbert said: "Behind you."
Jonathan said: "What's the combination?"
Cuthbert said: "I'll do it.  Just let me find my portable phone."

Jonathan said: "Forget it!"
Cuthbert said: "Calm down.  I found it!"

Cuthbert said: "Battery's dead.  Shit."
Jonathan said: "Let's go!"

Cuthbert said: "That thing won't come after us, right?  It's going for bigger game. The group blundering around in the basement.  Poor fools."
Jonathan said: "Hurry up!"
Cuthbert said: "Just a minute.  I'm shaking!  Take the gun."

Jonathan said: "For Chrissake, I'll do it.  What's the combination?!"
Cuthbert said: "To the left twice then five no... sorry... I think it's fifteen... it's been a while..."
Jonathan said: "Oh Jesus..."

Jonathan said: "Fifteen... what's next?"
Cuthbert said: "Eight to the right!  Look!  I found it!"

Ippolito said: "This huge police presence tonight isn't necessary, Lieutenant.  You'll just scare people off.  I can handle the security behind scenes with this system.  It's state of the art."
D'Agosta said: "The cops are non-negotiable, Ippolito.  Why don't you just tell me how this space station works."
Ippolito said: "It's fool proof, basically.  I designed this whole thing myself. Every valuable object in the Museum carries a small electronic chip.  If anything's moved so much as an inch, we get an alarm pinpointing the exact location of the attempted theft."
D'Agosta said: "That's great if you're stopping a burglar.  Not our goal here.  Are there motion detectors?"
Ippolito said: "In every exhibition room.  The museum's divided into five cells. The reception and exhibit are in cell five.  We could arm the motion detectors in cells one to four, then seal the perimeter with our fire doors."
D'Agosta said: "That would leave one exit for hundreds of people.  You'd be violating every fire regulation on the books.  We'll guard the perimeter with my men and engage the motion detectors in the other cells.  One more question.  I see a big hole.  If this entire thing is run by computer, what happens if the power fails?"
Ippolito said: "You don't know much about computers, Lieutenant.  There are safeguards built in.  We have back-up systems with redundancies.  There's no way these computers can fail."

Ippolito said: "The whole system is shutting down! We have to get out quickly before the fire doors fall!"
D'Agosta said: "What doors?"
Ippolito said: "I told you!  They seal off all the cells.  They were designed to fall automatically in a system failure --"
D'Agosta said: "You said the system couldn't fail!"

D'Agosta said: "Ippolito!  Get back here!"
Ippolito said: "Like hell!"

Ippolito said: "D'Agosta?  Ippolito.  Come in."
D'Agosta said: "Where the hell are you?"
Ippolito said: "I made it outside.  I'll co-ordinate the rescue efforts from here.  Help is on the way.  Just sit tight."
D'Agosta said: "It's a little late, you son of a bitch.  There's a friggin' monster loose in here!  Get the FBI, the fire department.  Find metal cutters, cut through.  And bring a cannon.  The damn thing is huge."

D'Agosta said: "Who are you?  The undertaker?"
Pendergast said: "Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI."
D'Agosta said: "Vince D'Agosta.  Am I out?"
Pendergast said: "Not at all.  I think we may be working on the same case.  If so, I could use your help."

Pendergast said: "The body?"
D'Agosta said: "What's left of it."
Pendergast said: "Mind if I have a look?"

D'Agosta said: "We need light in here, stat."
Pendergast said: "Where's the head?"

D'Agosta said: "Careful.  That mess on the ground is brains."
Pendergast said: "Whose footprints?"
D'Agosta said: "Night watchman who found the body. Sweet old man.  Been tossing his cookies for over an hour.  Not a likely suspect."

Pendergast said: "An original Roger Tory Peterson of a Red-Breasted Merganser.  Amazing.  I have a copy of this in my office at home."
D'Agosta said: "Can't really focus on birds at the moment, Pendergast.  I'm tryin' to keep my breakfast down."
Pendergast said: "In this violent world, I believe the only way to stay sane is to take time to notice beautiful things."
D'Agosta said: "I drink.  After hours of course.  On duty, I smoke.  Do you mind?"
Pendergast said: "Not at all.  I enjoy the smell of a good cigar."
D'Agosta said: "Then you won't like this one.  It's a piece of shit."

Pendergast said: "Lieutenant --"
D'Agosta said: "Call me Vince."
Pendergast said: "Did you read about a boat that washed up outside of New Orleans about four months ago?  Twelve bodies on board."
D'Agosta said: "Who didn't?  Big news.  Out of Brazil, wasn't it?"
Pendergast said: "Yes.  That's my case.  Now it's yours. All the corpses were badly mutilated in a very particular way. Decapitated.  Brains extracted.  Limbs torn to shreds.  It looked like the work of a large animal, but there was no sign of an animal on board."
D'Agosta said: "So the method of death is the only connection?"
Pendergast said: "No.  There's more.  There were crates from this museum in the hold of the boat."

Pendergast said: "If you don't mind, this could be important."
D'Agosta said: "You're kidding."
Pendergast said: "Unfortunately, no."

D'Agosta said: "I've got to admit, that was a damn sight better than "the dog ate my homework"."
Pendergast said: "How do you explain the part about Beauregard?"
D'Agosta said: "They heard the victim's name and wove him into their story.  Nice touch."
Pendergast said: "I believed them."

D'Agosta said: "You think what we've got here is a monster as big as a house that smells... like hamburger?"
Pendergast said: "No.  I think what we've got here is a psychotic killer wielding some kind of unusual weapon... who wants us to believe he's a monster."
D'Agosta said: "Oh."

D'Agosta said: "What happened to them?"
Pendergast said: "If you don't mind a suggestion, you might try a saliva test."

D'Agosta said: "Saliva test?  You mean, you think someone ate part of the brain?"
Pendergast said: "Correct."

D'Agosta said: "I don't like animals.  Never have. Dog bit me when I was little.  After that I gave up on pets.  Animals are irrational.  Give me a psychotic killer any day.  If there's one thing that makes me queasy it's being part of a food chain.  My first case as a rookie, two brothers climbed a fence at the zoo.  It was late August.  Over ninety.  The polar bear was inside his cave.  Kids didn't know he was in there.  All they saw was the pool. They got to swimming and splashing. The noise woke up the bear.  By the time I arrived, both little boys were in pieces.  The bear was dragging one kid around by the foot. I can still hear the mother screaming --"
Pendergast said: "This isn't an animal, Vince.  I've been on this case four months, remember?  I've learned a few things."
D'Agosta said: "You've been holding out on me Pendergast.  You have a suspect capable of this?"

D'Agosta said: "How big is the sub-basement?"
Pendergast said: "Apparently it's huge."
D'Agosta said: "I think I should come with you."
Pendergast said: "We haven't got time.  You have to meet with museum security so we can make a decision about tonight."

D'Agosta said: "Pendergast!  Help!  It's right behind us!"
Pendergast said: "This door's locked.  Try shooting the hinges off."

Pendergast said: "Vince?  There's no way we can get to you with the fire doors down. There's an entrance to the sub- basement in the hall off the north side exit."
D'Agosta said: "The sub-basement?"
Pendergast said: "I've been down there.  It links up to the old sewer system.  I can guide you out."

D'Agosta said: "I smell it.  It's here."
Pendergast said: "Go out the north exit!  There's a hallway and a false wall by the Greek vases.  Run!"
D'Agosta said: "Everybody.  Get behind me."

Pendergast said: "Nice to see you, Lieutenant."
D'Agosta said: "The sub-basement, huh?  Great idea."

D'Agosta said: "This place is a maze."
Frock said: "I'm one of the few who know every inch it, now that John is gone."

D'Agosta said: "Look.  It's some kind of letter."
Frock said: "May I see that?"

Frock said: "Did you hear that?  My God.  He says that Mbwun is real!"
D'Agosta said: "Pardon my French, but bull shit."
Frock said: "This on top of the scratches... isn't it proof!"

D'Agosta said: "Shouldn't a drug that powerful be destroyed?"
Frock said: "The virus itself might have positive applications.  They'll keep the plants in secure lock up while the studies are made.  Greg isn't joining us?"

Kawakita said: "Lieutenant!  It's me."
D'Agosta said: "What is it?"
Kawakita said: "Dr. Green has to see you!"
D'Agosta said: "Got my hands full here."
Kawakita said: "It's important.  Please.  You have to come!  Pendergast, too.  She's found out something."

Kawakita said: "What happened?!"
D'Agosta said: "There's a dead body in the exhibit! People are panicking, trampling each other trying to get out."

Kawakita said: "It's still back there!"
D'Agosta said: "I know."

D'Agosta said: "How much ammo do we have to make a stand?"
Kawakita said: "You're asking me?  I don't even know how to load this thing."

D'Agosta said: "All right.  Kawakita, cover the rear."
Kawakita said: "Oh shit."

Kawakita said: "I believe in you a hundred percent, Vince, but that's the second time we've been at that intersection."
D'Agosta said: "Not so loud."

Kawakita said: "What's that?"
D'Agosta said: "All right everybody, hold up!"

D'Agosta said: "What does it say?"
Kawakita said: "Dr. John Whittlesley."
D'Agosta said: "What's that doing here?"
Kawakita said: "I don't know.  I thought Dr. Whittlesley died in South America."

Kawakita said: "Dear God.  Where are we, Lieutenant?"

Pendergast said: "We've met.  The Hacksaw Murders.  '89."
Dr. Ziewzic said: "Oh yes!  Who could forget.  Afterwards you sent me that amazing case of Chateau Lafitte."
Pendergast said: "I hope you liked it."
Dr. Ziewzic said: "Lovely bouquet.  After our last case, Vince took me out for a draft beer. As I recall we split the check."

Dr. Ziewzic said: "What are we talking about here?"
Pendergast said: "Someone who makes the Hacksaw Murderer look like Mother Teresa."
Dr. Ziewzic said: "Right.  The entire brain appears to have been extracted.  May I see it, please?"

Dr. Ziewzic said: "Curious.  There's something missing."
Pendergast said: "The thalamus and the hypothalamus, perhaps?"
Dr. Ziewzic said: "Yes.  Two organs the size of a walnut have been removed with what looks like surgical precision."

Frock said: "Yes.  Bit of a shock.  But as Cuthbert so tactfully put it, the museum needs new blood.  And since I've been here since the Mesozoic Era --"
Margo said: "I don't believe it."
Frock said: "Now Margo, don't overreact.  Cuthbert has to cut costs somehow.  My leaving makes perfect sense.  This isn't exactly early retirement.  I've overstayed the party a bit."
Margo said: "We can't do without you.  You're one of the foremost authorities on primitive pharmacology.  You're practically an institution around here."
Frock said: "That, apparently, is the problem. I'm yesterday's news.  Who needs a Curator of Plant Biology in a museum with one exhibit on plants?  Monsters and dinosaurs, cannibals and shamans are the new currency of the realm."

Frock said: "Please.  Don't humiliate me further."
Margo said: "Let me help.  I can take care of everything."
Frock said: "No, Margo.  This is one problem you can't solve.  You have to stay out of it.  The fact is, I want to retire."
Margo said: "How can you say that?  You know it's not true."
Frock said: "Yes it is.  I'm tired and I'm no longer needed --"
Margo said: "My work on fossil intermediates would be crippled without you."
Frock said: "With all due respect, dear, that's bull.  You dance rings around me with your new technology.  You've left me in the dust."
Margo said: "Your work is highly relevant.  What about your display on Primitive Pharmacology?  Cuthbert told me himself he was going to feature it prominently in the Superstition Exhibit."
Frock said: "Healing plant use among the Ki tribe of Bechuanaland has been cancelled to make room for Tibetan Erotic Art."

Frock said: "Come on.  I'll walk you back to the elevator."
Margo said: "I'm not giving up."
Frock said: "You must."

Lombard said: "Why me, Mrs De Moraes? Why should such well-connected people as you hire a small- time French detective to look for their missing son, Mrs De Moraes?"
Deborah said: "Huh! Who do you think we are, Mr Lombard?"
Lombard said: "Couldnt Nazi hunters do the job?"

Deborah said: "I still dont buy your story but I figured it cant do any harm to let you go on with your enquiry. Besides, if you do turn out to be nothing but a cheap little extortioner, we could always get the right people onto you. I trust you know who I am talking about."
Lombard said: "You drive a hard bargain."

Lombard said: "Thank you for coming. Come in and close the door, will you?"
Deborah said: "Last night you upset my sleep. Tonight my social life. We have two minutes. My dinner guests are waiting."

Deborah said: "You lost my money?"
Lombard said: "You could say that. And Friedman left this morning for Los Angeles."
Deborah said: "Who is Friedman?"
Lombard said: "The man who sold the boy to your brother."
Deborah said: "Im impressed. That information could have cost me £20,000."
Lombard said: "Well, I found a little more than that. Let me put it this way:...  Last night I thought your brother might be dead, tonight Im convinced he is. That said, I have no evidence and I advise you to let the police deal with it."

Deborah said: "Are we understood?"
Lombard said: "You watched the tape?  Friedman and his people dont just provide little kids and videotapes, Mrs De Moraes. Theyre in the import-export business. They run hotels here in London which they probably use as ware- houses and ports of call for their merchandise."
Deborah said: "Huh! Really? Hotels?"
Lombard said: "The hotels are useful capital investments. The kids liquid assets. My guess is they own hotels across the globe, and travel agencies specialising in flights from the third world to boot."

Lombard said: "Minimizes the risks. Children can be moved across borders using reliable businesses. These can also be used to move women and drugs... Anything that makes money really."
Deborah said: "W-why are you telling me all this, Mr Lombard?"

Deborah said: "You drive a hard bargain, Mr Lombard."
Lombard said: "You do want me to keep the job, dont you, Mrs De Moraes?"

Deborah said: "Mr Lombard?"
Lombard said: "Have you got a pen?"
Deborah said: "Just a moment...  Go ahead."
Lombard said: "The Mondrian, room 504. The number is 266 7548, plus the L.A. code..."
Deborah said: "...7548. Have you... Have you found him yet?"

Lombard said: "Are you all right?"
Deborah said: "Yes... You woke me up... Its the middle of the night here. Have you found Mr Friedman?"
Lombard said: "Not yet. The place I hoped to find him turns out to be little more than a contact address. Ill give it 24 hours. He just might show up.  If you need to reach me ask for Mr Lamont. Paul Lamont, all right?"
Deborah said: "Paul Lamont...?"
Lombard said: "Yeah. Goodnight, Mrs De Moraes."

Deborah said: "Mr Lombard. Mrs De Moraes..."
Lombard said: "Uh... Wait a moment, Mrs De Moraes..."

Deborah said: "Mr Lombard..."
Lombard said: "How are you, Mrs De Moraes?"
Deborah said: "When did you get back?"
Lombard said: "Why dont you ask when I left the Mondrian?"

Deborah said: "Im really sorry you were not called..."
Lombard said: "Youre repeating yourself, Mrs De Moraes."
Deborah said: "I... Well, were burying Leon tomorrow and... Look, I wish I had more time, but its late and with the funeral..."
Lombard said: "Arent you curious to know about Friedman?"
Deborah said: "I... If you dont mind, I do not think he matters now. It... Things turned out to be as we thought; Leon was weak. Theres no point in delving into his sad life anymore. Now, will you please tell me how much we owe you?"

Lombard said: "Black suits you."
Deborah said: "Sorry?"
Lombard said: "Whats in the bag? Underwear? To seduce your husband? Or is it for your own recreation?  Tell me, how come such a handsome couple sleep in seperate bedrooms? Is it because he does it with little children?"

Lombard said: "Or is it the other way round? The children are needed because you cant satisfy him?"
Deborah said: "You... You are out of order, Mr Lombard. I..."
Lombard said: "You what, Mrs De Moraes? YOU WHAT?"

Lombard said: "How did you break into my office, Deborah? Ladies of your standing dont learn to pick locks between shopping trips.  Come on, Deborah! Acting dumb doesnt suit you! Who knew Id found dirt on your brother, huh? Who knew it was in an envelope? Taking me for dead, whod want to make sure it didnt fall into the wrong hands?"
Deborah said: "Youre mad..."
Lombard said: "Ive had a long and unpleasant day. Im tired and Im angry. But mad? Not yet.  I paid Leons boy a visit this morning. Found him alive and well. Why havent you told your husband where he is since reading my note, eh?"
Deborah said: "Why... I dont know what youre talking about."
Lombard said: "You know hed have had him killed, dont you? Does a conscience still burn somewhere inside your sore mind, Deborah? Or is it just cold expediency? Could the boy perhaps come in useful when and if the day ever comes for you to face up to the man you married?"
Deborah said: "Have you finished?"
Lombard said: "When did you learn about his taste for kids, huh? On your honeymoon? Or was it later, when bitterness set in and you turned against your beloved but weak little brother? How did you find out? Did he confess? Try to convert you perhaps? Or was it womans intuition? Or just the way he fucked you?"

Deborah said: "You do have a vivid imagination, Mr Lombard. I only wish youd use it fruitfully instead of in being obnoxious. I fail to understand your purpose in this. Still, say what youre owed if you still wish to be paid or get out, all right?"
Lombard said: "I guess the news youd sent me after Friedman didnt go down too well, eh?"

Deborah said: "Whatever the reason, Im sorry I did. Goodbye, Mr Lombard. I believe you know your way out."
Lombard said: "You knew he had nothing to do with your brothers disappearance, didnt you?"
Deborah said: "Huh! Dont you recall convincing me he had?  You should learn to live with your mistakes, Mr Lombard. There is some merit in it."
Lombard said: "I take it you learnt to live with yours then. Take it all the mind-dulling pills in your medicine cabinet are surplus to your well-being..."
Deborah said: "How... When did you..."
Lombard said: "It must be tough being married to Adonis to end up sleeping alone every night. Sleep must be hard coming. Whats harder? The thought of the fine litter you two could have bred if? Or imagining what he does with his children?"

Lombard said: "Tell me, did he kill his little victims too?"
Deborah said: "No!"

Lombard said: "What do you mean, No, Mrs De Moraes?"
Deborah said: "My brother hung himself."
Lombard said: "Does the name Pierre Dreyer mean anything to you? Hes a client of mine and a friend of your husband."
Deborah said: "Leon hung himself."
Lombard said: "Adonis thought your brothers bodyd be found reasonably quickly when he hung it in Epping Forest, didnt he? Seemed like a good idea. An ex-junkie, obsessed with death; the perfect candidate for suicide. He just forgot one thing: forest ramblers are rare during your average blustery English November. An Englishman might have thought of that, but a Brazilian..."
Deborah said: "Leon hung himself..."
Lombard said: "Leons not found, your parents worry, talk of hiring help to find him, even mention their manhunter friends perhaps... and Adonis panics, takes control, brings me in reckoning a small- time detective is unlikely to dig up anything awkward, not before Leons found anyhow. He must have kicked himself when he learned Id exceeded his expectations."
Deborah said: "Leon hung himself..."
Lombard said: "Leon didnt hang himself, Deborah. Your husband killed him and made his death look like suicide. How did he do it, eh? Strangulation? Drugs? No doubt an autopsy will tell."

Lombard said: "I doubt Friedman ever even met Leon, Deborah. Friedman dealt with select customers. As for my envelope, had he know where it was he wouldnt have mistaken me for a hitman called Lamont when we met in Los Angeles."
Deborah said: "...You-you spoke to him?"
Lombard said: "Not in the strict sense of the word, no. He was in too much of a hurry to kill me when we first met and too wasted in acid when I caught up with him later."

Lombard said: "Your brother stumbled upon Adoniss little secret, didnt he? And traded his silence for a kid and some cash. And Adonis fell for it, bought him his kid, sent him away, and then killed him when he came back for more.  Leon didnt come here to borrow money for prints. He came to extort a second kids life. Your flunkey let him in, so his visit couldnt be concealed, hence the exhibition story. There was no exhibition. Just as you suspected. Remember, Deborah? Leon does his own prints. Wouldnt want anyone to interfere with his Art.  I should have paid more attention to your words. Perhaps its the way you say them..."
Deborah said: "If-if my car is there, I could be the one who... Why dont you accuse me of killing my brother?"
Lombard said: "Kids are not your thing, Deborah. Youd have been ready for me when I turned up with Sleeping Beauty. Damn it! Then too I should have paid more attention. Not Leon, you said. It struck me at the time, but obviously not hard enough. You didnt say My God!, or whatever else well-bred ladies squeak on hearing Uncle Henry misbehaved. Not Leon. Who then?  You sure were right about one thing, Deborah, the job was too formidable for me. I should have thought a little more before I left for Los Angeles. But there I was focused so hard on Friedman Id stopped thinking. Nothing added up - Leon soliciting money for prints while buying kids at £15,000 a go; infiltrating the world of child traffickers; duping Friedman into selling him a little boy... You sure were right. The job was too formidable for me. But you knew that, didnt you?"
Deborah said: "Leon could still have hung himself."
Lombard said: "Oh no. At long last Leon had found a mission. Hed never have killed himself when glory beckoned. Your husband killed your brother. And thanks to you, almost got me killed too."

Deborah said: "Youre wrong about my being there, though. Carlos borrowed my car that day, his had broken down...  Leon saw it, like you, assumed I was there, thought hed wait to ask for a lift. But Carlos turned up, with the tape you found...  Leon got his lift, and accidentally picked up the tape with his photo equipment when he got out. He watched it, confronted Carlos, threatened to tell the police about the hotel... I dont know how he knew about the hotel. Perhaps Carlos talked too much... My husband did not tell me... You more or less guessed the rest...  I didnt know any of this before you left for Los Angeles."
Lombard said: "You dont say."
Deborah said: "That my brother, my husband and your Mr Friedman were linked, that much I had guessed. But that my husband had killed Leon? No."

Lombard said: "Why did you send me after Friedman? To atone for your sins?"
Deborah said: "I didnt know my husband and Friedman knew each other. I just...  Do you think we spoke about it? Ive known for five years. Hes known Ive known for five years... But not once have we spoken about it. There are things one just doesnt speak about..."
Lombard said: "One just doesnt... Tell me, what does one speak about, huh?"
Deborah said: "Think what you like. But dont presume to understand."
Lombard said: "I dont."
Deborah said: "Good."
Lombard said: "Is there anything to understand?"
Deborah said: "Why do I feel I neednt answer that?"
Lombard said: "Rich. Young. Beautiful. You must at least get a kick out of what he does to his kids."
Deborah said: "You bastard..."
Lombard said: "Five years of it. Surely, youd have divorced him if he disgusted you?"
Deborah said: "You splendid bastard..."
Lombard said: "Are there truly no extenuating circumstances?"
Deborah said: "...Were turning in circles."
Lombard said: "And you still havent told me why you sent me after Friedman."
Deborah said: "Maybe I wanted to give my husband a fright."
Lombard said: "A fright?... Five years of cowardice led to your brother being murdered and you wanted to give his murderer a fright?"
Deborah said: "I didnt know who or what had happened to my brother yet, Mr Lombard!"
Lombard said: "What was the idea? Husband is filled with fear when he learns his child suppliers being tailed?"
Deborah said: "Something like that."
Lombard said: "Something like that?"
Deborah said: "Something like that."
Lombard said: "What happened? Adonis slapped you about a little and you reverted to cowardice?"
Deborah said: "Here we go again."
Lombard said: "Where is that?"
Deborah said: "Simplify and damn."
Lombard said: "Dont you believe in simplicity?"
Deborah said: "Should I?"
Lombard said: "We all have to like what we become. Cowards included. We achieve this by complicating things a little. But its never that complicated really."
Deborah said: "You seem to know what youre talking about."
Lombard said: "Perhaps it came to me while dying in a Californian desert because a woman set upon giving her husband a fright got slapped about a little."
Deborah said: "My husband didnt need to slap me about, Mr Lombard. I volunteered..."
Lombard said: "To get me killed...?"
Deborah said: "I didnt intend it that way... It just happened.  He heard from Laurence that youd been back.  That wed argued. He asked why and it just happened; I told him everything... I couldnt help it. Wanted to see him scared. I had never seen him scared before, you see..."
Lombard said: "Well, I hope you enjoyed yourself."
Deborah said: "Perhaps I did... Until fear turned into panic. Thats when he hit me, and told me hed killed my brother... You dont know what youve done, he said.  Were in deep trouble, he said. We, he said. We.  Wed both be killed if Friedman ever found out you were working for us, he said. We had to stop you and Friedman meeting..."

Lombard said: "You know something? Ive just seen so much ugliness I dont think Id mind four walls and dinner served every night at a regular time.  Id hoped to have a private word with Adonis, but if thats the way you want it."
Deborah said: "What are you doing? You cant. I..."
Lombard said: "Do you think the boy you saved might identify your husband as his purchaser, Deborah? And then, your brothers not buried yet. As I said earlier, an autopsy will..."
Deborah said: "He... He is dead!  MY HUSBAND IS DEAD!  Call my parents. Theyll tell you. Call them!"

Deborah said: "Do you think wed let him get away with the murder of my brother?"
Lombard said: "We? You and your parents killed your husband?"
Deborah said: "No. Not us..."

Deborah said: "They found his body yesterday. In the pool at our house in Sao Paulo. He drowned. Drank too much, went for a swim and drowned."
Lombard said: "Your flunkey said he was expected back tonight."
Deborah said: "The staff dont know yet...  I called my parents, told them everything...  I just couldnt take any more..."
Lombard said: "Get to the point, will you..."
Deborah said: "My parents flew back from Israel... Told him they would get him killed unless he flew back to Brazil immediately and agreed to a divorce. He flew back to Brazil...  And his drowning was arranged..."

Lombard said: "So you did talk about it, huh?"
Deborah said: "On... Once...  Once... What are we... you going to do?"
Lombard said: "What do you suggest?"
Deborah said: "I dont know. Everyones dead..."
Lombard said: "Your parents arranged the visit to my office?"

Lombard said: "Why the hell couldnt you divorce the man?"
Deborah said: "You wouldnt understand."

Deborah said: "I... We have to bury Leon tommorrow..."
Lombard said: "The dead can wait."

Emily said: "May I ask where youre from, Mr Lamont?"

Emily said: "I cant believe this...  Whats coming now, eh? If I dont pay all Hells gonna break loose, is that it?"
Lombard said: "Well, Id sooner mug an old lady..."
Emily said: "You...  Jesus Christ!"

Emily said: "Okay. The woman just cant walk away...  I want straight answers. No hesitation or I walk for sure. Why cant you go to your Embassy?"
Lombard said: "French people need a visa to enter this country. That takes time and I didnt have any. I used a British passport. My names not Lamont but Lombard. Xavier Lombard."

Emily said: "Where were you staying before the attempt on your life and why cant you go back there?"
Lombard said: "The Mondrian, room 504. I was checked out in my absence."
Emily said: "By your Austrian?"
Lombard said: "Yeah."

Emily said: "You dont know why hes come to Los Angeles?  The man you say he killed? Who was he? A colleague of his?"
Lombard said: "No. A poor little rich boy who thought hed save a few kids from their retailer. He disappeared on his second shopping expedition."

Emily said: "Have you never heard of collect calls, Mr..."
Lombard said: "Lombard...  It will take a few days for the things I need to get here. Meanwhile Id sooner not draw police attention walking the streets like a hungry dog..."
Emily said: "There are over 4 million people in this city - why me?"
Lombard said: "I thought youd never ask... As I was having my coffee and crescents at the Mondrian the other morning I spotted your photograph in the Los Angeles Times... Theres a tough lady, I thought. Just the kind who might help me..."

Emily said: "You know where to look for your Austrian, right?"
Lombard said: "I know where to look."
Emily said: "I might come back, I might not. But if I do, it wont be for a couple of hours."

Emily said: "Thereve been 7 international treaties since 1904 aimed at preventing child slavery. But still no worldwide body dedicated to investigating the maltreatment of children used in sexual exploitation. Officially, its just not called for. Sit down. Can I offer you some coffee?"
Lombard said: "I wouldnt mind. Thank you."

Emily said: "A recent acquisition. Weve had four break- ins this year alone; files stolen, computers wrecked, faeces smeared on walls. The good guys dismiss us as alarmist do-gooders; the bad guys will risk prison to intimidate and rob us. An easy living indeed, Mr Lombard.  I got through to Moreau and Jane. I left your landlord out of it. Your flats been broken into. Jane wants you to call her back."
Lombard said: "Hah... What about Nathalie?"
Emily said: "No answer. You have no passport and your Embassys out. How do you plan to leave the U.S., Mr Lombard?"
Lombard said: "Im sure Ill find a way."
Emily said: "Like youll find a way to stop your Austrian killing you a second time round?"

Lombard said: "Thank you for the guided tour, but would you mind telling me what were doing here?"
Emily said: "How come youre alive? Child traffickers usually achieve what they set out to do.  What am I really looking at here, huh?  Are you really not just a lousy private eye? Am I really looking at some kind of cunning dispenser of justice in disguise?"
Lombard said: "Did you call me up here to enjoy yourself, Emily, or to let me use your phone? Because we seem to have a slight problem..."

Emily said: "Its give and take time, Mr Lombard. You need help, we need information. You didnt really expect me to put my ass on the line helping a criminal just for the thrill of it, did you?"
Lombard said: "A criminal?"
Emily said: "Did you not enter this country illegally?"

Lombard said: "Huh... I have no... ... hard evidence..."
Emily said: "Come on, Mr Lombard. You tailed your man all the way here from Europe. You told me you knew where to find him, remember? Or didnt I hear you right?"

Emily said: "A little too tight, eh?  ...They were my sons. Only thirteen and already six feet tall. A real lanky boy...  I... Theres some cold chicken salad in the fridge if youre hungry."
Lombard said: "Thank you. But I think Ill go to bed. Its been a long day."
Emily said: "Right... Well, Ill get your money first thing in the morning, okay?  Okay. Goodnight then."
Lombard said: "Yeah. Goodnight, Emily."
Emily said: "Dont fall asleep with your hair wet."

Emily said: "What am I to do with the packages if..."
Lombard said: "Burn the passport and keep the money. Think of it as a donation to the cause..."

Lombard said: "Get a pen and dont ask any questions."
Emily said: "Oh. What... Yeah. Okay."
Lombard said: "Route 395. Past Edwards Air Force base and about half a mile before a place called the Red Mountain Motel. Theres a dirt track with a Closed to the public sign. It leads to some kind of ranch in the middle of nowhere. If you havent heard from me by morning send the cavalry, okay? But not before, you hear?"
Emily said: "Have you found your man? Is that where he is?"
Lombard said: "I think so. And if it comes to it, tell the cops anything you think will make them move. Whatever you came up with couldnt come close to how bad it is. Bye now."

Emily said: "Look, you dont tell me about some Godforsaken place where stuff so bad even I couldnt imagine it goes down and expect me to go quietly to sleep! What happened? Whos the guy? The Austrian?"
Lombard said: "Whos the guy? Whos the guy! Nom de Dieu!  Had the guy got a closer look at you or your number plate Id have had to kill him."

Emily said: "What...?"
Lombard said: "What...  Some kind of organ factory... Pregnant girls doped up. Babies. Theres a lot of people back there. Theyre holding a seminar. Traffickings the past, breeding the future..."

Lombard said: "Friedmans dead... They killed him..."
Emily said: "So who... Whos the man? Where is he?"
Lombard said: "Some Italian I picked up back there. Hes in the boot of the Mustang."
Emily said: "Italian? The Mafia...?"
Lombard said: "Who knows. Who cares...  You wanted slime. You got slime."

Lombard said: "No one saw me but the Italian and a dog. I blew up their generator. They thought it was an accident but by now they must have realised one of their party is missing. It might make them feel insecure enough to decide to pack up..."
Emily said: "Were both thinking the same thing, right?"
Lombard said: "Do you know a friendly cop?"

Lombard said: "Call from the motel and tell him if he moves fast enough there might be something left of a body dissolving in acid.  Can I have the keys to your house?"
Emily said: "That-that wont do. Thats not the way it goes. You saw it, you tell it, thats the way..."
Lombard said: "Im finished here and Im tired, Emily. You shouldnt be here. Now dont make it worse."
Emily said: "A seminar in a baby breeding farm! Bodies in acid! You think Ill get anywhere with that? Jesus! With luck I might raise a laugh. They might even send a patrol car to check the place out. Whatever, itll be too late."
Lombard said: "Then find another way."
Emily said: "Look! Either you talk or the creeps are gonna walk. For gods sake. What am I supposed to say? I got this from a French guy from England who broke in there to have a chat with an Austrian child trafficker? Is that it?"

Emily said: "Damn it! You cant fucking walk away from this!"
Lombard said: "Its up to you whether they walk or not."

Emily said: "...Im Emily Stewart. The hysterical female who sees evil everywhere since the day her thirteen year-old boy disappeared. The pain in the ass who cries wolf at the drop of a hat. However I go about this thats who I am. Do you get what Im fucking saying, Mr Lombard?"
Lombard said: "What about your friendly cop?"
Emily said: "My ex-husband. My work drove him away. Made his life a misery. He thinks Im obsessed, punishing myself for what happened to our son.  But hes a good guy. Hell listen to you. He wont turn you in if I ask him not to. I can pretty much guarantee that. Okay?"

Lombard said: "Theyd never let me go. And youd end up in more trouble than you know for helping me."
Emily said: "You cannot walk away from this. You cannot."
Lombard said: "I can... The question is, can you lie to your ex- husband?"

Lombard said: "Nothing sticks to slime, Emily.  This should cover what you lent me."
Emily said: "Huh! And they say charitys only rewarded in Heaven... Hallelujah...  Christ..."

Emily said: "Whitney Armstrong, my deputy. What Whitneys trying to say is that you might not live to tell the tale next time you meet your Austrian..."
Whitney said: "And losing you, wed lose him. And that would be a shame, dont you agree?"

Whitney said: "Hi..."

Whitney said: "Weve still got the Italian..."

Whitney said: "Shell be alright. Shes tough..."

Nathalie said: "Quest-ce que tu veux?"

Nathalie said: "Où est passé ton salon?"

Lombard said: "Okay, shitbag. Im only going to ask you this once. Where is Friedman?"
The Italian said: "Who?  I dont know who the fuck youre talking about, sunshine."

Lombard said: "Five seconds. Then you die."
The Italian said: "Fuck..."
Lombard said: "Three..."

The Italian said: "Youre the lantern man, huh?  If you wanna see whats left of him..."
Lombard said: "The acid bath?"
The Italian said: "Huh! Youve been around, eh?"

Lombard said: "Why did you kill Friedman?"
The Italian said: "Let me give you a tip, asshole - no one pulls stunts like what you pulled in London and here tonight and hopes to get away with it. It upsets people. Its wrong. Fucking wrong."
Lombard said: "Why did you kill him?"
The Italian said: "Huh! You turned him into a liability, didnt you know?"
Lombard said: "Nice way to help a colleague in trouble."
The Italian said: "Thats just it. The sonofabitch didnt ask for help from his colleagues...  Testa di cazzo! Hiring some amateur outsiders to fix you... He hasnt gone to hell too soon... And neither will you, Mr Lamont!"

Lombard said: "Are you telling me Friedman didnt tell you I was here looking for him?"
The Italian said: "If he had, youd be dead."
Lombard said: "So why didnt he?"
The Italian said: "What do you think, huh?"
Lombard said: "I think youd rather not know what I think."
The Italian said: "Huh. Maybe he figured the news our London bureau got a visit from a hitman on behalf of a pissed off client wouldnt go down too well. He only shared his guilty secret last night. And then only cause he was so fucking edgy after calling his hotel we persuaded him to talk."
Lombard said: "So you killed him and went to clean out his hotel room... How did Friedman say he got to know where to find me?"
The Italian said: "Thats the beauty. An anonymous call. Makes you wonder how many people know what youre up to, eh, French-fuck?"

Lombard said: "Try again, and this time be polite."
The Italian said: "I can only tell you what he told us..."
Lombard said: "Not even scum like Friedman would go to the trouble of killing a stranger on the strength of one anonymous call."
The Italian said: "Some guy called to let him know the Frenchman whod called the night before he left London was in L.A. looking to kill him. He did his sums and decided to take the call seriously."
Lombard said: "What sums?"
The Italian said: "Two stiffs and a missing kid followed your visit to one of the London hotels. He didnt need your confession..."
Lombard said: "Youre sure he said his caller was a man?"
The Italian said: "Thats what he said..."

The Italian said: "When they realise Im missing..."
Lombard said: "Shut up and walk..."

The Italian said: "What you gonna do? Kill me?"
Lombard said: "Dont tempt me. The last scumbag who thought I might kill him died soon afterwards."
The Italian said: "Huh. Im a businessman. What are you, eh?"

Lombard said: "Moreau? Cest moi. Alors..."
Moreau said: "Salut, Laurent. Ouais. It wasnt easy but I got what you wanted through Interpol. Say, whats your business with these Spitzes?"
Lombard said: "They lost their son. Why?"

These people are well-connected, Laurent; former Israeli prime minister, etc. The ladys also president of an international Zionist organisation... Anyway, you get the picture."

Man On Dais said: "Ha ha... Yes. With prices reaching an all time low, the name of the game has become have-it- where-its-at... As we all know, transportation has always been the costliest and trickiest part of this business..."
