Charles said: "Oh dear, why is life so complicated? Sometimes I really wish I could be someone else."
Aulon said: "That's a good idea, sire."
Charles said: "What do you mean?"
Aulon said: "Let someone else pretend to be you, and see if..."
Charles said: "... if she can find me? -- That's a brilliant idea!  If she's really been sent by God she'll discover the trap, and if she's an assassin she'll kill the wrong man!  Bring her up!"

Charles said: "Why not you -- Jean d'Aulon?  The only man who's poorer than I am, and so the only man I can trust. Dignified, honorable, wise... what more could we ask of a king?"
Aulon said: "My lord, I'm not sure that..."

Charles said: "My dear Aulon, to you it shall befall the honor of impersonating the royal blood!"
Aulon said: "Majesty, I can't..."
Charles said: "Why, are you not ready to die for your king?"
Aulon said: "Of course I am, it's just that..."
Charles said: "Good.  Until then, feel free to live like a king!"

Aulon said: "Sire, you know how bad I am at this sort of game."
Charles said: "So... pretend it's not a game."

Charles said: "Jeanne, this is -- in fact -- my loyal friend and finest archer, Jean d'Aulon.  Jean... I place her in your care.  Find her suitable lodgings -- here -- in the castle... and guard her with your life."
Aulon said: "Yes, my lord."

Aulon said: "Here... to help pay Jeanne's ransom. All the Captains gave what they could, as well as the citizens of Orleans and the other towns she saved..."
Charles said: "Very generous of you all.  How much?"
Aulon said: "10,000 gold crowns."

Charles said: "My dear Aulon...  That's fine..."
Aulon said: "Jeanne's been badly injured!  She jumped from the top of a tower into a frozen moat!"

Charles said: "It's a miracle she's not dead!"
Aulon said: "We have to do something before she tries it again!  I beg of you, my lord, don't let her down... let me organize an escape..."
Charles said: "Jean, it's... it's not so easy..."
Aulon said: "But not impossible... Gilles and La Hire are ready to risk everything to save her..."
Charles said: "Jean... me dear, loyal Jean... why do you want to oppose the will of God?  Jeanne wanted to go to Compiegne -- we let her -- she got caught.  Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?"
Aulon said: "No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands."

Aulon said: "What do you fear most now... my sword?  ... or his hands?"
Charles said: "Tremoille... don't.  Please..."

Aulon said: "Listen, please accept my apologies for... you know, me pretending to be the... well it wasn't really my idea... well, yes it was my idea but..."
Jeanne said: "Do you think I could have some water?"

Jeanne said: "I would like some fresh straw."
Aulon said: "Louis... water and fresh straw!"

Jeanne said: "And I would like to see a priest."
Aulon said: "Now?"
Jeanne said: "Yes.  I didn't confess today."
Aulon said: "Right.  Raymond... a priest."

Jeanne said: "I shall also be needing a war horse -- mine is too slow -- and armor -- and a good sword -- and an artist to make me a banner."
Aulon said: "Now?"
Jeanne said: "Better today than tomorrow."
Aulon said: "Well... uh -- this might take a little time -- but let me see what I can do."

Jeanne said: "I also need someone who can read and write."
Aulon said: "This I can do.  I was studying at the University of Paris -- till the English invaded it."
Jeanne said: "I thought you were an archer?"
Aulon said: "Yes, I am.  I'm an archer who can read and write.  Who do you want to write to?"
Jeanne said: "The King of England.  I want to give them the chance to leave Orleans in peace before I get there."

Jeanne said: "Who do they think I am?!"
Aulon said: "Jeanne, calm down.  You can't blame the people -- they've been hearing all about you for weeks."
Jeanne said: "There's nothing to hear -- I haven't done anything.  And why haven't I done anything?  Because none of you will listen to me!!"

Aulon said: "Jeanne, stop it!"
Jeanne said: "How dare you stop me doing God's will!"

Aulon said: "He didn't tell you to cut all your hair off...!"
Jeanne said: "How dare you tell me what God tells me to do!"
Aulon said: "Alright, whatever -- but since He's not going to come down and cut it himself, at least let someone cut it properly!"

Jeanne said: "What did they say?"
Aulon said: "Uh... they said... they will think about it."
Jeanne said: "Good."
Aulon said: "But... to be honest... I don't think they'll leave tomorrow."

Aulon said: "What's going on?!"
Jeanne said: "They've started the battle without me!"

Jeanne said: "Not so... easily.  Why aren't you... fighting...?  go on... we're almost there..."
Aulon said: "Jeanne, you've been badly wounded..."
Jeanne said: "No, it's... it's nothing, it's..."

Jeanne said: "Alright... I promise to rest if you promise... to go back to the battle."
Aulon said: "I promise..."

Jeanne said: "The king said you're his finest archer...?"
Aulon said: "Well..."
Jeanne said: "Come with me..."

Aulon said: "Jeanne, calm down, do you hear me? Are you alright?"
Jeanne said: "Yes..."
Aulon said: "It's over, Jeanne.  We won, just as you said!"

Jeanne said: "I'll go."
Aulon said: "Jeanne, no..."

Aulon said: "Jeanne...!  Are you alright?"
Jeanne said: "Yes.  Yes, I'm fine...  We need more brushwood!  Why are you staring at me like that?"
Aulon said: "Because there's an arrow in your leg."

Aulon said: "Jeanne... the king has ordered us not to ride with you anymore."
Jeanne said: "So... what am I supposed to do now?"

Jeanne said: "They've abandoned me... like everyone."
Aulon said: "What... what do you mean?"
Jeanne said: "It's been weeks since they spoke to me.  Since the coronation... no signs... nothing..."
Aulon said: "Maybe their silence is a sign...? Maybe it's a sign to go home?"
Jeanne said: "It's not time yet.  My mission is not over yet.  There is still more I must do before I can really -- finally -- go home."
Aulon said: "But how do you know that these -- these voices aren't really just -- well, you."

Jeanne said: "Well of course they're me!  That's how God talks to me.  If you listen hard enough, even you can hear him. Everyone can hear him."
Aulon said: "But I hear so many voices... one voice saying one thing, another voice saying the opposite -- love your enemy, kill your enemy -- what is good, what is evil...?"
Jeanne said: "All you have to do is stop talking and just listen."
Aulon said: "But how do you know what you hear is the truth?"
Jeanne said: "I don't know it.  I feel it."
Aulon said: "You make it sound so simple..."
Jeanne said: "The truth is always simple... it's you, Jean, who's making things complicated."
Aulon said: "Me?!  It's not me, it's God who makes everything complicated!  If he's all-powerful, why not let the English stay on their island in the first place?  And why let this war go on for a hundred years?  And why send you out to fight when a girl like you should be at home with your family?  Why, why?!"
Jeanne said: "So... even you don't believe in me anymore..."
Aulon said: "Jeanne... I believe in you... more than anyone..."

Jeanne said: "If you really want to help me, there's one thing you can do."
Aulon said: "Tell me..."
Jeanne said: "Tell the king to give me more men."

Jeanne said: "That's not what I asked... Why do you want to marry me?"
Aulon said: "You listen to your voices, I listen to my heart."

Jeanne said: "What did the king say?"
Aulon said: "He said that... he's making a treaty with the Duke of Burgundy and..."
Jeanne said: "It's a trap!  They're buying time till they can bring over more soldiers from England!"
Aulon said: "Did your voices tell you that?  You told me you hadn't heard them for months..."
Jeanne said: "No, but..."
Aulon said: "Or maybe it's Jeanne who's in a trap -- her own trap -- a downward spiral that she can't stop?"
Jeanne said: "Did you come back to marry me or to insult me?"
Aulon said: "To marry you."

Jeanne said: "I will ask my voices... if they come back one day.  Meanwhile... I'm going to Compiegne."
Aulon said: "Jeanne... I have been hearing voices -- and believe me, those voices left me in no doubt that you must not go to Compiegne!"

Aulon said: "Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me."
Jeanne said: "I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God."
Aulon said: "But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?"
Jeanne said: "But it is what I want."
Aulon said: "To be killed in battle?"
Jeanne said: "If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever."

Aulon said: "Will you at least let me stay with you?"
Jeanne said: "It would not be the same without you."

Aulon said: "We must sound the retreat!"
Jeanne said: "Not yet!"

Jeanne said: "Get back inside the town and see if the English are attacking from the other side!"
Aulon said: "But... why... what's the point?"
Jeanne said: "Do as I say!"
Aulon said: "I want to stay with you..."
Jeanne said: "That's an order!"

Jeanne said: "I am ready now..."
Aulon said: "Just give me a moment and then you'll be free..."
Jeanne said: "I'm already free..."
Aulon said: "Yes yes... any moment... you're always so impatient..."

Jeanne said: "My gentle Captain... I'm staying."
Aulon said: "I -- I don't understand..."
Jeanne said: "One day you will."
Aulon said: "You don't know what you're saying. You're going to leave this place, Jeanne -- you're going home -- or whatever you want -- you're going to be happy, and have children, and..."

Aulon said: "... and maybe the king will give you some money, and a little land, and a title even...  ... wouldn't that be a fine thing? You, a lady of title!"
Jeanne said: "I'm staying, Jean."
Aulon said: "No, you must come, Jeanne -- we need you -- so much has happened since you left... I have a new horse now, a white one, just like yours... and La Hire hardly swears at all anymore...  You can't stay -- they'll burn you!"
Jeanne said: "I'm not afraid of the fire anymore. It will purify me..."
Aulon said: "Jeanne, you can't leave us like this!"

Aulon said: "Jeanne's alive!"
Dunois said: "Good."
Aulon said: "We have to press home the attack!"
Dunois said: "Sound the retreat..."
Aulon said: "But I promised Jeanne we'd fight on!"
Dunois said: "I made no such promise.  Sound the retreat for the night!"
Aulon said: "But that was her order!"
Dunois said: "I'm fed up with taking her orders. She swore she'd defeat the English before nightfall, instead of which she goes and plays the fool and gets herself nearly killed!  Look at the mess we're in!  That's her mess, not mine...!  We're worse off then if she'd never come at all!  ... now do as I say and Sound the Retreat!"

Jeanne said: "I won't tell you more about that. I'm more afraid of displeasing Him than not answering you..."
Beaupere said: "You're afraid of displeasing God when telling the truth?!"
Jeanne said: "No..."
Beaupere said: "Did God forbid you to tell the truth?"
Jeanne said: "No.  But my revelations were for the King of France, not for you."

Jeanne said: "Go onto the next question."
Beaupere said: "Good advice for the French, not for the English!  Do you think God hates the English?"
Jeanne said: "I don't know, but you're all men of the church... why not ask Him yourself?"

Beaupere said: "Is it true that you launched an attack on Paris?"
Jeanne said: "I tried to."
Beaupere said: "It was on a Sunday, wasn't it?"
Jeanne said: "I don't remember.  Maybe."
Beaupere said: "Do you think is was a good idea to launch an attack on a holy day?"
Jeanne said: "I don't know..."
Beaupere said: "And didn't you order the citizens of Paris to surrender the city in the name of the King of Heaven?"
Jeanne said: "No... I said "Surrender in the name of the King of France"..."
Beaupere said: "That is not what is written in the evidence... look for yourself!"

Jeanne said: "I can't read."
Beaupere said: "Ah, yes, I forgot... God sent us an illiterate peasant to carry out such an important mission!  Do you think that God made the right decision, to take an ignorant girl to save the kingdom of France?"
Jeanne said: "I leave the answer to God."

Beaupere said: "Do you have a sword?"
Jeanne said: "Quite a few."
Beaupere said: "Didn't you also carry a banner?"
Jeanne said: "Yes..."
Beaupere said: "Which did you prefer, your banner or your sword?"
Jeanne said: "I was forty times more fond of my banner than my sword."
Beaupere said: "And why was that?  Did it have some particular value or power?"
Jeanne said: "No, it's just... a sword is a weapon."
Beaupere said: "And?"
Jeanne said: "And so I... I prefer my banner."
Beaupere said: "Why?"
Jeanne said: "To avoid killing anyone."
Beaupere said: "Are you saying that if you had not been carrying your banner you'd have killed more people?"

Jeanne said: "No, of course not... I never killed anyone..."
Beaupere said: "Then perhaps the temptation to kill would have been stronger... too strong perhaps...?"
Jeanne said: "No!  I warned the English to go back home -- I begged them not to force us to fight -- they knew the defeat I would bring on them... why didn't they listen to me?"
Beaupere said: "We have numerous witnesses who can confirm that you were not always carrying your banner..."
Jeanne said: "Yes, probably... maybe..."
Beaupere said: "So sometimes you were carrying just your sword?"
Jeanne said: "Yes, but..."
Beaupere said: "Did you use the sword that you held in your hand?"
Jeanne said: "No, I... I held it up to..."
Beaupere said: "You held up your sword and flourished it about in the air? Like this?"
Jeanne said: "Yes, maybe... I don't remember..."
Beaupere said: "... so you were in the middle of the battlefield, with your sword in your hand, waving it above your head... charging against the enemy, screaming and yelling... fighting for your life... and you want us to believe that in the middle of all this excitement you never killed anyone?"
Jeanne said: "No, I... I never killed anyone!"

Yolande said: "It is the sacred place that matters, Charles -- not the size.  Am I correct, Bishop?"
Bishop said: "Oh yes, my lady.  All true kings of France must first be anointed in our great cathedral of Rheims... with the holy oil of Clovis... for it was within these very walls that Saint Remy received the sacred oil from Heaven, brought to him by a white dove for the anointing of King Clovis..."

Bishop said: "I don't understand... the holy oil of Clovis... it was quite full the last time I saw it..."
Yolande said: "And when was that?"
Bishop said: "Well... at the coronation of King Charles VI..."
Yolande said: "Thirty years ago?  I'm not surprised it's gone..."
Bishop said: "No no, you don't understand -- this is no ordinary oil -- this is miraculous... this oil was brought from heaven by a white dove to crown King Clovis in this... very... cathedral..."

Bishop said: "W-w-what are you doing?!"
Yolande said: "Performing a miracle."

Buck said: "Arrest them!"
Cauchon said: "What are you doing?  This is an ecclesiastical court -- you have no right to do this!"
Buck said: "Rouen is in English territory.  I have the right to do anything I like.  Take them away."

Buck said: "Who's running this trial, you or her?  I can't believe it!  This wretched girl -- how dare she speak to us like that?"
Cauchon said: "She's loyal to her king... it's only to be expected that she..."

Cauchon said: "I understand your impatience, but if you want this trial to be acknowledged as legal we must follow correct procedure and..."
Buck said: "To hell with procedure!  We paid a bloody fortune for this slut, and we can do whatever the hell we like with her, whether the church likes it or not -- is that clear?"
Cauchon said: "But if this trial seems fixed, I fear you'll have the very opposite result to the one you want..."
Buck said: "We want her burned as a witch!"
Cauchon said: "But in order to do so, the church must first prove her heresy, or else you'll be burning a martyr..."
Buck said: "Well then?  Start proving... or else the church will have another martyr!"

Cauchon said: "Calm down, my lord, I beg you!"
Buck said: "How can I calm down when I'm made the laughing-stock of the whole court?!  I've had enough!"
Cauchon said: "Be patient, my lord... you've seen how it is.  This girl has a way with people... but everyday we're making progress..."
Buck said: "So long as this bitch remains alive, our armies refuse to fight!  Don't you understand?  They want proof that God is on their side... and the only way they're going to believe that is when they see her being burnt as a witch!"

Cauchon said: "It is not for us to burn her, my lord.  That is your prerogative."
Buck said: "... and your prerogative is to find her guilty..."
Cauchon said: "But we can't do that unless she admits to blasphemy..."
Buck said: "Well what are you waiting for? You've got a castle full of racks and ropes and pulleys:  go and torture the bitch!"

Cauchon said: "You won't be able to drag anything from her that way.  You also must realize that many of my colleagues are... well, scared..."
Buck said: "Scared of a girl?"
Cauchon said: "Scared to make a mistake.  Supposing she's right... supposing she really has been sent by God??"

Buck said: "Whose side are you on, Cauchon?"
Cauchon said: "I'm on the side of our Mother Holy Church.  Besides, a confession under torture will never convince anyone of her guilt."
Buck said: "Well find some other way!  Be creative.  Tell them she fucks the devil... Hmm, not a bad idea... why can't you say that?  Sounds good to me... and who can prove she doesn't?"

Burgundy said: "So... here is the famous Jeanne... Savior of Orleans... terror of the English?  You look pretty ordinary to me..."
Jeanne said: "Am I... am I dead?"
Burgundy said: "Dead you're worthless, darling."
Jeanne said: "Where... where am I?"
Burgundy said: "Guess."

Jeanne said: "My king will pay any ransom you ask."
Burgundy said: "Your king?  Ah yes, of course... What's he going to pay me with? Cows?  Chickens?  I prefer gold, and the English have plenty.  I wonder how much they'll pay... to have the Witch of Orleans in their clutches? Those English are so arrogant, they can't accept the idea of being defeated by a peasant girl... it has to have been the devil's work."
Jeanne said: "God defeated the English, not me."
Burgundy said: "And God who allowed you to be caught?"

Catherine said: "Are you alright?  Did they hurt you?"
Jeanne said: "No no, I'm fine, really..."
Catherine said: "I was so worried -- we've all been looking for you!  The English are everywhere!  O thank you, lord!"

Catherine said: "Really?"
Jeanne said: "I was talking to the priest, and do you know what he said to me?"

Catherine said: "Quick -- hide in here..."
Jeanne said: "What about you?"
Catherine said: "Don't worry about me -- just stay in here... and don't move!"
Jeanne said: "But where are you going to be?"
Catherine said: "I'll be right here... I promise."

Jeanne said: "Oh, thank you Lord!  I'm so glad to see you!  I need to confess... I haven't been confessed since Easter... or been to Mass... Will you hear me now?"
Cauchon said: "I will hear you... but not now, not here."
Jeanne said: "Who are you?"
Cauchon said: "Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais. As you were captured in my diocese, the duty of conducting the trial falls upon me."
Jeanne said: "Trial?  What trial??"
Cauchon said: "Your trial, Jeanne.  On a charge of heresy."
Jeanne said: "But... the King -- my king -- didn't he pay my ransom?"
Cauchon said: "It seems that the English care more about you than the French."
Jeanne said: "The English??"
Cauchon said: "Yes.  They paid your ransom... tomorrow you will be transferred to their great castle at Rouen."

Cauchon said: "Take the Holy Gospels in your hand and swear to tell the whole truth concerning everything you will be asked."
Jeanne said: "I don't know what you're going to ask me questions about.  You may ask things that I won't want to answer."

Cauchon said: "You will swear to tell the truth about whatever you are asked."
Jeanne said: "I will willingly swear to tell the truth about earthly things, but as for my revelations, I've never told anyone except my king... Charles the Seventh... the one and only king of France."

Cauchon said: "You must take the oath!  Not even a king, would refuse to take an oath to tell the truth in a matter of faith."
Jeanne said: "I will willingly swear to tell you what I am allowed to tell you, but as to the rest, even if you threaten to cut off my head, I still won't tell you."

Cauchon said: "So... begin by telling us your name -- assuming you're allowed to tell us that much?"
Jeanne said: "My name is Jeanne.  My little cross I had round my neck was taken away from me.  I would like to have it back."

Cauchon said: "Show us a little more cooperation first.  Where were you born?"
Jeanne said: "In a village called Domremy."
Cauchon said: "How old are you?"
Cauchon said: "Nineteen... or thereabouts..."
Cauchon said: "Were you baptized?"
Jeanne said: "Yes.  In the church at Domremy."
Cauchon said: "Recite the Lord's Prayer."
Jeanne said: "Not unless you hear my confession."

Cauchon said: "Jeanne, listen to me very carefully. We are all men of faith, and we shall earnestly strive for the salvation of both your soul and body as though it were our own.  We do so in the name of our Holy Mother Church, who never closes her arms to those who would return to her.  But we cannot help you unless you submit to our learned judgment and authority.  Take heed of this charitable admonition, for if you persist in refusing our help, then we shall have no choice but to abandon you to the secular powers, and I think you know well enough the punishment that would await you.  So now... will you please recite Our Lord's Prayer?"
Jeanne said: "Not unless you hear my confession."

Cauchon said: "Jeanne -- be careful -- you're not helping yourself by refusing to submit to our judgment..."
Jeanne said: "And you be careful, you who claim to be my judges, for you too will be judged one day...!"

Cauchon said: "Jeanne, you are not helping yourself.  If you don't answer our questions properly, your refusal will be taken into account."
Jeanne said: "These questions have nothing to do with your trial."
Cauchon said: "I assure you they do.  So... answer me... when was the last time you heard this voice?"
Jeanne said: "Not long ago..."
Cauchon said: "When exactly?  A day, a week -- when?"
Jeanne said: "Last night."

Cauchon said: "What were you doing when the voice came?"
Jeanne said: "Praying."
Cauchon said: "The voice was in your cell?"
Jeanne said: "Yes."
Cauchon said: "What did it tell you?"
Jeanne said: "Many things..."
Cauchon said: "Did it give you advice?  Good advice?"

Cauchon said: "Tell us, Jeanne... do you often hear this voice?"
Jeanne said: "Yes..."
Cauchon said: "Is it here?  Now?  In this room?"

Cauchon said: "Let me clarify things for you, Jeanne.  On the one hand there is the Church Triumphant, that is to say God, his saints, and the souls that are saved.  And then there is the Church Militant, that is to say our Holy Father the Pope, the cardinals, the prelates of the Church, the clergy, and all good Catholic Christians.  Moreover this Church, when assembled, is guided by the Holy Spirit and therefore cannot be in error.  That is why we ask you to submit to the Church Militant... that is to say, us."
Jeanne said: "So it is the Church Militant that refuses to confess me, and so prevents me from being a good Christian?"

Cauchon said: "It is for us to determine whether you are a good Christian, not you."
Jeanne said: "I am sent by God, and I submit all my words and deeds to His judgment. Or do you think that you are better judges than He is?"

Cauchon said: "Jeanne, I beg of you... sign!  In God's name, don't you understand? I'm trying to save you!  If you don't sign, the English will burn you to death!  Is that what you want??"
Jeanne said: "No... I want to be confessed."

Cauchon said: "Sign this, and I will confess you myself if you want."
Jeanne said: "And may I go to Mass?"
Cauchon said: "As often as you like -- now, please -- for the love of God -- sign!!"

Jeanne said: "Please... may I have it back..."
Cauchon said: "You have nothing to regret..."

Jeanne said: "I didn't mean it!  I didn't know what I was signing!  You tricked me...!"
Cauchon said: "Silence her!  Take her away...!"

Cauchon said: "I don't understand, Jeanne... why did you do it?  Why?"
Jeanne said: "And you?  Why did you lie?  You promised I could be confessed..."
Cauchon said: "I know, Jeanne... it was the only way to save you from the fire!"
Jeanne said: "It's not my body I want to save. It's my soul."

Jeanne said: "I ask only one thing... to hear me in confession..."
Cauchon said: "I -- I can't Jeanne... I can't hear your confession... I'm sorry..."

Cauchon said: "Good day, sir.  I trust my honorable Duke of Burgundy is feeling well?"
Dijon said: "He's feeling wonderful."
Cauchon said: "Thanks be to God."
Dijon said: "And your Duke?  The Duke of Bedford?"
Cauchon said: "Not so well, I regret to say.  This business with the Maiden... it's caused him endless grief and torment.  That's why he's entrusted me with the task of... shall we say..."
Dijon said: "Buying her?"
Cauchon said: "This word is -- regrettably appropriate for the situation.  In fact what we -- the Church -- wish to do is determine whether or not this girl is sent by God, as she claims.  You understand that we cannot allow just anybody to abuse God's name in this manner..."
Dijon said: "I understand.  How much?"

Cauchon said: "20,000?!  But... I heard King Charles was... financially embarrassed."
Dijon said: "Don't look at the cost, look at what it brings.  What is your last offer?"

Yolande said: "Your health and happiness has always been my first concern, Charles... ever since you were a little boy -- and I think I know you better than your own mother..."
Charles said: "You think?"
Yolande said: "Mmmm.  Yes.  I know for example the sickness that plagues your heart.  I know how painful it is for you... to have loved a father... without ever knowing if he really was yours."
Charles said: "W-w-what has that got to do with this Maiden?"
Yolande said: "Who better than a messenger from God to give answers to your questions?"
Charles said: "You really think she's been sent... by God?"
Yolande said: "You're a fine judge of character, Charles.  It'll take you less than five minutes to expose her if she's a fake.  But if she's not -- then she will give you your answers... and place the crown on your head."

Charles said: "You will??"
Yolande said: "For the sake of France, Charles. And for the sake of my grandson."

Charles said: "It's true.  There's only one king... people need to be reminded of that. Nevertheless... Jeanne has done so much for us..."
Yolande said: "I assure you, Charles, the Maiden has no greater admirer than myself. But whatever our personal feelings, we cannot allow her to conduct her own private war.  For the sake of the kingdom, it is imperative that you stop her going to Compiegne..."
Charles said: "I... I can't stop her."

Yolande said: "Don't worry, Charles.  If God is still with her, she will be victorious.  We're not her judges... we're just spectators.  Let her go to Compiegne, as you let her go to Orleans, and let God decide her fate."
Charles said: "But... her army's so small now..."
Yolande said: "Then her faith will have to be bigger."

Jeanne said: "There's no need to be afraid, sire."
Charles said: "I'm... I'm not the king..."
Jeanne said: "I know you're not yet -- but you will be, soon."

Jeanne said: "What was my mission?  To help my country?  But how could I do that? I was only a poor girl who knew nothing about riding or making war... so I decided to wait and not to speak to anyone about it."
Charles said: "You did well..."
Jeanne said: "I didn't wait long.  One day I was going to Mass, like I do every day, when the same strange wind started blowing again..."

Charles said: "... and what... what did he say?"
Jeanne said: "He said that I have to save France from her enemies and give her back to God, and He told me that I -- Jeanne -- will lead you to the altar at Rheims to be crowned King of France."

Jeanne said: "I don't need lodgings if we're to be marching on Orleans..."
Charles said: "Orleans has held out for six months. I don't suppose a few days will make much difference.  Take some rest."

Charles said: "Ah, Jeanne... come here...!  This whole coronation idea of yours is a fiasco... nothing is ready..."
Jeanne said: "... You look wonderful..."
Charles said: "... and my crown doesn't fit and...  Really??"

Jeanne said: "Get them out of here!"
Charles said: "Now hold on -- you're not captain here... on the battlefield perhaps, but not in the royal bedchamber!"
Jeanne said: "Why did you betray me?  Paris was ours for the taking!  All I needed was another few hundred men... Why did you take back the army you gave me?"
Charles said: "Gave you?  Well now, I wouldn't quite put it like that..."
Jeanne said: "So how would you put it?"
Charles said: "Well... we are, of course, enormously grateful for your past efforts, but your task is done.  Now it's time for negotiation... and after many months of skillful work, our dear Tremoille is about to seal a treaty with our Burgundian friends who will no longer lend their support to the English.  You see, my dear Jeanne... as it is written in the Bible, "to everything there is a season:  a time for war, and a time for peace"..."
Jeanne said: "Peace will only be got from the English at the end of a lance!"
Charles said: "Why do you have to be so bloodthirsty?  Do you enjoy it?  All that blood and noise and pain? Diplomacy is far more civilized... far safer... and far cheaper..."

Tremoille said: "She pretends she's been sent by God! These charlatans -- it's a pity there isn't enough wood to burn them all!"
Charles said: "She says she'll be here tomorrow...!"
Tremoille said: "You mustn't see her, my lord.  We know nothing about her... we don't even know if she is from Lorraine."
Charles said: "What difference does it make where she comes from?"
Tremoille said: "If she comes from Burgundy it makes a difference.  It might be a trap...  Look... Signed "X".  What sort of name is "X"?  Or must we conclude that a messenger of God can't even write her own name?"

Tremoille said: "Not exactly.  She wants you to give her an army -- at your expanse.  Bearing in mind that your mother stole every last piece of gold in the treasury, I fail to see how you can afford such an adventure."
Charles said: "I can see her if I want to.  I mean, with half of France in the hands of the English, what have I got to lose?"
Tremoille said: "The other half."

Tremoille said: "Your majesty, I urge you not to see this woman.  It all reeks of a Burgundian trap!"
Charles said: "My astrologers assure me that the hour is p-p-propitious -- Leo, with Virgo rising.  Have you ever noticed on the astrological chart how the Virgin is next to the Lion?"
Tremoille said: "Supposing she's an assassin?"
Charles said: "Tremoille, I'm not even king yet... who'd want to assassinate me?"

Tremoille said: "Your majesty, I really think you..."
Charles said: "My dear loyal Tremoille, I know I can count on you..."
Tremoille said: "... as always, majesty..."
Charles said: "... to ensure our privacy.  I need to talk to her.  Alone."

Charles said: "My captains have sworn their support."
Tremoille said: "No doubt your captains will fight for your fine cause -- but what about the ordinary soldier?  They don't fight for causes these days. They fight for money.  Who's going to pay them?"

Charles said: "He's probably right -- let's call a delay..."
Tremoille said: "There's no time, sire -- we can't hold up the ceremony... there's no telling when the English might come back... they're only ten leagues away..."
Charles said: "Let them come!  Let them see who's the true king of France!"

Charles said: "I... I don't know... it'll sound like we... betrayed her...?"
Tremoille said: "Noooo!"

D'Estivet said: "When you saw your king for the first time, was there an angel over his head?"
Jeanne said: "If there was, I didn't see it..."
D'Estivet said: "Then why did your king believe in you without any proof?"
Jeanne said: "Go and ask him yourself."

D'Estivet said: "You told us about the appearance of this... voice.  What exactly did you see?  Part of it... or all of it?"
Jeanne said: "His face."
D'Estivet said: "Does he have hair?"
Jeanne said: "Yes."
D'Estivet said: "Is it long and hanging down?"
Jeanne said: "I'm more interested in what he says, not what he looks like."
D'Estivet said: "But if the devil were to take on the physical appearance of a saint or an angel... or a man... how would you recognize him?  By what he said?"
Jeanne said: "Go on to the next question."
D'Estivet said: "That's enough!  You will answer the question... or face the consequences!"

Regnault said: "5,000 gold crowns."
Dijon said: "That's not a lot."
Regnault said: "It is all his majesty can afford. He has even donated his very own personal savings.  His majesty will greatly appreciate a gesture of good will in this delicate negotiation between our two families."
Dijon said: "I know... but the English want her very badly, and I have to tell you that they are proving much more generous."
Regnault said: "May I, without offending you, inquire how generous?"
Dijon said: "20,000 gold crowns."

Regnault said: "8,000.  We can't raise more... We can only place ourselves at the mercy of your generosity."
Dijon said: "I must offer to the Duke.  I will give you his answer tomorrow."

Jeanne said: "Were you sent by Lord Dunois?"
Dunois said: "Yes... they were."
Jeanne said: "Good.  Where are the English?"
Dunois said: "Everywhere.  Where is the food?"
Jeanne said: "It's coming -- I rode on ahead.  I have to speak with the Captain of the English army... his name's Talbot..."
Dunois said: "I know..."
Jeanne said: "Good.  Can you bring me to him?"
Dunois said: "He's on the other side of the river."

Dunois said: "Wait, wait..."
Jeanne said: "For what?"
Dunois said: "Because... because -- I mean -- the English have a broad sense of humor, but... I mean, you don't understand... to them you're a witch, working for the devil.  What makes you think they'll listen to you?"
Jeanne said: "Because if they don't, I'll raise such a war-cry against them that they will remember us forever!"
Dunois said: "Well.  I'd love to see that, but after taking counsel with my captains, I felt it would be better to first bring the food into the city, then wait till Alencon arrives with reinforcements before doing anything."
Jeanne said: "You may have been with your counsel, but I've been with mine, and I'm telling you, God's counsel is wiser than yours, and he's telling me to speak to the English -- now!"
Dunois said: "Fine -- go now if you want, but not with me!  You may have a duty to God but I have a duty to my people, and my people are starving!  So right now I'm going to take the food back to the city, and if you can please calm down, and let me accompany you to Orleans, it will be my honor to welcome you."

Dunois said: "So... what is the message?"
Jeanne said: "We offer the English a last chance to return home in peace.  If they refuse, we recross the river and attack them here -- at the Tourelles."

Dunois said: "Jeanne, that really makes no sense at all.  The Tourelles is virtually impregnable... besides, if we're on the other side of the river attacking the Tourelles, what's to stop Talbot attacking the city from the north?"
Jeanne said: "God."

Jeanne said: "You know, I feel a great sorrow for you, because you're laughing now, but by tomorrow night some of you will be dead and having to repeat your jokes in front of God."
Dunois said: "Jeanne, with respect -- we can't just attack the Tourelles like that -- it's a very complicated matter and..."
Jeanne said: "What complicated about it?  All you have to do is do what you're told -- what could be simpler than that? I'm the drum on which God is beating out his message -- beating so loudly it's bursting my ears -- but you're all so full of your own voices, you're deaf to His!"

Jeanne said: ""Be patient, be patient"... is that the only advice you can ever come up with??  I've shown more patience than a dozen saints!"
Dunois said: "Jeanne, you have to understand -- it's not easy for us -- I mean for our pride -- to suddenly be usurped by a -- well, with all due respect, by a... girl."
Jeanne said: "Ah, so that's it.  To you I'm just a girl."
Dunois said: "Jeanne, put yourself in my shoes for a moment -- how would you feel, if you were me?"
Jeanne said: "Knowing what I know?  Enormous gratitude."

Jeanne said: "Dunois... was it you who ordered the attack?  Answer me?!"
Dunois said: "Can we -- uh -- discuss this later?"
Jeanne said: "Sooner is better than later!"

Jeanne said: "Position the long-bows over there, crossbows over there -- and set up Dijon Culverins either side of those trees..."
Dunois said: "The wind will be against us..."
Jeanne said: "The wind will be with us!  Do as I say."

Dunois said: "What's going on?"
Jeanne said: "We're taking back the Tourelles!"

Dunois said: "Jeanne, what are you doing with that... you've got it back to front..."
Jeanne said: "I know what I'm doing, so either lend a hand or go back to bed!"

Jeanne said: "Stand by with the battering-rams..."
Dunois said: "We need another ten minutes..."
Jeanne said: "The bridge won't wait!"

Dunois said: "Well...?  Shall we go?"
Jeanne said: "Not yet."
Dunois said: "The English won't wait."

Xaintrailles said: "My lord Dunois... I have wonderful news! -- finally -- he's sending her to us -- thanks be to God -- we're saved -- it's wonderful!"
Dunois said: "Calm yourself, Xaintrailles.  Now slowly.  Who has finally done what?"
Xaintrailles said: "The Dauphin -- he's sending us food -- and supplies -- and an army -- led by Jeanne -- the maiden from Lorraine -- isn't it wonderful?!"
Dunois said: "Yes, it's a miracle."
Xaintrailles said: "And it's not the first one!  They say she saved a little boy who was dying of..."
Dunois said: "Xaintrailles...!  Don't talk to me about miracles...  If I was still sitting there waiting for a miracle, I'd be dead now. Anyway..."

Xaintrailles said: "But... don't you think we should at least... go and... welcome her?"
Dunois said: "As long as she brings food and supplies, she'll be welcome."

Gilles said: "Brilliant idea... but to be really effective, why not send a whole army of virgins?"
La Hire said: "That'll put fire in my soldiers!"

Gilles said: "God... why of course -- we'd forgotten about him!  Strange, I don't seem to remember seeing him at Agincourt."
La Hire said: "Damn right!"
Gilles said: "Oh, but I forgot!  It was a Sunday... that explains it.  God's day off."

Gilles said: "I do love her when her fire gets well and truly stoked!"
La Hire said: "Me too..."

La Hire said: "There must be something we can do for her for Chrissakes!"
Gilles said: "Yes.  We can pray."
La Hire said: "Good idea..."

Gilles said: "This is no good!"
La Hire said: "No good?  This is a disaster!"

Gilles said: "And... what does Jeanne think?"
Jeanne said: "I don't think.  I leave that to God. I'm nothing in all this, I'm just the messenger."

Jeanne said: "We return to Orleans... across the bridge, at the Tourelles."
Gilles said: "But the bridge has been pulled down!"
Jeanne said: "The English are rebuilding it."

Jeanne said: "Clear?"
Gilles said: "Perfectly."

Gilles said: "You look disappointed... Isn't this what you wanted?"
Jeanne said: "No... not like this..."
Gilles said: "For weeks you've been asking for this... well now you have it!"

Gilles said: "Jeanne... let him do it.  One more dead body's not going to make any difference, so who cares?"
Jeanne said: "I care!  And I care because God cares!  All life is precious to God -- even his -- even yours and mine..."

Gilles said: "Bravo!  What about all the other hundreds of prisoners?  Do we let them go too?"
Jeanne said: "Maybe... I don't know... but first we have to confess..."

Gilles said: "Jeanne... The men are exhausted!"
Jeanne said: "I know, but so is the enemy -- they're falling back -- Paris is ours...!"
Gilles said: "Jeanne... we're not enough..."
Jeanne said: "So... bring up the reinforcements!"
Gilles said: "Reinforcements?  Where??"

Jeanne said: "Right behind us -- Dunois with another then thousand men!"
Gilles said: "Jeanne, look behind you."
Jeanne said: "Never look behind -- only ahead!"

Gilles said: "Do you know how to count?"
Jeanne said: "Of course I do?  Bring them up!"
Gilles said: "Jeanne... that is not ten thousand reinforcements -- that is one hundred very loyal but very tired soldiers."
Jeanne said: "But... where is Dunois... where are the men the king promised me?"
Gilles said: "He never sent them... Don't you understand?  He doesn't want this war anymore... he has his crown now, that's all he ever wanted..."
Jeanne said: "But my voices... they promised me..."
Gilles said: "To hell with your voices -- it's time to face facts!  We have nothing to do here... none of us... not even you.  You should go home, Jeanne."

Jean Le Maistre said: "Who told you to wear men's clothes?"
Jeanne said: "The clothes are not important..."
Jean Le Maistre said: "You also cut your hair short like a man, and in the Bible it clearly states that it is an abomination for a woman to pretend to be a man!  It proves your desire to deceive..."
Jeanne said: "It was just... more convenient as I was among soldiers..."
Jean Le Maistre said: "So you think you did well to cut your hair and dress as a man?"
Jeanne said: "I... submit to Our Lord."
Jean Le Maistre said: "But will you also submit to the decision of the Church?"
Jeanne said: "It seems to me that the Church and Our Lord are one and the same.  Why must you complicate what is so simple?"

Jean Midi said: "Tell us, Jeanne... why did you jump from the tower at Beaurevoir?"
Jeanne said: "I had been sold to the English.  I'd rather die than fall into their hands."
Jean Midi said: "Did your voice tell you to jump?"
Jeanne said: "No..."
Jean Midi said: "So when you jumped, you wanted to kill yourself?"
Jeanne said: "No...!"
Jean Midi said: "How can you deny it when you just said "I'd rather die than fall into the hands of the English"...?"
Jeanne said: "That's now what I meant..."
Jean Midi said: "Do you not know that suicide is a very grievous sin?  No one is allowed to destroy the life that God created!"
Jeanne said: "I know, but that's not the way things happened..."
Jean Midi said: "You mean it was not of your own free will that you were on the ledge?"
Jeanne said: "Yes, but..."
Jean Midi said: "And you didn't jump of your free will?"
Jeanne said: "No!"
Jean Midi said: "Oh?  Perhaps someone pushed you then?"

Jeanne said: "Stop it!  What are you doing?"
Soldier said: "Nothing... just taking his teeth."
Jeanne said: "But you can't just kill a man for his teeth!"
Soldier said: "Why not?  He has good teeth..."
Jeanne said: "Because... because you just can't!"

Soldier said: "Besides, what about these...?"
Jeanne said: "That's different... I mean... we were fighting for a... for a cause!"

Soldier said: "Yeah..."
Jeanne said: "Here -- take this instead."

Jeanne said: "So who gave the order to bring me to this side of the river??"
La Hire said: "Hey, my friend!  I'm glad to see your ugly damn face again!"
Jeanne said: "La Hire, I'm warning you -- don't swear!"
La Hire said: "Sorry Jeanne...  Did you both meet already?"

La Hire said: "Jeanne, let me introduce the king's half brother, the dogged Lord Dunois."
Jeanne said: "Then, Lord Dunois, show me the way to the other side of the river..."

La Hire said: "Jesus Christ... the goddamn English will pay for this!"
Jeanne said: "They will -- and so will you if you go on swearing like that."

Jeanne said: "What happened?  Who gave the order to attack?"
La Hire said: "God knows, but it was a bad idea!"
Jeanne said: "Were the men confessed?  Where are the priests?"

La Hire said: "I swear I'll never swear again in my life if you save her life!  But I'm warning you, if you let her die, then you're the biggest..."
Jeanne said: "Don't swear..."

La Hire said: "Physicians are a waste of time. You'll have more luck with this charm of mine... it saved my life at Agincourt!"
Jeanne said: "I'd sooner die than use magic!"

Jeanne said: "Prepare these as battering-rams!"
La Hire said: "What's the use?  The drawbridge is up!"
Jeanne said: "Not for long..."

Jeanne said: "We... won?!"
La Hire said: "Won?!  Such a small word will never do!  This is victory, Jeanne, this is... glory!"

Jeanne said: "You call this... glory...?  All this... this blood... this smell of..."
La Hire said: "... the smell of victory, Jeanne! Mmmmmmm!  I love it!"
Jeanne said: "It's not possible..."

Jeanne said: "Take mine instead -- here -- smash mine first!"
La Hire said: "Jeanne... get up... this is ridiculous..."
Jeanne said: "If you kill him, you kill me!"

La Hire said: "Jeanne... the man hasn't been paid for six months -- that's his only reward.  Let him take a few teeth..."
Jeanne said: "A few teeth... that's the price of his life?"

La Hire said: "Jeanne, if you don't mind... I'll stay standing... this armor... it's a nightmare to get back up..."
Jeanne said: "I said, kneel!"

Jeanne said: "You don't believe me anymore?"
La Hire said: "We still believe in you, Jeanne.  If it were up to me, I'd chase every goddamn Englishman into the ocean. But it's not up to us anymore -- it's up to the king..."

Maitre Maurice said: "When you were taken prisoner at Compiegne, did you have a horse?"
Jeanne said: "Yes... a half-steed... white."
Maitre Maurice said: "Who gave you that horse?"
Jeanne said: "My king."
Maitre Maurice said: "How many did he give you?"
Jeanne said: "Five steeds and a few hackneys..."
Maitre Maurice said: "As much as for a Lord?  What an honor!  Did your king give you other wealth apart from horses?"
Jeanne said: "No."
Maitre Maurice said: "What about all those dresses you were given... silk dresses weren't they?"
Jeanne said: "Yes, I was given a few, but I never had time to wear them..."
Maitre Maurice said: "Still, pretty wealthy for a peasant girl wouldn't you say?"
Jeanne said: "And you look pretty wealthy for a servant of God, wouldn't you say?"

Man said: "Jeanne... what are you doing?"
Jeanne said: "Playing..."

Man said: "What have you done to me?"
Jeanne said: "I -- I -- I..."

Jeanne said: "Who... who are you...?"
Man said: "I am that I am.  You don't like my face?  Maybe you prefer this one..."

Man said: "Who are you to even think you can know the difference between good and evil?  Are you God?"
Jeanne said: "No... no... I'm just a messenger... He needs me... a higher calling..."

Jeanne said: "I don't know... I thought..."
Man said: "YOU THINK GOD ISN'T BIG ENOUGH TO DELIVER HIS OWN MESSAGES?"
Jeanne said: "I don't know... please... tell me I'm dead..."
Man said: "WHO ARE YOU TO DECIDE IF YOU SHOULD LIVE OR DIE?"
Jeanne said: "I... don't know... what do you want from me?"
Man said: "Nothing.  I'm here to set you free..."

Jeanne said: "What are you doing out here?"
Man said: "I might ask you the same question."
Jeanne said: "I... I'm leaving... I can't take anymore..."
Man said: "And what exactly is it that you can't take anymore of?"
Jeanne said: "Everything!  Prison -- humiliation -- being abandoned and betrayed by everyone -- I can't stand it anymore -- I'd rather die!"
Man said: "You'll be dead soon enough anyway, so why be in such a hurry?  Why not face up to your lies?  It's your lies you can't stand anymore..."
Jeanne said: "I... I never lied!"
Man said: "If you were true to yourself... if your faith was firm, you wouldn't need to run away from yourself like this..."
Jeanne said: "I am true -- to my Lord, the King of Heaven.  He knows how much I love him -- that's all that matters to me..."
Man said: "How can you pretend that you love God when you're about to throw away the most precious thing he gave you? Life is a gift, you should know that by now Jeanne -- a gift from God. You know what He'd say to you, if He was here?  "What are you doing to me, Jeanne?""

Man said: "That's too easy.  One minute you want to die, the next you want to live...  Do you think that life is a toy that can be played with and then broken when you don't want it anymore?"
Jeanne said: "No, no... I'm just so tired, and lost, and... I didn't realize what I was doing!"

Man said: "Oh?  And just because you realize now, everybody else should forgive you?!"
Jeanne said: "I don't know -- I don't care anymore -- I just want to be at peace!"
Man said: "Oh, so you don't want war anymore? You want to be at peace?  You want to be able to change your mind anytime you feel like it and expect everyone to go along with it?"
Jeanne said: "I don't understand.  What do you want from me?"
Man said: "I told you already... I'm here to set you free..."

Man said: "Why were you yelling like that?!"
Jeanne said: "What are you doing here?  Please... leave... you can't stay here..."
Man said: "Why?  Are you waiting for someone else?"
Jeanne said: "Yes!"
Man said: "Who?"

Jeanne said: "My... visions..."
Man said: "They're going to come and visit you in here?"
Jeanne said: "Yes... that's what I pray for...!"
Man said: "I want to see that.  Do you mind if I stay... on the side?  I won't bother you."
Jeanne said: "No, no -- you can't stay or they won't come!"
Man said: "Why not?"
Jeanne said: "Because... I have to be alone!"

Man said: "They won't come anyway."
Jeanne said: "What do you mean, they won't come?"
Man said: "Why would they?"
Jeanne said: "Because!  Because I've always been faithful to God, and I've followed everything he said... and I've done everything he asked me..."
Man said: "God asked you to do something?"
Jeanne said: "Yes... lots of things!"
Man said: "You mean God said, "I need you, Jeanne?""
Jeanne said: "No, but... he sent me so many signs!"
Man said: "What signs?"
Jeanne said: "Like... like the wind... and the clouds... and... the bells... and what about that sword lying in the field... that was a sign...!"
Man said: "No.  That was a sword in a field."
Jeanne said: "But... it didn't just get there by itself."
Man said: "True -- every event has an infinite number of causes -- but why pick one rather than another?  There are many ways a sword might find itself in a field..."

Jeanne said: "I'm not lying, I... I can't remember... leave me alone!"
Man said: "Oh?  You can't remember?  Let me help your memory..."

Jeanne said: "No!  I don't want to know anymore! Leave me alone!  I didn't kill that man!"
Man said: "Oh no?  How about this one?"

Jeanne said: "Stop, stop... I can't remember!  The battles were all so confusing... there was so much smoke, dust, noise... I was being attacked on all sides, so... maybe... perhaps I fought back but it was only to defend myself..."
Man said: "So your memory's coming back?"
Jeanne said: "Yes... yes!  And now you tell me why God let all these battles happen in the first place... if he's so powerful... he said he's "the creator of heaven and earth, the source of all life..." he could have easily stopped all this blood and misery?  Why didn't he?"
Man said: "Is he the one who spread all this blood and misery?"
Jeanne said: "No, but... why didn't he stop it? Or did he get pleasure, watching us killing each other in his name?"
Man said: "In His name??"
Jeanne said: "Yes!  We fought and killed in His name... the King of Heaven!"
Man said: "Really?"

Man said: ""Let all who love me follow me"... Where does God get mentioned?  Come on Jeanne, be honest.  You fought for yourself, in your name."
Jeanne said: "I... I was defending myself as best I could!  Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they?  Or should I have let myself be killed?"
Man said: "No, no, you did fine.  I'd even say well done.  Besides, most of the ones you killed probably deserved it, don't you think?"
Jeanne said: "No, I do not think so.  I don't think that killing each other will ever bring peace."
Man said: "I agree..."

Man said: "I don't agree.  Why do you have to keep changing your mind all the time?"
Jeanne said: "Why are you doing this to me??  Do you get pleasure from hurting me?"
Man said: "Ah, pleasure... that's a difficult word to define.  When does the pain end and the pleasure begin...? When did your pleasure begin with that sword in your hand...?"
Jeanne said: "I never took pleasure in hurting anyone?"
Man said: "Really?"

Jeanne said: "I -- I cleaned up my room, look... and I said my prayers... all of them... and..."
Man said: "What are you doing on the wall?"
Jeanne said: "I'm trying to make my cross look more beautiful..."
Man said: "What for?"
Jeanne said: "Because... because I don't know what else to do to please him."
Man said: "Do you think this cross will protect you?"
Jeanne said: "No, I..."

Jeanne said: ""Love your enemies"..."
Man said: "Good.  But "love your enemies"... body and soul."

Jeanne said: "My voices... my voices... do you think they will ever come back?"
Man said: "I don't think so."
Jeanne said: "Are you going to leave me too?"
Man said: "Yes... of course... when you don't need me anymore."
Jeanne said: "Are you sent by God?"

Jeanne said: "There's nothing for me to do here anymore... I don't belong here I want to be with Him now..."
Man said: "Do you think you are ready?"

Jeanne said: "Yes I am."
Man said: "Are you willing to follow all His commandments?"
Jeanne said: "Yes..."
Man said: "... to love your enemy as much as you love yourself?"

Man said: "You know what you just signed, Jeanne?  You just signed away my existence... For you I'm a lie, an illusion.  You see?  In the end, you were the one who abandoned me..."
Jeanne said: "No..."

Man said: "You think you are ready now?"
Jeanne said: "Yes, my lord."
Man said: "Let's see."

Priest said: "You know I'm always happy to see you, Jeanne, but to keep coming here twice, three times a day..."
Jeanne said: "I need to confess."
Priest said: "But you already confessed this morning..."
Jeanne said: "I need to confess again."
Priest said: "So... alright.  What terrible sin have you committed since then that can't wait till tomorrow to be forgiven?"

Jeanne said: "I saw a poor monk without shoes so I gave him some."
Priest said: "There's no sin in charity, Jeanne."
Jeanne said: "They weren't my shoes.  Mine were too small."
Priest said: "Whose were they?"
Jeanne said: "My father's."
Priest said: "I'm sure he'll forgive you."
Jeanne said: "He already did, but I want God to forgive me too."
Priest said: "Jeanne -- if we were to ask forgiveness all the time, we'd spend our whole life in church."
Jeanne said: "Is that bad?"
Priest said: "Well no, but... Jeanne, are you happy at home?"
Jeanne said: "Oh yes... very."
Priest said: "And your mother -- everything's fine with her?"
Jeanne said: "Oh yes, she's... wonderful."

Priest said: "Good, good.  And your sister... Catherine -- she's still your best friend?"
Jeanne said: "Oh yes, my sister's just... she's... wonderful."

Priest said: "And what about your other friends... you don't like playing with them?"
Jeanne said: "Oh yes, I play with them... lots..."

Priest said: "So... everything sounds... wonderful?"
Jeanne said: "Yes, it is."
Priest said: "Then... why are you here so often?"
Jeanne said: "I feel safe here.  And it's where I can talk to him."
Priest said: "Him?"
Jeanne said: "Well, I try and talk to him, but mostly he's the one who does the talking."
Priest said: "Who is this "he"?"
Jeanne said: "He never says his name."
Priest said: "What... does he... look like?"

Jeanne said: "Beautiful."
Priest said: "And what does he say to you?"

Jeanne said: "He says... he says I must be good... and help everyone... and take care of myself.  Do you think he's coming from the sky?"
Priest said: "Perhaps... but wherever he comes from, I think you should listen to him, because it sounds like he's giving you very good advice."

Priest said: "I heard about your sister, and I... understand your pain..."
Jeanne said: "Why did she have to die?"
Priest said: "Only God knows the answer to that."
Jeanne said: "I know Jesus says to love our enemies but I can't -- I just want the English to burn in hell for ever and ever!"
Priest said: "I realize your anger, Jeanne, but we must learn to forgive.  It's hard, but revenge will never bring about peace."
Jeanne said: "Then what will?  And what will bring her back?  And why did she have to die in the first place instead of me?  Why didn't he take my life instead of hers?  It was my fault -- I was late -- she gave me her hiding place...!!"
Priest said: "Jeanne... calm down...!  Calm down, Jeanne!"

Jeanne said: "I don't want to wait for his call."
Priest said: "Jeanne, be patient."
Jeanne said: "I want to be with him always..."
Priest said: "Soon you'll be able to take the Holy Mass, and as you eat of his flesh and drink of his blood, you will be at one with him."
Jeanne said: "I want to be at one with Him now."

Benek said: "I'm sorry, Mr Wladek, he wants you to stop."
Szpilman said: "Who wants me to stop?"

Benek said: "Why are you here, Mr. Wladek?"
Szpilman said: "It's like this... I...we...all of them."

Benek said: "Someone you know?"
Szpilman said: "Yes."

Benek said: "A beauty. Who is she?"
Szpilman said: "A singer. Her husband's an actor. I knew them well. Good people. I'd like to talk to her."
Benek said: "Don't forget, Mr. Wladek, they hang them for helping Jews."

Dorota said: "This is my husband. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent him."
Michal said: "Oh, yes. I remember."

Dorota said: "I'm going to get a doctor."
Michal said: "You can't, it's too dangerous."
Dorota said: "I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust him."
Michal said: "Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's a pediatrician."
Dorota said: "He's still a doctor."

Szpilman said: "Hello."
Dorota said: "I came specially to meet you today. I love your playing, but what a day to choose."
Szpilman said: "Who are you?"
Dorota said: "My name's Dorota, I'm Jurek's sister. oh! You're bleeding."
Szpilman said: "It's nothing."

Dorota said: "I nagged Jurek for weeks and weeks. And at last he gave in and said, 'All right, come with me tomorrow,' and so I came and they bombed the station."
Szpilman said: "You know something? Meeting you like that was absolutely wonderful."
Dorota said: "Really?"
Szpilman said: "Yes!  It was...it was unforgettable."

Dorota said: "I've always loved your playing, Mr. Szpilman."
Szpilman said: "Wladek, please."
Dorota said: "No one plays Chopin like you."

Dorota said: "Oh, Mr Szpilman, you're quite... quite wonderful."
Szpilman said: "Wladek, please."

Szpilman said: "Dorota!"
Dorota said: "I didn't want to come, I didn't want to see all this, but I couldn't stop myself."
Szpilman said: "How are you doing?"
Dorota said: "Fine, no, not really, they arrested my cousin, but Jurek says they'll let him out.  This is disgraceful."
Szpilman said: "Don't worry, it won't last long."
Dorota said: "That's what I said, it's so - it's too absurd!"
Szpilman said: "I'll see you...soon."

Dorota said: "Wladyslaw Szpilman."
Szpilman said: "Dorota."
Dorota said: "Come in! come in!"

Dorota said: "Sit."
Szpilman said: "I'm sorry - I was given this address. I'm looking for a Mr--  -- a Mr Dzikiewicz."
Dorota said: "Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband."

Szpilman said: "I need help."
Dorota said: "He'll be back before curfew."
Szpilman said: "I've been in hiding. I need somewhere to stay."
Dorota said: "He'll be here soon."

Szpilman said: "How long have you been married?"
Dorota said: "Just over a year."

Szpilman said: "And how's Yurek?"
Dorota said: "Dead."

Szpilman said: "When's your baby due?"
Dorota said: "Christmas.  This is not a good time to have children. But then..."

Father said: "What did I tell you?"
Szpilman said: "What are you doing?"

Father said: "Will I still be able to play?"
Szpilman said: "Let's find out."

Szpilman said: "Let me see this."
Father said: "Doesn't it say we have to provide these armbands ourselves? Where will we get them?"

Father said: "To tell you the truth, I thought it would be worse."
Szpilman said: "How will we sleep?"

Szpilman said: "For what? For my tie?"
Father said: "American Jews, and there's lots of them, what have they done for us? What do they think they're doing? People here are dying, haven't got a bite to eat. The Jewish bankers over there should be persuading America to declare war on Germany!"

Gebczynski said: "It's not going to be very comfortable."
Szpilman said: "I'll be fine."
Gebczynski said: "You'll have to stay here until tomorrow afternoon."

Gebczynski said: "Must feel better this side of the wall."
Szpilman said: "Yes, but sometimes I'm still not sure which side of the wall I'm on."
Gebczynski said: "Here."

Gebczynski said: "Get your things together, you have to leave!"
Szpilman said: "What's happened?"

Gebczynski said: "I'm on the run!"
Szpilman said: "What's happened?"
Gebczynski said: "The Gestapo found our weapons. They've arrested Janina and Andrzej. They're bound to find out about this place, too - you must get away at once."
Szpilman said: "Where do you want me to go?  Look at me. No, no, I'm not leaving. Can't I take my chances here?"
Gebczynski said: "That's your decision.  But when they storm the flat, throw yourself out of die window - don't let them get you alive. I have poison on me, they won't get me alive either!"

Halina said: "Have you seen this?"
Szpilman said: "What, I'm working, what?"

Szpilman said: "What's happened?"
Halina said: "Oh my God, it's terrible, you've got to do something, oh my God!"
Szpilman said: "Calm down, what, what is it?"
Halina said: "They're hunting people on the streets. They've picked up Henryk."

Szpilman said: "Halina?"
Halina said: "What?"
Szpilman said: "Funny time to say this."
Halina said: "What?"
Szpilman said: "wish I knew you better."
Halina said: "Thanks."

Szpilman said: "Henryk's in there."
Heller said: "I haven't seen him."
Szpilman said: "Believe me, they've picked him up."
Heller said: "Tough luck."
Szpilman said: "Can you help?"
Heller said: "Oh, you need me now, yes, now you need me!"
Szpilman said: "Can you help us?"
Heller said: "It costs."
Szpilman said: "I've no money."
Heller said: "Then there's nothing I can do. He should've joined us when I gave him the chance.."
Szpilman said: "Yitzchak, they told me you had influence."
Heller said: "Who told you?"
Szpilman said: "People I know. They said you're an important man."

Heller said: "We're recruiting."
Henryk said: "Who's recruiting?"
Heller said: "Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police..."
Henryk said: "Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!"
Heller said: "Someone's got to do it, Henryk."
Henryk said: "But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean..."
Heller said: "Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?"
Henryk said: "Yes, please."
Heller said: "I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work..."

Henryk said: "And suppose they take the table away?"
Mother said: "What d'you mean, take the table away?"
Henryk said: "The Germans go into Jewish homes and they just take what they want, furniture, valuables, anything."
Mother said: "Do they?"

Henryk said: "What's this about?"
Mother said: "Sit down, have tea, I'll start lunch when the girls get back."

Mother said: "And, please, tonight, for once, I don't want anything bad talked about. Let's enjoy our meal."
Henryk said: "Okay, then I'll tell you something funny. You know who I mean by Dr. Raszeja."

Mother said: "Henryk, I said nothing bad."
Henryk said: "What's the matter with you all? Have you lost your sense of humour?"

Mother said: "Boys, boys..."
Henryk said: "Your work, yes, playing the piano for all the parasites in the ghetto, they don't give a damn about people's sufferings, they don't even notice what's going on around them!"

Szpilman said: "They bombed us, we're off the air."
Henryk said: "Warsaw's not the only radio station."

Henryk said: "Mama, that was a great dinner."
Szpilman said: "It certainly was."

Henryk said: "No, no. Listen, I've been thinking --"
Szpilman said: "That makes a change."
Henryk said: "You know what we do? We use psychology."
Szpilman said: "We use what?"
Henryk said: "We leave the money and the watch on the table. And we cover it like this.  In full view. The Germans will search high and low, I promise you, they'll never notice it."
Szpilman said: "Of course they'll notice it. But look--  This is a good place for something."
Henryk said: "A good place for what?  He's insane!"
Szpilman said: "Just shut up."

Szpilman said: "But...they won't get all of us... we'll...it's too small...there's four hundred thousand of us in Warsaw!"
Henryk said: "No. Three hundred and sixty thousand, so it'll be easy."

Szpilman said: "You sell anything?"
Henryk said: "Just one. Dostoevsky. The Idiot. Three zlotys."
Szpilman said: "That's better than yesterday."
Henryk said: "Three lousy zlotys. And there are people here making millions."
Szpilman said: "I know."
Henryk said: "You don't know, believe me. They bribe the guards. The guards turn a blind eye. They're bringing in cartloads, food, tobacco, liquor, French cosmetics, and the poor are dying all around them and they don't give a damn."

Szpilman said: "It's not funny."
Henryk said: "Well, you know what's funny? You're funny with that ridiculous tie."
Szpilman said: "What are you talking about, my tie? What's my tie got to do with anything? I need the tie for my work."

Henryk said: "You go to Heller, did I ask you to talk to him?"
Szpilman said: "You're out, aren't you?"

Henryk said: "Did you beg, did you grovel to that piece of shit, that cockroach?"
Szpilman said: "I didn't grovel, I asked him to help."
Henryk said: "What did you pay him?"
Szpilman said: "Pay him? With what? With what could I pay him? Every zloty I earn we spend on food!"
Henryk said: "I can look after myself!"
Szpilman said: "They were taking you away."
Henryk said: "It's nothing to do with you. It's me they wanted, not you. Why do you interfere in other people's business?"
Szpilman said: "You're mad, that's your trouble, you're mad."
Henryk said: "That's also my business."

Szpilman said: "What's the matter? Are you sick?"
Henryk said: "Hungry."

Szpilman said: "What's that mean, no employment certificate?"
Henryk said: "You have to have an employment certificate to work for one of the German firms in the ghetto, otherwise..."
Szpilman said: "Otherwise what?"
Henryk said: "You'll be deported."

Szpilman said: "What are you reading?"
Henryk said: "'If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?'"

Szpilman said: "Very appropriate."
Henryk said: "Yes, that's why I brought it."

Janina said: "No one thought they'd hold out so long."
Szpilman said: "should never have come out. I should've stayed there, fought with them."
Janina said: "Wladek, stop that. It's over now. Just be proud it happened. My God, did they put up a fight."
Szpilman said: "Yes, so did the Germans."
Janina said: "They're in shock. They didn't expect it. Nobody expected it. Jews fighting back? Who'd have thought?"
Szpilman said: "Yes, but what good did it do?"
Janina said: "What good? Wladek, I'm surprised at you. They died with  dignity, that's what good it did. And you know something else?  Now the Poles will rise. We're ready. We'll fight, too. You'll see."

Jehuda said: "Ah, here. Today's news from the other side."
Szpilman said: "You're amazing, Jehuda."
Jehuda said: "No, I'm a socialist. I have brothers everywhere. They bring me news and food. We care about our fellow human beings. Workers of the world unite."
Szpilman said: "So, what's the news?"
Jehuda said: "The Germans are advancing on Kharkhov."
Szpilman said: "I don't know why I come here every evening, it's always such bad news."
Jehuda said: "Bad news, you crazy? You have no world view, Wladek, that's your trouble. The news couldn't be better. The moment Hitler invaded Russia, I knew we'd be all right. Remember Napoleon. Same business. The Germans will freeze to death, please God."

Szpilman said: "Jehuda, give me something to do."
Jehuda said: "You're an artist, Wladek, you keep people's spirits up. You do enough."
Szpilman said: "But I want to help, I want to."
Jehuda said: "You're too well known, Wladek. And you know what? You musicians don't make good conspirators. You're too...too musical."

Szpilman said: "There are notices going up. The city's to be cleansed of undesirables."
Jehuda said: "There are always notices going up."

Jehuda said: "Five hundred. You know how many people on average read one copy? Twenty.  That makes ten thousand readers. These will start the uprising. Majorek hides them in his underpants. And leaves them in toilets."
Szpilman said: "Toilets?"

Jehuda said: "I thought you'd be off on tour, playing London, Paris, New York?"
Szpilman said: "Not this week."

Jehuda said: "I have to say you look terrible. What's the trouble?"
Szpilman said: "You've heard the rumours they're going to resettle us in the East?"
Jehuda said: "Rumours, rumours, you take it all too much to heart, Wladek."
Szpilman said: "I've been trying to get a certificate of employment for my father. I've managed to get certificates for me and the rest of the family but I need one more for my father. I've been trying all the firms, the shops..."
Jehuda said: "Why didn't you come to me?"
Szpilman said: "I didn't know you were in the certificate business."
Jehuda said: "I'm not, but Majorek is."
Szpilman said: "Can you help? I've no money..."
Jehuda said: "Please, don't insult us.  Can you do something for him?"

Szpilman said: "Jurek? Wladek Szpilman."
Jurek said: "Wladek! How are you?"
Szpilman said: "Fine, we're fine, thank you, and you?"
Jurek said: "Fine, we're fine in the circumstances. But I can guess what you've called about. There's nothing we can do; they won't reopen the station--"
Szpilman said: "Yes, I know, but Jurek, Jurek..."
Jurek said: "...not even music, nothing, no radios for the Poles. But I'm sure you'll find work, Wladek, a pianist like you."
Szpilman said: "Maybe, maybe not, but, Jurek, don't be offended, I didn't call to discuss my future career."

Kitten'S Voice said: "Puppydog, what d'you mean, you forgot?"
Puppydog'S Voice said: "What d'you think I mean, Kitten? I forgot, that's what I mean."
Kitten'S Voice said: "You know what? You treat me like dirt!"
Puppydog'S Voice said: "I treat you like dirt because you are dirt."
Kitten'S Voice said: "Pig!"
Puppydog'S Voice said: "Cow!"
Kitten'S Voice said: "Pig!"
Puppydog'S Voice said: "Bitch!"
Kitten'S Voice said: "Dirty pig!"
Puppydog'S Voice said: "You're a dirty pig!"
Kitten'S Voice said: "Takes one to know one! Pig!"

Kitten'S Voice said: "If I play like an angel, why don't you listen?"
Puppydog'S Voice said: "I was listening, Kitten."
Kitten'S Voice said: "Liar, you fell asleep. Pig!"

Szpilman said: "How long have you been here?"
Majorek said: "Since last night. I was pleased to see you."

Majorek said: "They're going to start the final resettlement now. We know what it means. We sent someone out. Zygmunt. A good man. His orders were to follow the trains out of Warsaw. He got to Sokolow. A local railwayman told him the tracks are divided, one branch leading to Treblinka. He said every day freight trains carrying people from Warsaw forked to Treblinka and returned empty. No transports of food are ever seen on that line. And civilians are forbidden to approach the Treblinka station. They're exterminating us. Won't take them long. We're sixty thousand left. Out of half a million. Mostly young people. And this time we're going to fight. We're in good shape. We're organised. We're prepared."
Szpilman said: "If you need help..."

Szpilman said: "Have a favour to ask. I want to get out of here."
Majorek said: "It's easy to get out, it's how you survive on the other side that's hard."
Szpilman said: "I know. But last summer, I worked for a day in Zelazna Brama Square. I saw someone I knew. A singer. Her husband's an actor. They're old friends.  I've written their names down. And their address. If they're still there. Janina Godlewska and Andrzej Bogucki. Good people. Majorek, you go into the town every day. Would you try and make contact? Ask them if they'd help me get out of here?"

Majorek said: "I tried your friends. They're not at that address any more.  But."
Szpilman said: "You made contact?"
Majorek said: "Be ready to leave in two days' time. Same place as last night."

Mother said: "Thank God - Wladek! You're wounded."
Szpilman said: "It's a little cut, nothing."
Mother said: "I've been worried sick."

Mother said: "Pack, darling, get your things, pack."
