Niles said: "All we need is the bookie setup for now.  We'll worry about the telegraph office later."
Garfield said: "All right, I'll rent ya everything I got in the warehouse for two grand.  That'll give ya phones, cages, blackboards and ticker gear. You supply the guys to move 'em. If you want a counter and bar, that's another grand.  I don't know where the hell I'm gonna get 'em though."
Niles said: "C'mon, you can do better than that. We ain't no heel grifters."
Garfield said: "You want the stuff tomorrow or don't ya?  It's gonna take hours just to clean it up.  Besides, Gondorff's still a hot item.  Where am I gonna be if he gets hit?"
Niles said: "Just give us what ya can, Benny. We'll send a truck down."

Garfield said: "We bought ya a tap into Moe Anenberg's wire.  He's got eyes at every track in the country.  You'll get race results, odds, scratches, pole positions, everything; and just as fast as Western Union gets 'em."
Niles said: "Does J.J. know how to use this thing?"
Garfield said: "All he's gotta do is read."

Gondorff said: "Turn the goddamn thing off, will ya."
Hooker said: "You sober?"
Gondorff said: "I can talk, can't I?"

Gondorff said: "Glad to meet ya, kid.  You're a real horse's ass."
Hooker said: "Yeh, Luther said you could teach me something.  I already know how to drink."

Gondorff said: "I'm sorry about Luther.  He was the best street worker I ever saw."
Hooker said: "He had you down as a big-timer. What happened?"
Gondorff said: "Aw, I conned a Senator from Florida on a stocks deal.  A real lop-ear. He thought he was gonna take over General Electric.  Some Chantoozie woke him up, though, and he put the feds on me."
Hooker said: "You mean you blew it."
Gondorff said: "Luther didn't tell me you had a big mouth."
Hooker said: "He didn't tell me you was a fuck- up, either.  You played the Big Con since then."
Gondorff said: "No, I lammed it around for a while while things cooled off.  Philly, Denver, Baltimore, nuthin' towns."

Gondorff said: "You gonna stay for breakfast, or do you already know how to eat?"
Hooker said: "I picked something up on the way."
Gondorff said: "Lonnegan after you, too?"
Hooker said: "I don't know.  Haven't seen anybody."
Gondorff said: "You never do, kid."

Hooker said: "Gondorff, you gonna teach me the Big Con or not?"
Gondorff said: "You didn't act much like you wanted to learn it."
Hooker said: "I wanna play for Lonnegan."
Gondorff said: "You know anything about him?"
Hooker said: "Yeh, he croaked Luther.  What else do I gotta know."

Hooker said: "Aw right, he runs the numbers outta the south side."
Gondorff said: "And a packing company, a chain of Savings and Loans and half the politicians in Chicago and New York. There ain't a fix in the world gonna cool him out if he blows on ya."
Hooker said: "I'll take him anyway."
Gondorff said: "Why?"
Hooker said: "'Cause I don't know enough about killin' to kill him."

Gondorff said: "You can't do it alone, ya know.  It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make 'em look good."
Hooker said: "We'll get by without 'em."
Gondorff said: "This isn't like playin' winos on the street.  You gotta do more than outrun the guy."
Hooker said: "I never played for winos."
Gondorff said: "You gotta keep Lonnegan's con, even after you spent his money.  And no matter how much you take from his, he'll get more."
Hooker said: "You're sacred of 'em, aren't ya?"
Gondorff said: "Right down to my socks, turkey.  If I'da been half as scared a that lop-ear, I wouldn't a fallen asleep on 'em.  Lonnegan might kill me, but at least he won't bore me to death."
Hooker said: "Then you'll do it?"
Gondorff said: "If I can find a mob that'll risk it. But no matter what happens, I don't want you comin' back to me halfway through and sayin' it's not enough... cause it's all you got."

Hooker said: "He's not as tough as he'd like to think."
Gondorff said: "Neither are we."

Hooker said: "He's waitin' for you in the card room."
Gondorff said: "Let him wait."

Gondorff said: "You just worry about your end, kid."
Hooker said: "If we ever get to it."

Hooker said: "How'd ya do?"
Gondorff said: "Well we got some workin' money anyway."

Gondorff said: "Everything go all right?"
Hooker said: "Yeh, it was easy."

Gondorff said: "No signs of trouble?"
Hooker said: "What do ya mean?"
Gondorff said: "You know, somebody tailin' ya.  A torpedo or somethin'."
Hooker said: "No, not a thing."

Gondorff said: "How 'bout Lonnegan?"
Hooker said: "I gave him the breakdown just like ya told me to."
Gondorff said: "And?"
Hooker said: "He threatened to kill me."
Gondorff said: "Hell, they don't do that and you know you're not gettin' through to 'em."

Hooker said: "Then he drove me home.  He tried to put himself away as legit, so I went right into the pitch."
Gondorff said: "Did he hold you up on anything?"

Hooker said: "You think he'll show?"
Gondorff said: "Did he say he wouldn't?"
Hooker said: "No."
Gondorff said: "He'll show."

Gondorff said: "Why didn't you tell me about Snyder before?"
Hooker said: "I thought I'd lost him."

Gondorff said: "Well you found him again and we're gonna have to do somethin' about it. What else haven't ya been tellin' me?"
Hooker said: "Nothin'.  I told ya everything there is."
Gondorff said: "Then why'd ya move outa your room?"
Hooker said: "It was too noisy."
Gondorff said: "You can't play your friends like marks, Hooker."

Gondorff said: "You know how easy it'd be for one of Lonnegan's guys to nail you?"
Hooker said: "All we need is a couple days, Henry. A couple days and we'll get Lonnegan down and stomp on 'em."
Gondorff said: "You just won't learn, will ya. Hell, you come in here, I teach you stuff maybe five guys in this world know, stuff most grifters couldn't do even if they knew it, and all you wanna do is run down a bullet.  You're just like all them new jerks. Lotsa nerve and no brains.  And ten years from now when me and the others are through and you dumb guys are all dead there won't be one gee left who knows the Big Con was anything more than a way to make a livin'."
Hooker said: "A couple days; that's all I'm askin'.  I can stay clear that long."
Gondorff said: "Christ, they'll probably miss you and hit me."

Gondorff said: "What's the matter, kid?  You're not sayin' much."
Hooker said: "Just a little nervous, that's all."
Gondorff said: "Luther always told me to bite my toenails when I get nervous.  You see yourself doin' that and you realize it ain't worth it."

Gondorff said: "Take it easy, you won't lose him now.  We had him 10 years ago when he decided to be somebody.  Believe me, I've seen enough to know."
Hooker said: "How many guys you conned in your life, Henry?"
Gondorff said: "Two or three hundred I guess. Sometimes played two a day when I was in Shea's mob.  We had it down to a business.  'Course Chicago was a right town then.  The fix was in.  The dicks took their end without a beef.  All the Wall Street boys wanted to make investments for us.  Even had marks looking us up, thinkin' they could beat the game.  Yeh, kid, it really stunk.  No sense in bein' a grifter if it's the same as bein' a citizen."

Gondorff said: "I better do some packin'.  I'm gonna be a hot number again after tomorrow."
Hooker said: "Then why you doin' it?"
Gondorff said: "Seems worthwhile, doesn't it? Maybe it's just for the cave-in on Lonnegan's face when we put in the sting."

Hooker said: "Henry."
Hooker said: "Yeh."
Hooker said: "I appreciate your stickin' your neck out.  I wouldn't have asked ya if it weren't for Luther."
Gondorff said: "Ain't nothin' gonna make up for Luther, kid.  Revenge is for suckers.  I been griftin' 30 years and never got any."

Gondorff said: "You beat him, kid."
Hooker said: "You were right, Henry.  It's not enough... But it's close."
Gondorff said: "You wanta wait for your share?"
Hooker said: "Naw, I'd just blow it."

Niles said: "He's been taking the 8:10 Century Limited outa New York on Friday and getting in here early Saturday morning.  He usually stays a day to check on his policy operations, and then flies back."
Gondorff said: "Wonder why he doesn't fly both ways."
Niles said: "The porters say he runs a braced card game in one of the cars.  $100 minimum, straight poker.  Last time he pulled in here ten grand heavier than he left New York."
Gondorff said: "Fancies himself a gambler, huh?"

Gondorff said: "We'll use the wire.  Never known a gambler who wouldn't like to beat the ponies."
Niles said: "The wire is ten years outa date."
Gondorff said: "That's why he won't know it."

Niles said: "All you gotta do is show up with some money and look like a fool."
Gondorff said: "I also gotta win."

Gondorff said: "He's gonna hit ya with 20 grand, Eddie.  How much cash we got?"
Niles said: "Not enough to cover a bet that big."
Gondorff said: "Get a couple extra guys in the line, then.  We'll give him the shut-out."

Niles said: "Looks like he's sulking."
Gondorff said: "If we're lucky, this'll bring him back stronger than ever."

Gondorff said: "What's the problem?"
Niles said: "He wants to put a half million on Syphon."

Singleton said: "Lonnegan's a fast egg, Henry.  He's not gonna sit still for a standard play."
Gondorff said: "Everybody'll sit still for somethin'. What did ya find out about the train, Eddie?"

Singleton said: "I'm not sure I know it."
Gondorff said: "We'll give him the hook on the train, and play him here.  You think I can get in that poker game, Eddie?"

Singleton said: "You in?"
Gondorff said: "Yeh, I think so.  I gave the kay- ducer a C-note.  You find out the deck?"
Singleton said: "He usually plays with a Royal or a Cadenza.  I got you one of each.  He likes to cold deck low, 8's or 9's."
Gondorff said: "Nice work, J.J."

Singleton said: "Look at that.  He's got four apes with him."
Gondorff said: "That's what I like about these guys, J.J... They always got protection against things we'd never do to 'em."

Gondorff said: "How ya doin'?"
Singleton said: "Nothin' yet.  I got a good one on the lead at Hialeah, but he's fadin'."

Gondorff said: "Yeh, that'd be real nice of ya, Mr. Lonneman."
Lonnegan said: "Lonnegan."

Lonnegan said: "Raise 500."
Gondorff said: "See ya and raise three."
Lonnegan said: "See and raise five."
Gondorff said: "Five and call."

Gondorff said: "Raise 300."
Lonnegan said: "Pass."

Gondorff said: "Raise 1,000."
Lonnegan said: "Raise 500."

Lonnegan said: "See and raise 1,000."
Gondorff said: "Raise 5,000."

Lonnegan said: "I guess I left it in my room."
Gondorff said: "What!  Don't give me that crap you little weenie.  How do I know you ain't gonna take a powder.  You come to a game like this, you bring your money."

Gondorff said: "Never get enough, huh pal?  I'd think you'd get tired of losin', Honnigan."
Lonnegan said: "The name is Lonnegan."
Gondorff said: "Make sure you see cash from this guy, Eddie.  He's got the name for bettin' money he don't have."

Gondorff said: "I can't lay that off in time.  We lose a bet that big, it could break us."
Lonnegan said: "If ya win it could make ya, too."
Gondorff said: "What are the odds on Syphon?"

Gondorff said: "A half mill on an eight to one shot. You're dumber than I thought, Lonnegan."
Lonnegan said: "You're more gutless than I thought."

Hooker said: "She coulda killed me last night."
Gunman said: "Too many people coulda seen ya go in her room.  She was a professional. Used to work in the Dutch Schultz gang."
Hooker said: "Who are you?"
Gunman said: "Gondorff asked me to look after ya."
Hooker said: "How do I know you're tellin' the truth."
Gunman said: "Don't have much choice, do ya?"

Hooker said: "Hi there, Snyder.  Things a little slow down at the Bunco Department tonight, eh?  Somebody lose the dominoes?"
Snyder said: "You scored blood money today, Hooker.  You need a friend."
Hooker said: "Aw, find yourself a shoplifter to roll."

Snyder said: "I'll tell ya what you did, smart boy.  You tied into a loaded mark on 47th across from Maxies.  You and Coleman played the switch for him and blew him off to a cab on 49th.  If he hadn't been a numbers runner for Doyle Lonnegan, it woulda been perfect."
Hooker said: "You're crazy.  I'm not stupid enough to play for rackets money."
Snyder said: "Not intentionally maybe, but that don't make no difference to Lonnegan. He'll swat you like any fly."
Hooker said: "I'll square it with the fixer."
Snyder said: "Nobody can buy you a prayer, if I put the finger on ya."

Hooker said: "My end was only one."
Snyder said: "Then you'll have to come up with another grand somewhere."

Hooker said: "Excuse me, sir.  Treasury Dept... I'd like to ask you a few questions."
Man said: "What for?  I haven't done anything."
Hooker said: "We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station.  Have you made any purchases here today?"
Man said: "Yes, a ticket to Chicago."

Hooker said: "Then I'm afraid we'll have to impound your money until we're sure that it's all good.  Can I see your wallet and your ticket, please?"
Man said: "But I got a train to make."
Hooker said: "It'll only take 20 minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down the hall."
Man said: "But what about all these other people?"
Hooker said: "We'll get 'em!  Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here, ya know.  We go around advertising ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh?  You think I'm wearin' this rag here 'cause I like it?  Christ, everybody thinks life's a holiday or somethin' when you got a badge.  I been here since three this morning, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people.  You try to help 'em and they spit on you.  I shoulda let ya go and gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes."

Man said: "I'm sorry, really I am, but my train leaves in ten minutes."
Hooker said: "All right, I'll give ya a break.  Down that hall there, there's an unmarked door on the left.  Go on in there and wait at the window. I'll take this...  ...in the back and run it through right away.  We'll have you outta there in a couple minutes."
Man said: "Thank you.  You don't know how much I appreciate this."
Hooker said: "Think nothin' of it."

Loretta said: "You done?"
Hooker said: "Yeh, I guess I shoulda had the meat loaf."
Loretta said: "It isn't any better."
Hooker said: "Where's June today?"
Loretta said: "She don't work here no more.  I'm fillin' in for a couple days... till I can get a train outa here."
Hooker said: "Where you goin'?"
Loretta said: "I don't know.  Depends what train I get on."

Hooker said: "Meat loaf, apple pie and a cup of coffee."
Loretta said: "Sixty-five."

Hooker said: "What time you get off work here?"
Loretta said: "2:00 A.M."
Hooker said: "You doin' anything tonight?"
Loretta said: "Yeh, sleepin'."

Hooker said: "You got a back door to this place?"
Loretta said: "No.  What's wrong with the front?"
Hooker said: "Look, I don't have time to fuck around.  There's somebody out there I don't need to see.  You got a fire escape or anything?"
Loretta said: "No."
Hooker said: "All right, do me a favor.  Go into the bathroom, open the window and wait for me there."
Loretta said: "What the hell for?"
Hooker said: "Just do what I tell ya and everything'll be jake."

Loretta said: "What does this guy want?"
Hooker said: "He'd like to kill me."

Loretta said: "Looks like he missed ya."
Hooker said: "Yeh, this time anyway."

Hooker said: "I, ah...thought you might wanna come out for a while.  Maybe have a drink or somethin'."
Loretta said: "You move right along, don't ya."
Hooker said: "I don't mean nothin' by it.  I just don't know many regular girls, that's all."
Loretta said: "And you expect me to come over, just like that."
Hooker said: "If I expected somethin', I wouldn't be still standin' out here in the hall."

Loretta said: "I don't even know you."
Hooker said: "You know me.  I'm just like you... It's two in the morning and I don't know nobody."

Hooker said: "You sure it'll be one of these two?"
Twist said: "No.  They're just the only ones we know of."

Hooker said: "Twist?  I told him the tale.  He wants to see ya."
Twist said: "All right, when?"
Hooker said: "Tomorrow, after 4:00.  Stay inside, I'll come in and get ya.  And be hard on him for a while; he's talking money."
Twist said: "Okay, Tootsie."

Hooker said: "Les, I got Mr. Lonnegan with me. He wants to see you a second."
Twist said: "What the hell's the matter with you. We coulda met at a club or somethin'."
Hooker said: "I thought it might be good for him to see the setup."
Twist said: "Well we can't talk in here.  They're having the place painted."

Jimmy said: "Hooker!"
Hooker said: "How ya doin', Jimmy."

Jimmy said: "Ain't seen you in months, boy. Thought maybe you took a fall."
Hooker said: "Naw, just a little hard times, that's all.  It's all over now."
Jimmy said: "You gonna have a go here?  How 'bout a ten spot on the line here.  The 4-9 been lookin' good today.  Lotsa action on 28th Street down there, too.  Pay ya 10-1."

Jimmy said: "You sure you wanna start off that big?  Bet like that could put a real dent in us."
Hooker said: "I feel lucky tonight."
Jimmy said: "Aw, come on, Hooker, why don't you just..."
Hooker said: "Three grand on the black, Jimmy."

Lonnegan said: "Your boss is quite a card player, Carver.  How does he do it?"
Hooker said: "He cheats."

Lonnegan said: "He'll have to take a check.  I couldn't find my wallet."
Hooker said: "Yeh, he knows that."
Lonnegan said: "What do you mean?"
Hooker said: "He hired a dame to take it from ya."

Hooker said: "You were set up, Lonnegan.  Shaw's been planning to beat your game for months.  He was just waiting for you to cheat him so he could clip ya."
Lonnegan said: "I could have you put under this train for this, errand boy."
Hooker said: "So could Shaw."
Lonnegan said: "Then why the rat?"
Hooker said: "Cause I'm tired of bein' his nigger.  I want you to help me break him."

Lonnegan said: "What's the matter?  You gotta get back to Shaw?"
Hooker said: "Naw, he picked up some jane in the bar.  Can't see him till morning anyway."
Lonnegan said: "All right, then."

Lonnegan said: "Why me?  Shaw probably has lotsa enemies to choose from."
Hooker said: "I need somebody respectable...but not completely legit.  What I'm gonna do isn't very legal."
Lonnegan said: "I'm a banker, friend.  That's legit in this state."
Hooker said: "All you gotta do is place a bet for me at Shaw's place.  I'll supply all the money and the information."

Hooker said: "If you help me out, I'll pay ya back the money you owe Shaw, myself."
Lonnegan said: "That's worth fifteen grand to ya?"
Hooker said: "Maybe a couple million."

Lonnegan said: "You're dreamin', kid."
Hooker said: "660 Marshall Street.  Tomorrow at 12:30, if you're interested."
Lonnegan said: "If I'm not there by quarter of, I'm not coming."

Lonnegan said: "You should always look to the back too, kid."
Hooker said: "I was afraid you weren't gonna come. We haven't got much time."
Lonnegan said: "Get on with it then."
Hooker said: "Sometime after 1:00 a guy's gonna call here and give you the name of a horse.  All you do is take this two grand across the street to Shaw's place and bet it on that pony.  There's nothin' to it, but don't take too much time.  We only have 3 or 4 minutes after you get the call."
Lonnegan said: "You're not gonna break him with a $2,000 bet."
Hooker said: "This is just a test.  The big one comes later.  Be careful with that though, it's all I got."
Lonnegan said: "And you were gonna pay me back?"
Hooker said: "I am after this race."

Lonnegan said: "You really picked a winner, kid."
Hooker said: "Give 'em a little time."

Hooker said: "Well, what did I tell ya?"
Lonnegan said: "You're a lucky man, all right."
Hooker said: "Lucky, hell.  I could do it every day."
Lonnegan said: "Why don't ya then."
Hooker said: "'Cause it's better to do it all at once.  We're puttin' down 400 grand next week.  At 5-1 we make 2 million. Twenty per cent of that is yours if ya stick with us."
Lonnegan said: "You got a system, Carver?"

Hooker said: "You stayin' in or not?"
Lonnegan said: "I'm in."
Hooker said: "It's foolproof.  We got a partner downtown runs the central office of the Western Union.  Race results from all over the country come in there and go right across his desk on their way to the bookies.  All he does in hold them up a couple minutes until he can call us and get a bet down on the winner.  Then he releases the results to the bookies and we clean up on a race that's already been run.  It can't miss, unless the Western Union Dicks get onto it."

Lonnegan said: "You got the 400 grand yet?"
Hooker said: "Not yet, but...  Hey, there's only a grand here."
Lonnegan said: "I think we oughta place another bet tomorrow."
Hooker said: "What is this?  That's my money. You tryin' to muscle me?"
Lonnegan said: "If your system's as foolproof as you say, you'll get even more."

Hooker said: "I gotta talk to me partner first. We can't afford to expose our game too much."
Lonnegan said: "Let me talk to him."
Hooker said: "No."
Lonnegan said: "You want your money back?  Try and get it in a court of law.  C'mon, don't be a sorehead.  I'll make it worth your while.  Migth even help ya finance the big play if this one works out."

Lonnegan said: "What happened to your face?"
Hooker said: "Had a little fight with a raggle down on 13th.  She got me with her ring."

Lonnegan said: "A week's a long time, friend. Anything can happen.  All of it bad."
Hooker said: "He's right, Les."

Hooker said: "What happened?"
Lonnegan said: "I didn't get the bet down in time."
Hooker said: "Oh, Jesus."

Lonnegan said: "Tell your friend I'll have the money here by post-time tomorrow. We'll take the first race where the odds are 4-1 or better.  And make sure I can get to that window this time."
Hooker said: "How am I gonna do that?"
Lonnegan said: "I don't know, figure something out."

Polk said: "You want a drink or something?"
Hooker said: "No."
Polk said: "We want to talk to ya about Henry Gondorff."
Hooker said: "Don't think I know him."
Polk said: "Well give yourself a couple seconds, crumb.  You wouldn't wanna lie to me.  Lt. Snyder here says you done a lotta griftin' in this town."
Hooker said: "Lt. Snyder doesn't know shit."

Hooker said: "You got nothin' on me."
Polk said: "We'll get it, and if we can't, we'll just make it up.  Grand larceny, extortion.  Counterfeiting, anything you want."

Polk said: "Look, I got nothin' against you, but you're in trouble here.  All you gotta do is tell us when Gondorff's gonna play his chump. We come in at the sting, make the pinch, and you walk out free as a bird.  No questions, no court appearance, nothing."
Hooker said: "No."

Polk said: "You've already done time twice, and judges don't like three time losers. You wanna sit in the can for forty years, startin' tonight?"
Hooker said: "I'll make parole."
Polk said: "Like hell.  You won't even get a review till you're seventy.  And if the board starts to go soft, we'll let ya out in the yard some night with a hard-nose young bull who'll put fifty slugs in your face and ask what you were doin' there later."

Hooker said: "Will you wait until the chump is played?"
Polk said: "Hell yes.  We don't care about the mark.  He deserves what he gets."
Hooker said: "I mean completely played.  Until he's beat and the score is taken. You come in before we beat him and I'll kill him.  You'll have a tough time explaining that, won't ya."
Polk said: "All right, Hooker, but you take it on the lam, and we'll shoot you down on sight."
Hooker said: "Just as long as I get to finish the play."

Twist said: "Can't do it.  There're telegraph inspectors all over the place.  I got 750 grand coming in from the coast, and I'm not gonna blow it for a lousy 14 gees.  We'll get somebody else to do our betting."
Lonnegan said: "I could come up with 750 grand in a day if I had a reason to."
Twist said: "But who says you will.  I got a guy I can depend on.  He's liquidating everything he has for this.  You wouldn't even give Carver his money back."
Lonnegan said: "I need more proof, that's all. Anybody can get lucky once."
Twist said: "On a 6-1 shot?  The hell with ya. We'll keep the deal we got."
Lonnegan said: "If it works again tomorrow, I'll have a half million in cash here by noon the next day.  We split 60-40."
Twist said: "We were getting 50 from our guy."
Lonnegan said: "With 20% coming off the top for me laying your bet.  Either way you end up with 40."

Twist said: "Yeh, and what if we play tomorrow and he doesn't come up with the money.  We risk our whole operation for nothing.  I'll say when we make our bets."
Lonnegan said: "Not if you want me to keep makin' 'em for ya."

Lonnegan said: "Take it easy.  Everything's all right.  I put it on Syphon, on the nose."
Twist said: "On the nose!  I said place.  Place it on Syphon.  That horse is going to run second."

Lonnegan said: "All right, Riley.  What the hell happened?"
Riley said: "We missed him."
Lonnegan said: "You weren't hired to miss him."
Riley said: "There wasn't any way he coulda known we was in there.  We made a clean pick on the lock and didn't leave no footprints in the hall. Somebody musta wised him up."
Lonnegan said: "Yeh, and what does Cole say about that?"
Riley said: "I don't know.  He took it hard."
Lonnegan said: "All right, get outa here.  You're outta work."

Mimi said: "and there she was lying dead.  The police said she'd probably been killed about ten minutes before I got there."
Jorgensen said: "I thought you said you weren't going there."
Mimi said: "Why, you said..."
Jorgensen said: "Never mind."

Julia said: "We're just having a little drink."
Wynant said: "So I see."

Wynant said: "Who's that man?"
Julia said: "He's not anybody.  Just a fellow I used to know."
Wynant said: "I thought you'd given up that sort of friend."
Julia said: "This is the first time I've seen him in years.  I didn't want him to think I was high-hatting him."
Wynant said: "I don't like him."
Julia said: "Don't worry.  You won't see him again.  What happened? Did you change your mind about going?"
Wynant said: "No.  I just came back for a second. I wanted to get those bonds."
Julia said: "What bonds?"
Wynant said: "The government bonds.  The ones you took from the office safe."
Julia said: "Oh yes.  Why, you told me to sell them a long time ago."
Wynant said: "I'd never tell you to sell those. I bought them for my daughter."
Julia said: "Don't you remember...."
Wynant said: "Now see here, Julia.  You're counting a little too much on my being absent-minded.  You've been taking a little here and there for some time, and I haven't said anything about it.  But this is fifty thousand dollars!"
Julia said: "Do you realize that you're accusing me of ...."
Wynant said: "No one else had the combination of that safe.  You took them.  What did you do with them?"
Julia said: "What if I did take them? I'm sick and tired of seeing you hand out thousands of dollars to that family of yours...."
Wynant said: "That's my business."
Julia said: "supporting that gang of loafers! There's not one of them that cares a damn for you.  A wife who threw you out the first time your foot slipped.  They wouldn't raise a hand to help you.  And I've given my whole life for you.  If you kicked off tomorrow, where'd I be? Out in the gutter!  Sure I took those bonds.  Who has a better right -- ?"

Wynant said: "I want that money right now, or I'll hand you over to the police."
Julia said: "Go ahead!"
Wynant said: "They'll be pretty rough with you....with your record."

Julia said: "That's a fine thing to throw up to me after all I've been to you...."
Wynant said: "Hello ....  give me ....  Well ....  ?"
Julia said: "I'll give it back to you ....  all I've got ....twenty-five thousand..."
Wynant said: "You're going to return every cent of it!"
Julia said: "I can't! I haven't got it!"
Wynant said: "What did you do with the rest?"
Julia said: "I never had it."
Wynant said: "Then someone was in with you.  Who was it? -- Who was it?  I'll answer that --  Hello ...  hello ..."

Nora said: "Is there a Mr. Macaulay in the house?  Oh, it's you."
Macaulay said: "Yes?"

Nora said: "Oh, hello.  Come on in."
Macaulay said: "Good morning. I'm afraid this isn't a very "Merry Christmas" for you."
Nora said: "Oh, he's sitting up."
Macaulay said: "Good."

Nora said: "Asta - don't bother Mr. Macaulay."
Macaulay said: "That's all right."

Macaulay said: "I got word from Wynant this morning..."
Nora said: "So did we.  I mean, Sherlock here."

Nora said: "Oh, please, Nick."
Macaulay said: "Would it help any if I could persuade him to meet you?"

Wynant said: "Did you get my money?"
Macaulay said: "I do wish you'd tell me where you're going."
Wynant said: "I'm not telling anyone."
Macaulay said: "But suppose some business comes up..."
Wynant said: "That's just why I'm going."

Macaulay said: "One hundred...  two hundred... three..."
Wynant said: "Never mind."
Macaulay said: "I wish you'd count them.  There's a thousand dollars there."
Wynant said: "I trust you."
Macaulay said: "Isn't there anything else I can do for you? Have you bought your ticket?"
Wynant said: "No."
Macaulay said: "Well, let me do that for you."
Wynant said: "You might do that.  Get me a ticket for...  No, you don't!"

Wynant said: "Thanks, and goodbye."
Macaulay said: "What'll I do if something comes up?"
Wynant said: "Settle it yourself.  What have I got a lawyer for?"
Macaulay said: "Is Julia going with you?"
Wynant said: "No."

Macaulay said: "But what if you need more money?"
Wynant said: "I left instructions with Julia. She'll get it from you.  Goodbye."

Macaulay said: "How are you?"
Nick said: "Hello, Macaulay.  Come in."
Macaulay said: "Dorothy told me you were here.  I was going to telephone but...."
Nick said: "That's all right.  What are you drinking?"

Macaulay said: "Nothing, thank you.  Nothing.  I wanted to see you...  What's Mimi up to, Charles?"
Nick said: "Mimi?  ...  Oh, Dorothy's mother.  Does she have to be up to something?"
Macaulay said: "She usually is.  Trying one way or another to get money out of Wynant. I wanted to find out if you were er - er -  --sleuthing for her."
Nick said: "I haven't been a detective for four years."
Macaulay said: "You don't say --"
Nick said: "My wife's father died and left her a lumber mill and a narrow guage railroad and a couple of other things.  And I'm looking after them."
Macaulay said: "I see.  I see."
Nick said: "What's all the fuss about? Is he in hiding?"
Macaulay said: "You know as much about it as I do. I haven't seen him in three months."
Nick said: "No word at all?"
Macaulay said: "He sends word through Julia Wolf when he wants money...  I give it to her and she gives it to him."

Nick said: "My wife."
Macaulay said: "How do you do?  What did you say?....  He is?.... Where is he?  Very well.  He's back in town....  Wynant.  Thank heaven.  He's waiting for me now.  Forgive me, Mrs. Charles...  but I've been so upset.  It's no joke working for a man like that.  I must be off.  Goodbye....  Goodbye,"
Nick said: "S'long."

Nick said: "How are you?"
Macaulay said: "I hate to bother you when you're laid up."
Nick said: "That's all right."

Macaulay said: "What are the chances of getting you to do what he wants?"
Nick said: "Slim."

Nick said: "It might."
Macaulay said: "He gave me a code message to insert in the Times, in case I wanted to get in touch with him."
Nick said: "It wouldn't hurt to put it in."

Macaulay said: "I've done that already. He should appear, you know.  It doesn't look well... his staying away at a time like this."
Nick said: "Hello.... oh, just a minute.  Police department?"
Macaulay said: "Hello....  Where?  In Allentown.  Yes... When is the next train? Right - I'll get that.  Wynant's tried to commit suicide. They want me to come down and identify him.  I guess this changes the whole story, doesn't it?  That looks like an admission of guilt.  And I had such hopes.  I thought if you got on the case, you'd be able to clear him.  I thought that Mimi.... the way she acted... I was sure that....  Oh, well, well... it's no use thinking of it now.  I'm sorry to have wasted so much of your time."

Macaulay said: "But it must have been Wynant.  I should have known if it weren't his voice."
Nick said: "Oh he as clever about that.  He called when you were out.  That same afternoon, Julia telephoned to him. She said that you were coming, Mimi, to ask about Wynant. He got terrified. He was afraid that Julia would break down and tell... so he went to Julia and killed her and left Wynant's watch chain in her hand."

Macaulay said: "I have no right to answer that."
Nick said: "What about it, Tanner.  Isn't that the truth?"

Mimi said: "Oh, Nick... Nick!"
Nick said: "Hello, Mimi."
Mimi said: "want to talk to you about something very important."

Mimi said: "Clyde Wynant's crazy... absolutely crazy to stay away at a time like this. No wonder the police think he has something to do with it."
Nick said: "What do you think?"
Mimi said: "Oh, I know he didn't, but I wish I could find him...  I have something very important to tell him. Macaulay won't help at all.  He thinks I just want money."
Nick said: "Well, don't you?"
Mimi said: "You're always teasing."

Mimi said: "Nick, you will help me find Clyde -- won't you?"
Nick said: "Now, Mimi, there are a thousand detectives in New York.  Hire one of them."
Mimi said: "But he knows you.  All you have to do is get in touch with him, and tell him that Mimi says everything is all right... but that I've got to see him."
Nick said: "I tell you again, I don't want any part of it.  Now you take Dorothy home and..."
Mimi said: "Dorothy!  Is she here?"
Nick said: "Yes..."

Mimi said: "Where's Gilbert?"
Nick said: "Gilbert!  Is he here too?  We might as well be living in the lobby."

Mimi said: "Chris may be at the club -- or somewhere -- I don't see that it's important --"
Nick said: "You should have told them he'd disappeared."

Mimi said: "But he has nothing to do with it!"
Nick said: "That's not for you to decide. Everybody's under suspicion - especially running off like this --  The police will want his description.  Is this a picture of him?"

Mimi said: "I tell you -- he didn't do it."
Nick said: "They'll want more than your word for that."
Mimi said: "All right, then -- I'll tell them who did do it!"

Mimi said: "This is all very pleasant but why are here?"
Nick said: "I've got some very important news - I've seen Wynant."

Nick said: "You did... where?"
Mimi said: "Last night.  He came to see me at my apartment."
Nick said: "Oh, did he?  What did he say?"
Mimi said: "He didn't say very much.  Wanted to know how I was and how the children were."

Mimi said: "Because I don't believe that Clyde's dead!  Why, you said yourself you saw him last night."
Nick said: "So I did.  I saw him lying buried in his shop."

Mimi said: "Perfectly absurd."
Nick said: "And the murderer is right here in this room tonight... he's sitting at this table.  You may serve the fish."

Mimi said: "Nobody told me.  I did see him!"
Nick said: "What did he pay you, Mimi, to stick to that story?"
Mimi said: "It isn't a story - it's true.  I did see Wynant.  He's not dead."
Nick said: "You're lying, Mimi.  But then, you'd do anything for money.  You're getting a good price for saying you saw Wynant and you figure you won't get anything if he's dead."
Mimi said: "I'm lot going to stay here to be insulted -"
Nick said: "Macaulay, you drew up Wynant's will.  Mimi was cut off, wasn't she, if she re-married?"

Morelli said: "I gotta talk to you.  I want you to tell me something and I want you to give it to me straight. Get me?"
Nick said: "Do you mind putting that gun away? My wife doesn't care, but I'm in a delicate condition."

Nick said: "I've never heard about you."
Morelli said: "I didn't knock Julia off."
Nick said: "All right - you didn't."
Morelli said: "I haven't seen her in three months. We were all washed up."
Nick said: "Why tell me?"
Morelli said: "I wouldn't have any reason to hurt her.  She was always on the up and up with me.  But that dirty little Nunheim -- he got sore cause I clicked with her and he didn't, so he put the finger on me."
Nick said: "That's all swell.  Only you're peddling your fish in the wrong market. I've got nothing to do with it."
Morelli said: "Listen.  "Studsy" Burke told me you used to be O.K. That's why I'm here. Do  they...."
Nick said: "How is Studsy?  I didn't know he was out of stir."
Morelli said: "He's all right. He'd like to see you. But listen...  What's the law doing to me?  Do they think I did it, or is it just something else to pin on me?"
Nick said: "I'd tell you if I knew. But I'm not in this.  Ask the police."
Morelli said: "That'd be very smart.  That'd be the smartest thing I ever did. Me that a police captain's been in a hospital three weeks on account we had an argument.  The boys would like to have me come in and ask questions.  They'd like it right down to the end of their blackjacks. Now I come to you on the level. Studsy says you're on the level. Be on the level."
Nick said: "I am on the level. If I knew anything I'd...."

Morelli said: "What's that?"
Nick said: "This is your party."

Nick said: "Morelli -  You knew Julia.  Was she gypping Wynant?"
Morelli said: "She don't say she is, but I figure she is -"
Nick said: "Why do you say that?"
Morelli said: "Once I wanted five grand --  Cash -"
Nick said: "Thank you.  Now I'll tell you why I know Wynant didn't commit those murders -  Three months ago - the night that he caught you in Julia's apartment, he found out that Julia was cheating him, and was splitting with some man.  He went to find the man. That man was.... Tanner, don't you...?"

Morelli said: "What am I?  The fall guy?"
Nick said: "I hope you won't let this news spoil your dinner.  Nice food, isn't it?"

Nora said: "So it's you he was after!"
Nick said: "Hello, baby."
Nora said: "He's dragged me into every gin mill on the block."
Nick said: "I had him out this morning."
Nora said: "I thought so.  He even tried to drag me into the gentlemen's --"
Nick said: "Oh, this is Andy --"

Nora said: "You might have mentioned me first."
Nick said: "He's well-trained.  He'll behave himself."
Nora said: "As long as there isn't a fire hydrant.  What I've gone through --"

Nora said: "Pretty girl."
Nick said: "If you like 'em like that."
Nora said: "You got types?"
Nick said: "Only you, darling...  lanky brunettes with wicked jaws."
Nora said: "Who is she?"
Nick said: "I was hoping I wouldn't have to tell you.  Dorothy is really my daughter.  You see, it was Spring in Venice, and I was so young.  I didn't know what I was doing.  We were all like that on my father's side."
Nora said: "By the way, how is your father's side?"
Nick said: "Much better, thanks."
Nora said: "How many drinks have you had?"
Nick said: "Six Martinis."
Nora said: "Six Martinis.  You're not going to have anything on me."

Nora said: "What hit me?"
Nick said: "That last Martini."

Nora said: "I can't lie here.  I've got to get up and trim that darned Christmas tree."
Nick said: "Take it easy."

Nora said: "Who's that?"
Nick said: "Santa Claus."

Nick said: "Come on -- relax --  Give them a drink."
Nora said: "We need ice."

Nora said: "I'd better order some food.  That sounds like an interesting case.  Wouldn't you like to take it?"
Nick said: "I haven't the time.  I'm much too busy seeing that you don't lose any of the money I married you for."
Nora said: "Room service, please -"

Nora said: "Sounds like a good case.  Girl mysteriously murdered.  No one knows who did it.  They haven't found any clues yet -- no gun -- no fingerprints --"
Nick said: "I wonder if they've --  I don't want to hear anything about it."

Nora said: "Isn't that my drink?"
Nick said: "What are you drinking?"
Nora said: "Rye."

Nora said: "Where did you get that?"
Nick said: "She brought it in.  Trying to make me believe she did it."
Nora said: "What are you going to do with it?"
Nick said: "Nothing, 'til I find out if it's the gun Julia Wolf was killed with.  Keep her in here, and don't let those reporters see her. They might believe her."

Nick said: "She didn't tell me a thing."
Nora said: "Too bad you didn't bring your whip."

Nora said: "Nick!  Nick!  Are you asleep?"
Nick said: "Yes."
Nora said: "Good. I want to talk to you."
Nick said: "That's jolly."
Nora said: "Don't you think you'd like to go back to detecting once in a while, just for the fun of it?"
Nick said: "Can't you get to sleep?"
Nora said: "No."
Nick said: "Maybe a drink would help you."
Nora said: "No thanks."
Nick said: "Maybe it would if I took it."

Nora said: "Everybody says you were a grand detective."
Nick said: "They were kidding you."
Nora said: "I'd like to see you work."
Nick said: "Tomorrow I'll buy you a whole lot of detective stories."

Nora said: "That poor girl is in a tough spot."
Nick said: "There's nothing I can do to help her."

Nora said: "She thinks you can. It wouldn't hurt you to find out if you could, would it?"
Nick said: "Darling, my guess is that Wynant killed Julia and Dorothy knows it. And the police'll catch him without my help."
Nora said: "I think I would like that drink.  I'll give you your Christmas present now if you'll give me mine."
Nick said: "At breakfast."

Nora said: "But it's Christmas now."
Nick said: "Breakfast."
Nora said: "What are you going to give me?  I hope I don't like it."
Nick said: "You'll have to keep them anyway. The man at the Aquarium said that he wouldn't take them back."

Nora said: "Nick!  Nick!  There's someone to she you,"
Nick said: "That's great.  I was afraid I'd have to go to sleep."

Nora said: "You idiot!  Asta! Stop that!  Get down!  Now, stay there."
Nick said: "All right... shoot!  I mean... what's on your mind?"

Nick said: "It's all right.  It just grazed me."
Nora said: "Someone get a doctor."
Nick said: "There's one coming."
Nora said: "Well, quick -- get into bed.  Are you all right?"
Nick said: "Sure -- I don't even feel it."
Nora said: "I'll get some towels."

Nick said: "I'll be all right. Don't let's fuss till the doctor comes."
Nora said: "Want a drink?"
Nick said: "Yeah."

Nora said: "I wish that doctor'd come.  How do you feel?"
Nick said: "He'll be here.  Give him time to get his trousers on.  Where's Asta?  Asta!  Asta!"

Nick said: "You're a fine watch dog."
Nora said: "He's got more sense than you have. Thank Heaven you're not on this case."
Nick said: "On it!  I'm in it ... They think I did it!"
Nora said: "Well, didn't you?"

Nick said: "I never saw that before."
Nora said: "No.  It's a Christmas present."
Nick said: "Who gave it to you?"
Nora said: "You did."
Nick said: "You must admit I have good taste."

Nora said: "Finished with these?"
Nick said: "Yes.  I know all they know about the murder. And I'm a great hero. The Tribune said I was shot twice."

Nora said: "I read you were shot five times in the tabloids."
Nick said: "That's not true.  He never came near my tabloids.  That's one thing I always protect... my tabloids."

Nick said: "Hello... send him up."
Nora said: "Who's that?"
Nick said: "Macaulay."

Nick said: "Aren't you hot in that?"
Nora said: "I'm stifling, but it's so pretty.  The Kirbys."
Nick said: "Is that another Christmas present?"
Nora said: "Yes."
Nick said: "Did I give it to you?"
Nora said: "Yes."

Nora said: "Nick, listen.  From Clyde Wynant!  "Will you take charge of investigation on Julia Wolf murder. Communicate with Herbert Macaulay"."
Nick said: "Let's see.  Where's it from?"
Nora said: "Philadelphia.  Then he didn't do it, did he, Nick?"
Nick said: "I don't know."
Nora said: "He wouldn't ask you to handle it if he were guilty."
Nick said: "Your guess is as good as mine."
Nora said: "Oh take it!  Please take it!"

Nick said: "Oh, it's a fire hydrant."
Nora said: "Yes.  It's Asta's Christmas present."

Nora said: "Well, that's that.  Stay there, Nick!"
Nick said: "It's not going to hurt me to get up."
Nora said: "Sit down!"
Nick said: "You talk as if I were Asta."
Nora said: "All right, hard guy.  Get up and bleed on the rugs."

Nora said: "What's the trouble, Asta?  Your balloon busted?  So's mine."
Nick said: "What's the matter with you?"
Nora said: "The mystery's all gone. And I wanted you to find out who did it."
Nick said: "Maybe I will."
Nora said: "But Wynant --- ?"
Nick said: "I don't believe he did it."
Nora said: "Why don't you?"
Nick said: "No reason.  Just a hunch.  But I'm going to find out.  I'm tired of being pushed around."
Nora said: "So am I."
Nick said: "Come on, Watson, we're going places."

Nick said: "This may be a little rough - you'd better let us go alone."
Nora said: "Catch me letting you go alone!"

Nora said: "I wish they'd stop that.  It makes me fidgety. Do you think they'll find him, Nick?  He must be in New York....  Where do you think you're going?"
Nick said: "I'm going to take Asta for a walk."
Nora said: "He's just been for a walk."
Nick said: "We're going sightseeing -- aren't we, Asta?"

Nora said: "What's that?  What are you up to?  Nickie - what is this?"
Nick said: "Looks like a hold-up!"
Nora said: "What are you going to do?"
Nick said: "I've got hunch.  I'm going down to look at Wynant's shop, I want to find out why it's closed."
Nora said: "Why shouldn't be close it? He went away."
Nick said: "He went away lots of times when I knew him - but he never closed his shop. I've got a hunch something is up."
Nora said: "You mean, he might be hiding there?"
Nick said: "I don't know...  This thing has got my goat. I've got to find out."
Nora said: "Nick - I won't have you going down there."
Nick said: "Say you're the one who got me in this!"
Nora said: "I know but this is different. He's a crazy man. He might kill you."
Nick said: "I'll be all right.  I've got Asta to protect me."
Nora said: "Go on - go on - see if I care. But it's a dirty trick bringing me all the way to New York just to make me a widow."
Nick said: "You wouldn't be a widow long."
Nora said: "You bet I wouldn't."
Nick said: "Not with all your money!"
Nora said: "You dog!"
Nick said: "Goodbye, darling."
Nora said: "Nickie, take care of yourself won't you?"
Nick said: "Sure I will."
Nora said: "Don't say it that way. Say it as if you meant it."
Nick said: "Why, I believe the little woman cares."
Nora said: "I don't care - I'm just used to you, that's all --  If you let anything happen to him, you'll never wag that tail again!"

Nora said: "Back to California"
Nick said: "My soul, woman.  I give you three murders and you aren't satisfied."
Nora said: "I want you to stay and find Wynant."
Nick said: "I did find him!"
Nora said: "What do you mean?"
Nick said: "He was down in the shop."
Nora said: "Nick!"
Nick said: "It was his body that was buried there."
Nora said: "Nick, you'd better lay off that liquor."
Nick said: "That's a fact."
Nora said: "Wynant's body?"
Nick said: "Yup.  Don't you want something to eat?"
Nora said: "But they all said it was Rosebreen's."
Nick said: "That's what they think... Guild and all of them.  They take it for granted that it's just another of Wynant's victims.  Guild's hot-footing it around now, looking for Wynant. That's all that troubles him."
Nora said: "What makes you so sure it's Wynant's body?"
Nick said: "Several things.  Hello, Fred.  We're hungry again. Yeah, and lots of onions.  Oh, and coffee."
Nora said: "Nick, you'll drive me crazy.  What things?"
Nick said: "Huh?"
Nora said: "What things made you so sure?"
Nick said: "Oh.  Well, the clothes for instance. They were carefully preserved, and the body was just as carefully destroyed.  The person who killed him counted on one thing... that all skeletons look alike."
Nora said: "Well, don't they?"
Nick said: "Sure."

Nora said: "You don't get another swallow 'til you really open up."
Nick said: "I remembered that Wynant had some shrapnel in his shin.  It often bothered him.  So I looked for it and I found it.  Gimme."

Nora said: "How long has he been dead?"
Nick said: "Couple of months anyway."
Nora said: "Then he couldn't have committed those other murders."
Nick said: "Smart gal."
Nora said: "Wynant dead?  Does Dorothy know?"
Nick said: "No.  Nobody but you."

Nora said: "I'm going to tell her."
Nick said: "Hey... hey.  Don't do that."
Nora said: "But the poor kid's going crazy. She'd rather know her father was dead than that..."
Nick said: "I can't help it. I can't tell a soul.  I didn't even tell Guild."
Nora said: "Why not?"
Nick said: "I want to lie low till I get the whole dope.  I don't want to go off half-cocked."
Nora said: "What are you going to do?"
Nick said: "I'm going to get the real murderer. I've got an idea.  Want to see me take him?"
Nora said: "Yes!"
Nick said: "Got a nice evening dress?"
Nora said: "Now Nick, what's that got to do with it?"
Nick said: "Got a nice evening dress?"
Nora said: "I've got a lulu -- why?"
Nick said: "I'm going to give a party, and invite all of the suspects."
Nora said: "The suspects!  They won't come."
Nick said: "Oh, they'll come.  I'll have Guild issue the invitations."
Nora said: "Who do you think did it?"
Nick said: "Mimi..."
Nora said: "Mimi!"
Nick said: "Mimi, Jorgensen, Morelli, Tanner....."

Nora said: "You give such charming parties, Mr. Charles."
Nick said: "Thank you, Mrs. Charles."

Nora said: "I can't wait any longer.  Tell me, do you think one of them did it?"
Nick said: "Yes."
Nora said: "I wish you'd tell me who."
Nick said: "I wish you'd tell me."

Nora said: "Serve the nuts - I mean, serve the guests the nuts."
Nick said: "I'm afraid you're lying, Mimi. You see, I really did see Wynant last night."

Nora said: "You're going to drive me crazy!"
Nick said: "Let's see... where was I?  Oh, yes.  He went to find the man. That man was desperate!  He knew that he was caught dead to rights -- and with prison staring him in the face, he took the only way out. He killed Wynant.  It's terrible to tell you this way but your father's dead, Dorothy."

Nora said: "If that knife is missing, I'll look for it in your back."
Nick said: "After our hero had killed Wynant, he got a brilliant idea.  He realized that he and Julia could still collect money.  Wynant was supposed to be on a trip - no one knew where - so our dinner guest wrote letters to Macaulay, signing Wynant's name, so that Macaulay would continue to send the money to Julia.  He even telephoned Macaulay --  Do you remember?.... the first day that you came to see me... he telephoned that he was in town?"

Nora said: "Is that true?"
Nick said: "I don't know."
Nora said: "Why are you saying it?"
Nick said: "It's the only way it makes sense."
Nora said: "I hope you're well."

Brock said: "That's the shape my hand's gonna be when I hold that thing. You understand? I'm not leaving here without it."
Lizzy said: "Look, Brock, she's going to do this her way, in her own time. Don't forget, she contacted you. She's out here for her own reasons, God knows what they are."

Buell said: "The partners want to know how it's going?"
Lovett said: "How it's going? It's going like a first date in prison, whattaya think?!"

Buell said: "There's a satellite call for you."
Lovett said: "Bobby, we're launching. See these submersibles here, going in the water? Take a message."
Buell said: "No, trust me, you want to take this call."

Lovett said: "This is Brock Lovett. What can I do for you, Mrs...?"
Buell said: "Rose Calvert."
Lovett said: "...Mrs. Calvert?"

Buell said: "I told you you wanted to take this call."
Lovett said: "Alright. You have my attention, Rose. Can you tell me who the woman in the picture is?"

Lovejoy said: "None of the stewards have seen her."
Cal said: "This is ridiculous, Lovejoy. Find her."

Lovejoy said: "She's not on the starboard side either."
Cal said: "We're running out of time. And this strutting martinet...  ...isn't letting any men in at all."
Lovejoy said: "The one on the other side is letting men in."
Cal said: "Then that's our play. But we're still going to need some insurance.  Come on."

Cal said: "I make my own luck."
Lovejoy said: "So do I."

Cal said: "We're too late."
Lovejoy said: "There are still some boats forward. Stay with this one... Murdoch. He seems to be quite... practical."

Lovejoy said: "What could possible be funny?"
Cal said: "I put the diamond in my coat pocket. And I put my coat... on her."

Cal said: "Your daughter is much too hard to impress, Ruth.  Mind your step."
Ruth said: "So this is the ship they say is unsinkable."
Cal said: "It is unsinkable. God himself couldn't sink this ship."

Cal said: "Steerage swine. Apparently missed his annual bath."
Ruth said: "Honestly, Cal, if you weren't forever booking everything at the last instant, we could have gone through the terminal instead of running along the dock like some squalid immigrant family."
Cal said: "All part of my charm, Ruth. At any rate, it was my darling fiancee's beauty rituals which made us late."

Ruth said: "You know I don't like that, Rose."
Cal said: "She knows."

Cal said: "It's just the God damned English doing everything by the book."
Ruth said: "There's no need for language, Mr. Hockley.  Go back and turn the heater on in my room, so it won't be too cold when we get back."

Rose said: "You told me to change."
Cal said: "I couldn't let you wear black on sailing day, sweetpea. It's bad luck."
Rose said: "I felt like black."

Cal said: "Those mud puddles were certainly a waste of money."
Rose said: "You're wrong. They're fascinating. Like in a dream... there's truth without logic. What's his name again...?  Picasso."
Cal said: "He'll never amount to a thing, trust me. At least they were cheap."

Cal said: "What made you think you could put your hands on my fiancee?! Look at me, you filth! What did you think you were doing?!"
Rose said: "Cal, stop! It was an accident."
Cal said: "An accident?!"
Rose said: "It was... stupid really. I was leaning over and I slipped."

Rose said: "I was leaning way over, to see the... ah... propellers. And I slipped and I would have gone overboard... and Mr. Dawson here saved me and he almost went over himself."
Cal said: "You wanted to see the propellers?"

Rose said: "Is that the going rate for saving the woman you love?"
Cal said: "Rose is displeased. Mmm... what to do?"

Rose said: "My God... Cal. Is it a --"
Cal said: "Diamond. Yes it is. 56 carats."

Cal said: "It was once worn by Louis the Sixteenth. They call it Le Coeur de la Mer, the --"
Rose said: "The Heart of the Ocean. Cal, it's... it's overwhelming."

Cal said: "I had hoped you would come to me last night."
Rose said: "I was tired."
Cal said: "Yes. Your exertions below decks were no doubt exausting."
Rose said: "I see you had that undertaker of a manservant follow me."
Cal said: "You will never behave like that again! Do you understand?"
Rose said: "I'm not some foreman in your mills than you can command! I am your fiancee --"

Rose said: "Something serious has happened."
Cal said: "That's right. Two things dear to me have disappeared this evening. Now that one is back...  ...I have a pretty good idea where to find the other.  Search him."

Rose said: "But I was with him the whole time."
Cal said: "Maybe he did it while you were putting your clothes back on."

Rose said: "Oh, Mother shut up!  Don't you understand? The water is freezing and there aren't enough boats... not enough by half. Half the people on this ship are going to die."
Cal said: "Not the better half."

Cal said: "Where are you going? To him? Is that it? To be a whore to that gutter rat?"
Rose said: "I'd rather be his whore than your wife."

Rose said: "Yes, I lived. How awkward for you."
Cal said: "Rose... your mother and I have been looking for you --"

Rose said: "Is this in any way unclear?"
Cal said: "What do I tell your mother?"
Rose said: "Tell her that her daughter died with the Titanic."

Cal said: "You're precious to me, Rose."
Rose said: "Jewels are precious. Goodbye, Mr. Hockley."

Cal said: "I know.  Perhaps you could join us for dinner tomorrow, to regale our group with your heroic tale?"
Jack said: "Sure. Count me in."
Cal said: "Good. Settled then."

Cal said: "This should be amusing."
Jack said: "Can I bum a cigarette?"

Cal said: "Just a soupcon of lemon...  ...it improves the flavor with champagne."
Jack said: "No caviar for me, thanks.  Never did like it much."

Jack said: "No thanks. I'm heading back."
Cal said: "Probably best. It'll be all business and politics, that sort of thing. Wouldn't interest you. Good of you to come."

Cal said: "There are boats on the other side that are allowing men in. Jack and I can get off safely. Both of us."
Jack said: "I'll be alright. Hurry up so we can get going... we got our own boat to catch."
Cal said: "Get in... hurry up, it's almost full."

Cal said: "You're a good liar."
Jack said: "Almost as good as you."
Cal said: "I always win, Jack. One way or another.  Pity I didn't keep that drawing. It's going to be worth a lot more by morning."

Jack said: "Let's see... Fabrizio's got niente. Olaf, you've got squat. Sven, uh oh... two pair... mmm.  Sorry Fabrizio."
Fabrizio said: "What sorry? What you got? You lose my money?? Ma va fa'n culo testa di cazzo --"
Jack said: "Sorry, you're not gonna see your mama again for a long time..."

Jack said: "'Cause you're goin' to America!! Full house boys!"
Fabrizio said: "Porca Madonna!! YEEAAAAA!!!"

Jack said: "Goin' home... to the land o' the free and the home of the real hot- dogs! On the TITANIC!! We're ridin' in high style now! We're practically goddamned royalty, ragazzo mio!!"
Fabrizio said: "You see? Is my destinio!! Like I told you. I go to l'America!! To be a millionaire!!  Capito?? I go to America!!"

Fabrizio said: "You know somebody?"
Jack said: "Of course not. That's not the point.  Goodbye! Goodbye!! I'll miss you!"

Jack said: "How you two doin'?"
Fabrizio said: "I don't know what she's say, she don't know what I say, so we get along fine."

Fabrizio said: "The boats are all going."
Jack said: "We gotta get up there or we're gonna be gargling saltwater. Where's Tommy?"

Fleet said: "You can smell ice, you know, when it's near."
Lee said: "Bollocks."
Fleet said: "Well I can."

Fleet said: "Cor... look at that, would ya."
Lee said: "They're a bloody sight warmer than we are."
Fleet said: "Well if that's what it takes for us two to get warm, I'd rather not, if it's all the same."

Fleet said: "Oy, mate... that was a close shave."
Lee said: "Smell ice, can you? Bleedin' Christ!"

Hitchins said: "Keep pulling... away from the ship. Pull."
Molly said: "Ain't you boys ever rowed before? Here, gimme those oars. I'll show ya how it's done."

Hitchins said: "The suction will pull us right down if we don't keep going."
Molly said: "We got room for lots more. I say we go back."
Hitchins said: "No! It's our lives now, not theirs. And I'm in charge of this boat! Now row!!"

Hitchins said: "They'll pull us right down I tell ya!"
Molly said: "Aw knock it off, yer scarin' me. Come on girls, grab your oars. Let's go.  Well come on!"

Molly said: "I don't understand a one of you. What's the matter with you? It's your men back there! We got plenty a' room for more."
Hitchins said: "If you don't shut that hole in yer face, there'll be one less in this boat!"

Ismay said: "So you've not lit the last four boilers then?"
Smith said: "No, but we're making excellent time."
Ismay said: "Captain, the press knows the size of Titanic, let them marvel at her speed too. We must give them something new to print. And the maiden voyage of Titanic must make headlines!"
Smith said: "I prefer not to push the engines until they've been properly run in."
Ismay said: "Of course I leave it to your good offices to decide what's best, but what a glorious end to your last crossing if we get into New York Tuesday night and surprise them all.  Retire with a bang, eh, E.J.?"

Ismay said: "Why have we stopped?"
Smith said: "We've struck ice."
Ismay said: "Well, do you think the ship is seriously damaged?"
Smith said: "Excuse me."

Jack said: "Take my hand. I'll pull you back in."
Rose said: "No! Stay where you are. I mean it. I'll let go."
Jack said: "No you won't."
Rose said: "What do you mean no I won't? Don't presume to tell me what I will and will not do. You don't know me."
Jack said: "You would have done it already. Now come on, take my hand."

Rose said: "You're distracting me. Go away."
Jack said: "I can't. I'm involved now. If you let go I have to jump in after you."
Rose said: "Don't be absurd. You'll be killed."

Rose said: "The fall alone would kill you."
Jack said: "It would hurt. I'm not saying it wouldn't. To be honest I'm a lot more concerned about the water being so cold."

Rose said: "How cold?"
Jack said: "Freezing. Maybe a couple degrees over."

Jack said: "Ever been to Wisconsin?"
Rose said: "No."
Jack said: "Well they have some of the coldest winters around, and I grew up there, near Chippewa Falls. Once when I was a kid me and my father were ice- fishing out on Lake Wissota... ice- fishing's where you chop a hole in the --"
Rose said: "I know what ice fishing is!"
Jack said: "Sorry. Just... you look like kind of an indoor girl. Anyway, I went through some thin ice and I'm tellin' ya, water that cold... like that right down there... it hits you like a thousand knives all over your body. You can't breath, you can't think... least not about anything but the pain.  Which is why I'm not looking forward to jumping in after you. But like I said, I don't see a choice. I guess I'm kinda hoping you'll come back over the rail and get me off the hook here."
Rose said: "You're crazy."
Jack said: "That's what everybody says. But with all due respect, I'm not the one hanging off the back of a ship."

Jack said: "I'm Jack Dawson."
Rose said: "Pleased to meet you, Mr. Dawson."

Rose said: "HELP! HELP!!"
Jack said: "I've got you. I won't let go."

Jack said: "Hello again."
Rose said: "Could I speak to you in private?"
Jack said: "Uh, yes. Of course. After you."

Jack said: "So, you got a name by the way?"
Rose said: "Rose. Rose DeWitt Bukater."
Jack said: "That's quite a moniker. I may hafta get you to write that down."

Rose said: "Mr. Dawson, I --"
Jack said: "Jack."
Rose said: "Jack... I feel like such an idiot. It took me all morning to get up the nerve to face you."
Jack said: "Well, here you are."
Rose said: "Here I am. I... I want to thank you for what you did. Not just for... for pulling me back. But for your discretion."
Jack said: "You're welcome. Rose."
Rose said: "Look, I know what you must be thinking! Poor little rich girl. What does she know about misery?"
Jack said: "That's not what I was thinking. What I was thinking was... what could have happened to hurt this girl so much she though she had no way out."
Rose said: "I don't... it wasn't just one thing. It was everything. It was them, it was their whole world. And I was trapped in it, like an insect in amber.  I just had to get away... just run and run and run... and then I was at the back rail and there was no more ship... even the Titanic wasn't big enough. Not enough to get away from them. And before I'd really though about it, I was over the rail. I was so furious. I'll show them. They'll be sorry!"
Jack said: "Uh huh. They'll be sorry. 'Course you'll be dead."
Rose said: "Oh God, I am such an utter fool."
Jack said: "That penguin last night, is he one of them?"
Rose said: "Penguin? Oh, Cal! He is them."
Jack said: "Is he your boyfriend?"
Rose said: "Worse I'm afraid."

Jack said: "So you feel like you're stuck on a train you can't get off 'cause you're marryin' this fella."
Rose said: "Yes, exactly!"
Jack said: "So don't marry him."
Rose said: "If only it were that simple."
Jack said: "It is that simple."
Rose said: "Oh, Jack... please don't judge me until you've seen my world."
Jack said: "Well, I guess I will tonight."

Rose said: "What's this?"
Jack said: "Just some sketches."
Rose said: "May I?"

Rose said: "Jack, these are quite good! Really, they are."
Jack said: "Well, they didn't think too much of 'em in Paree."

Rose said: "Oh no! Oh, I'm so sorry. Truly!"
Jack said: "Well, they didn't think too much of 'em in Paree."

Rose said: "And these were drawn from life?"
Jack said: "Yup. That's one of the great things about Paris. Lots of girls willing take their clothes off."

Rose said: "You liked this woman. You used her several times."
Jack said: "She had beautiful hands."
Rose said: "I think you must have had a love affair with her..."
Jack said: "No, no! Just with her hands."
Rose said: "You have a gift, Jack. You do. You see people."
Jack said: "I see you."

Rose said: "And...?"
Jack said: "You wouldn'ta jumped."

Rose said: "You know, my dream has always been to just chuck it all and become an artist... living in a garret, poor but free!"
Jack said: "You wouldn't last two days. There's no hot water, and hardly ever any caviar."
Rose said: "Listen, buster... I hate caviar! And I'm tired of people dismissing my dreams with a chuckle and a pat on the head."
Jack said: "I'm sorry. Really... I am."
Rose said: "Well, alright. There's something in me, Jack. I feel it. I don't know what it is, whether I should be an artist, or, I don't know... a dancer. Like Isadora Duncan.... a wild pagan spirit..."

Rose said: "So then what, Mr. Wandering Jack?"
Jack said: "Well, then logging got to be too much like work, so I went down to Los Angeles to the pier in Santa Monica. That's a swell place, they even have a rollercoaster. I sketched portraits there for ten cents a piece."
Rose said: "A whole ten cents?!"
Jack said: "Yeah; it was great money... I could make a dollar a day, sometimes. But only in summer. When it got cold, I decided to go to Paris and see what the real artists were doing."
Rose said: "Why can't I be like you Jack? Just head out for the horizon whenever I feel like it.  Say we'll go there, sometime... to that pier... even if we only ever just talk about it."
Jack said: "Alright, we're going. We'll drink cheap beer and go on the rollercoaster until we throw up and we'll ride horses on the beach... right in the surf... but you have to ride like a cowboy, none of that side-saddle stuff."
Rose said: "You mean one leg on each side? Scandalous! Can you show me?"
Jack said: "Sure. If you like."
Rose said: "I think I would.  And teach me to spit too. Like a man. Why should only men be able to spit. It's unfair."
Jack said: "They didn't teach you that in finishing school? Here, it's easy. Watch closely."

Jack said: "I saw that in a nickelodeon once, and I always wanted to do it."
Rose said: "Cal, surely you remember Mr. Dawson."

Rose said: "Jack, must you go?"
Jack said: "Time for my coach to turn back into a pumpkin."

Rose said: "May I cut in, miss?"
Jack said: "You're still my best girl, Cora."

Rose said: "I don't know the steps."
Jack said: "Just move with me. Don't think."

Jack said: "You're not one of them. There's been a mistake."
Rose said: "A mistake?"
Jack said: "Uh huh. You got mailed to the wrong address."
Rose said: "I did, didn't I?  Look! A shooting star."
Jack said: "That was a long one. My father used to say that whenever you saw one, it was a soul going to heaven."
Rose said: "I like that. Aren't we supposed to wish on it?"

Jack said: "Rose, you're no picnic... you're a spoiled little brat even, but under that you're a strong, pure heart, and you're the most amazingly astounding girl I've ever known and --"
Rose said: "Jack, I --"
Jack said: "No wait. Let me try to get this out. You're amazing... and I know I have nothing to offer you, Rose. I know that. But I'm involved now. You jump, I jump, remember? I can't turn away without knowin' that you're goin' to be alright."

Rose said: "You're making this very hard. I'll be fine. Really."
Jack said: "I don't think so. They've got you in a glass jar like some butterfly, and you're goin' to die if you don't break out. Maybe not right away, 'cause you're strong. But sooner or later the fire in you is goin' to go out."
Rose said: "It's not up to you to save me, Jack."
Jack said: "You're right. Only you can do that."
Rose said: "I have to get back, they'll miss me. Please, Jack, for both our sakes, leave me alone."

Rose said: "Fabrizio said you might be up --"
Jack said: "Sssshh. Come here."

Rose said: "Will this light do? Don't artists need good light?"
Jack said: "Zat is true, I am not used to working in such 'orreeble conditions.  Hey... Monet!"

Rose said: "Cal insist on lugging this thing everywhere."
Jack said: "Should I be expecting him anytime soon?"
Rose said: "Not as long as the cigars and brandy hold out."

Jack said: "What is it? A sapphire?"
Rose said: "A diamond. A very rare diamond, called the Heart of the Ocean."

Rose said: "I believe you are blushing, Mr. Big Artiste. I can't imagine Monsieur Monet blushing."
Jack said: "He does landscapes."

Jack said: "Pretty tough for a valet, this fella."
Rose said: "He's an ex-Pinkerton. Cal's father hired him to keep Cal out of trouble... to make sure he always got back to the hotel with his wallet and watch, after some crawl through the less reputable parts of town..."
Jack said: "Kinda like we're doin' right now -- uh oh!"

Jack said: "Where to, Miss?"
Rose said: "To the stars."

Jack said: "Are you nervous?"
Rose said: "Au contraire, mon cher."

Rose said: "You're trembling."
Jack said: "It's okay. I'm alright."

Rose said: "When this ship docks, I'm getting off with you."
Jack said: "This is crazy."
Rose said: "I know. It doesn't make any sense. That's why I trust it."

Jack said: "Looks okay. I don't see anything."
Rose said: "Could it have damaged the ship?"
Jack said: "It didn't seem like much of a bump. I'm sure we're okay."

Jack said: "It's bad."
Rose said: "We have to tell Mother and Cal."
Jack said: "Now it's worse."
Rose said: "Come with me, Jack. I jump, you jump... Right?"
Jack said: "Right."

Jack said: "This is horseshit."
Rose said: "Cal, you can't be serious! We're in the middle of an emergency and you --"

Jack said: "Don't you believe it, Rose. Don't!"
Rose said: "He couldn't have."

Jack said: "That guy Lovejoy put it in my pocket."
Rose said: "I know, I know."
Jack said: "See if you can find a key for these. Try those drawers. It's a little brass one."

Jack said: "So... how did you find out I didn't do it?"
Rose said: "I didn't.  I just realized I already knew."

Jack said: "You have to go for help."
Rose said: "I'll be right back."
Jack said: "I'll wait here."

Rose said: "Will this work?"
Jack said: "We'll find out."

Rose said: "I'm not going without you."
Jack said: "Get in the boat, Rose."

Rose said: "You jump, I jump, right?"
Jack said: "Right."

Jack said: "Look for something floating. Some debris... wood... anything."
Rose said: "It's so cold."
Jack said: "I know. I know. Help me, here. Look around."

Rose said: "It's getting quiet."
Jack said: "Just a few more minutes. It'll take them a while to get the boats organized..."

Jack said: "No... don't say your good-byes, Rose. Don't you give up. Don't do it."
Rose said: "I'm so cold."
Jack said: "You're going to get out of this... you're going to go on and you're going to make babies and watch them grow and you're going to die an old lady, warm in your bed. Not here. Not this night. Do you understand me?"
Rose said: "I can't feel my body."
Jack said: "Rose, listen to me. Listen. Winning that ticket was the best thing that ever happened to me."

Jack said: "You must do me this honor... promise me you will survive... that you will never give up... no matter what happens... no matter how hopeless... promise me now, and never let go of that promise."
Rose said: "I promise."
Jack said: "Never let go."
Rose said: "I promise. I will never let go, Jack. I'll never let go."

Lightoller said: "I don't think I've ever seen such a flat calm, in 24 years at sea."
Smith said: "Yes, like a mill pond. Not a breath of wind."
Lightoller said: "It's make the bergs harder to see, with no breaking water at the base."
Smith said: "Mmmmm. Well, I'm off. Maintain speed and heading, Mr. Lightoller."
Lightoller said: "Yes sir."
Smith said: "And wake me, of course, if anything becomes in the slightest degree doubtful."

Lizzy said: "April 14, 1912."
Lovett said: "If your grandma is who she says she is, she was wearing the diamond the day Titanic sank.  And that makes you my new best friend. I will happily compensate you for anything you can tell us that will lead to its recovery."

Lovett said: "Wait! Can you give us something go on, here. Like who had access to the safe. What about this Lovejoy guy? The valet. Did he have the combination?"
Lizzy said: "That's enough."

Lovett said: "Maybe she wants to make peace with the past."
Lizzy said: "What past? She has never once, not once, ever said a word about being on the Titanic until two days ago."
Lovett said: "Then we're all meeting your grandmother for the first time."
Lizzy said: "You think she was really there?"
Lovett said: "Oh, yeah. Yeah, I'm a believer. She was there."

Lizzy said: "I'm sorry."
Lovett said: "We were pissin' in the wind the whole time."

Lovett said: "Is your stateroom alright?"
Rose said: "Yes. Very nice. Have you met my granddaughter, Lizzy? She takes care of me."

Rose said: "There, that's nice. I have to have my pictures when I travel. And Freddy of course.  Isn't that right, sweetie."
Lovett said: "Would you like anything?"
Rose said: "I should like to see my drawing."

Lovett said: "Louis the Sixteenth wore a fabulous stone, called the Blue Diamond of the Crown, which disappeared in 1792, about the time Louis lost everything from the neck up. The theory goes that the crown diamond was chopped too... recut into a heart-like shape... and it became Le Coeur de la Mer. The Heart of the Ocean. Today it would be worth more than the Hope Diamond."
Rose said: "It was a dreadful, heavy thing.  I only wore it this once."

Lovett said: "I tracked it down through insurance records... and old claim that was settled under terms of absolute secrecy. Do you know who the claiment was, Rose?"
Rose said: "Someone named Hockley, I should imagine."
Lovett said: "Nathan Hockley, right. Pittsburgh steel tycoon. For a diamond necklace his son Caledon Hockley bought in France for his fiancee... you... a week before he sailed on Titanic. And the claim was filed right after the sinking. So the diamond had to've gone down with the ship.  See the date?"

Rose said: "It's been 84 years..."
Lovett said: "Just tell us what you can --"
Rose said: "It's been 84 years... and I can still smell the fresh paint. The china had never been used. The sheets had never been slept in."

Rose said: "I can still feel its weight. If you could have felt it, not just seen it..."
Lovett said: "Well, that's the general idea, my dear."

Lovett said: "Rose, tell us more about the diamond. What did Hockley do with it after that?"
Rose said: "I'm afraid I'm feeling a little tired, Mr. Lovett."

Rose said: "Don't come any closer."
Lovett said: "You had it the entire time?!"

Ruth said: "My God, Rose, what's gotten into --"
Rose said: "Excuse me."

Rose said: "Mother, may I introduce Jack Dawson."
Ruth said: "Charmed, I'm sure."

Ruth said: "Rose, this is not a game! Our situation is precarious. You know the money's gone!"
Rose said: "Of course I know it's gone. You remind me every day!"
Ruth said: "Your father left us nothing but a legacy of bad debts hidden by a good name. And that name is the only card we have to play."

Ruth said: "I don't understand you. It is a fine match with Hockley, and it will insure our survival."
Rose said: "How can you put this on my shoulders?"

Ruth said: "Do you want to se me working as a seamstress? Is that what you want? Do you want to see our fine things sold at an auction, our memories scattered to the winds? My God, Rose, how can you be so selfish?"
Rose said: "It's so unfair."
Ruth said: "Of course it's unfair! We're women. Our choices are never easy."

Ruth said: "Rose, get in the boat!"
Rose said: "Goodbye, mother."

Lother said: "Anya!"
Anya said: "Don't you hate people that surprise you? ... I do.  We can't stand here."

Lother said: "Anya, I think you're crazy."
Anya said: "Any woman's crazy to feel about a man the way I do about you."
Lother said: "I wasn't running out on you. When I got over there-- made my plans--I'd have sent for you."

Anya said: "Then why the sudden exit without even telling me?"
Lother said: "Do you want the truth, Anya?"
Anya said: "It would be a nice change from you."
Lother said: "I had an idea your husband was getting suspicious."
Anya said: "You're a charming liar. You <U>know</U>, Herbert's too dull to be suspicious about anything--even when I suddenly decided to come to Europe at a few hours' notice--"
Lother said: "How'd you ever get away with it?"
Anya said: "When I found out you were going I just had an attack of nerves--a few tears--and Herbert was on his way downtown to get my passport ... so who cares ... I'm here with you ... and that's all that matters to me."
Lother said: "Sure!"
Anya said: "I never want to go back...."

Anya said: "Here's to Europe!  Couldn't try to look a little less glum, could you?"
Lother said: "Don't be crazy--I'm tickled to death to see you."
Anya said: "That's fine--because you're going to see a lot of me ... for the rest of your life."
