I don't know what most guys want out of life--but <U>that</U> would be enough for me--I wouldn't care about-- easy money--or--showing off my smart brains--I'd just like to live <U>my</U> life so nothing I did would bounce back and ruin <U>hers</U>--Do I make myself clear?"
Brett said: "Very clear. That's one favor I'll be glad to do you."
Denby said: "O.K., kid--  I'm only sorry for one thing."
Brett said: "What's that?"
Denby said: "If you hadn't agreed--I was going to throw you overboard--"

Shortie said: "Here you are, sir."
Dan said: "What'll I say?"

Shortie said: "Eighty cents a word--three--six--nine words. That'll be seven twenty, but it's too much--I'll show you how to save some money."
Dan said: "How?"

Shortie said: "Where do you live?"
Dan said: "In New York."
Shortie said: "Your wife knows that, don't she?"
Dan said: "Sure."
Shortie said: "Then you don't have to tell her--cut out New York."

Shortie said: ""Will be back in four weeks"--  --that saves you eighty cents right there!"
Dan said: "That's right--here's the eighty cents for you. I'd rather see you get it than the company--send it right off."
Shortie said: "Wait a minute--I think I can cut out a couple o' more words."
Dan said: "How?"
Shortie said: ""Will--be--back--in--four--weeks." You don't need the "will be." Just say "Back in four weeks.""
Dan said: "That's right. I owe you a dollar sixty."

Shortie said: "Wait a minute--I think I can cut something else out.  "Back in four weeks." Instead of "in four weeks"--say "next month"--That saves another word."
Dan said: "Right. Here's eighty cents. Send it."

Shortie said: "Just a minute--I don't think we need the word "Back" --Where <U>is</U> "Back"?"
Dan said: "Back is in New York."
Shortie said: "Your wife knows that, don't she?"
Dan said: "Sure."
Shortie said: "Cut it out."

Shortie said: "Now we get it down to two words--"next month.""
Dan said: "Send that."
Shortie said: "Wait a minute--What <U>is</U> next month?"
Dan said: "Next month is June."
Shortie said: "Fine! Instead of saying "next month"--we'll use one word and say "June.""
Dan said: "June? That's my wife's name."
Shortie said: "That's great! There's the address and message all in one word."
Dan said: "O.K.! Send that!"
Shortie said: "Just a minute--Your wife knows her own name, doesn't she?"
Dan said: "Sure."
Shortie said: "Well, there's no use in sending it.  See that--I saved you seven twenty!"
Dan said: "Well. I'd rather see <U>you</U> get it than the company."

Dan said: "I'll say--how fast is this boat going?"
Denby said: "Oh,--we're doing about thirty--"
Dan said: "Pretty good--thirty <U>miles</U> an hour--"
Denby said: "No. <U>Knots</U>!"
Dan said: "What?"
Denby said: "Knots!"
Dan said: "I can see you're no gentleman--"

Denby said: "That's me!"
Dan said: "Not the <U>real</U> Chad Denby?--"
Denby said: "Yes--Me--in person!"
Dan said: "So what?"

Denby said: "I can see where I won't talk much to you."
Dan said: "<U>Nuts</U> to you too!"

Dan said: "Hello, Denby!"
Denby said: "I thought I put you to bed."
Dan said: "Oh, was that me you put to bed? Thanks. I've been looking all over for you."
Denby said: "Well, did you find me?"
Dan said: "Not yet.  Say, where is this boat headed for?"
Denby said: "This is a fine time to be asking that. You're on your way to France."
Dan said: "That's news to me. I'd better cable my wife."

Denby said: "Hey, boy--give this man a cablegram blank.  Where is your wife?"
Dan said: "She's in New York."

Denby said: "Tell her you're on your way to France and will be back in four weeks."
Dan said: "That's fine."

Denby said: "Come on, get up.  That horse is carrying too much of a load."
Dan said: "Who won?"
Denby said: "Well, you got the first down--there's one more to go. Come on, we're ready to start right now. Come on. Just keep stiff."
Dan said: "I was never stiffer in my life."
Denby said: "All right, folks, get on your mark. When you hear the pistol shot--"

Mary said: "He's funny--maybe you can use him in the show, Mr. Denby."
Dan said: "<U>Denby!</U>--Are you Chad Denby?"

Mary said: "Oh, there you are--"
Dan said: "That's right--you're the one I was looking for.  You'll excuse me.   How about you and I being alone?"
Mary said: "Not now, Toots--Which is the right way to say this? You're dumber than me--or--you're dumber than I?"
Dan said: "Let me see now--Don't tell me--  You're dumber than me and I'm dumber than you. I don't get it."
Mary said: "Never mind."

Mckinney said: "McKinney's the name."
Denby said: "Miss Marsh."

Denby said: "Here we are, folks--eighty thousand wild-eyed fans go mad--they go mad as Chad Denby--with the arms of iron, and the nerves of steel--picks up his racket--  What is this thing--a racket or a mallet?"
Mckinney said: "Looks to me like standard equipment for the Department of Street Cleaning--"
Denby said: "Too bad we're not making a trip around the world-- maybe we could finish this game.  Hey! When you get through with that conference, shoot that last disk!"

Mckinney said: "You can always tell how much a man's traveled by the way he plays shuffle-board."
Denby said: "Yeah--if he'd only stick to shuffle-board."

Mckinney said: "Those kids seem to be getting along fine!--"
Denby said: "It must be the sea air--it gets everybody."
Mckinney said: "He's a likable chap--he's got an honest face--"
Denby said: "It's all right--if you like honest faces--let's have another drink--Steward!"
Mckinney said: "Oh no--I don't want to impose on you--  It's funny about that billfold--I could have sworn I had it-"

Denby said: "Hello, Inspector--I hear your vacation's been spoiled. Somebody lost a bracelet."
Mckinney said: "Yes, a bracelet's been lost, but I'm still on my vacation."
Denby said: "I understand you searched Brett for it last night. By the way--what do you know about him?"
Mckinney said: "Well, I've seen him here and there. What's on your mind?"
Denby said: "Oh, nothing--only I wondered why you suspected him."
Mckinney said: "Well, I'll tell you--we picked him up about a year ago-- but could never pin anything on him."
Denby said: "Maybe he just travels in bad company."
Mckinney said: "Yeah--"

Denby said: "I didn't--"
Mckinney said: "He asked for a loan of it, didn't he?"
Denby said: "Yes--but I didn't give it to him--"
Mckinney said: "Is this your gun?"
Denby said: "Yes!"

Sally said: "Well, that's something--even if only the fish can see it."
Denby said: "Are you happy?"
Sally said: "Will be--as soon as the ship sails."

Sally said: "Am I a member of this club?"
Denby said: "You're the President. Come in! Your brother was just telling me a few jokes I can use on the radio--"
Sally said: "Are you paying any attention to his jokes?--the first thing you know, you'll be taking piano lessons from Venus de Milo--  Get out of here."
Denby said: "Everything O.K.?"
Sally said: "Just what the doctor ordered."

Sally said: "Looks like your old workshop back on 42nd Street."
Denby said: "Like it?"
Sally said: "Swell--You've got Times Square right here--all but the noises--"
Denby said: "Yep--spending lots of time aboard--you see, Sally, I sold this Transatlantic idea to the shipping company."
Sally said: "And you've put it over--haven't you?"
Denby said: "Why not? I give 'em a great show--and you know-- We're doing capacity, Sally--and all <U>Nice</U> people--"
Sally said: "You never fail at anything, do you, Chad?"
Denby said: "No--not much--excepting--"
Sally said: "Still got my picture, I see--I was pretty dumb then, wasn't I, Chad?"
Denby said: "No--Inexperienced--  A red-headed kid--homemade clothes--Broadway was Paradise--and a slot at the Automat was a Banquet."
Sally said: "I came to tell you what a swell guy I think you are to do this--"
Denby said: "Do what--"
Sally said: "You made it possible for us to get away at a few hours' notice--you never asked why, but I guess you know."
Denby said: "News travels fast on Broadway--you had to get away from a rat--"
Sally said: "It wasn't only that--Ned was in a jam."
Denby said: "I get it--Lee Lother have a hand in that, too?"
Sally said: "I was so crazy about him--anything he did or said was O.K. by me.  I introduced him to people--even after I knew his stock promoting was phoney and the card games were crooked. It didn't seem to matter--I didn't care--  --until he roped Ned in. Some confidence game--and the kid left his fingerprints on a drinking glass."
Denby said: "I felt pretty low, Sally, when I heard you were running around with a racketeer--"
Sally said: "Women have a curious taste for knickknacks. When I found out about Ned--tried to make a break--Lee wouldn't stand for it and--well--here I am!"
Denby said: "Stay on the other side of the pond for a couple of months--you'll soon forget all about it."
Sally said: "Chad Denby broadcasting--  --the nicest man I ever knew--"
Denby said: "But not nice enough to marry--eh?"
Sally said: "Come on, now--you've forgotten all about that."
Denby said: "I'll never love anybody else."

Sally said: "Women are such fools!--Why do so many of us pass up <U>right</U> guys?"
Denby said: "Guess they're dull--nothing for you to reform."

Sally said: "You're just a Master of Ceremonies. He might have knocked his head off."
Denby said: "What's the difference? He's got more heads than he needs."
Sally said: "I don't get the humor of that remark."
Denby said: "<U>He</U> does. Here's your quarter, Brett."

Sally said: "Yes."
Denby said: "Very serious?"
Sally said: "Very--"

Sally said: "Why--don't you like him?"
Denby said: "Of course--but--  There's your cue--hurry up--"

Denby said: "I'll give you another chance to tell the truth, Lother."
Lother said: "What do you mean?"
Denby said: "Why don't you be a good little boy and leave her alone?"
Lother said: "Oh--I understand you were an important part of her education when she came to New York."
Denby said: "I just tried to show her the difference between the squirrels and the skunks."
Lother said: "Meaning what?"
Denby said: "You don't shoot squirrels."

Denby said: "Yep--everybody's having a good time but me--What do you want, Mary?"
Mary said: "I just wrote a poem about the Atlantic Ocean--"
Denby said: "But, Mary--everybody's having such a great time-- why spoil it?"
Mary said: "Somebody's got to do it--"
Denby said: "Well, let's hear the poem--"
Mary said: "Oh, you dear Atlantic Ocean--how you spread across the sea--From New York to dear old Europe--just for boats to ride on thee--"
Denby said: "Very good, Mary--"
Mary said: "But I'm not finished yet----And your waves are so colossal--rocking boats both to and fro--Oh-h, Atlantic, how I love you ----how I love you--"
Denby said: "What's the matter, Mary?"
Mary said: "I'm getting seasick--"
Denby said: "H'mm--<U>Dear</U> Atlantic--"
Mary said: "Mr. Denby--What do you think I ought to do with that part?"
Denby said: "Put the whole thing in an envelope and mail it through a porthole--"

Mary said: "Oh, Mr. Den-n-by!"
Denby said: "Everyone but me--what do you want now, Mary?"
Mary said: "I feel better now--I've got a riddle! When is a plate of bean soup not a plate of bean soup?"
Denby said: "All right. When <U>is</U> a plate of bean soup not a plate of noodle soup?"
Mary said: "When it falls off the table and turns turtle--Cute?"
Denby said: "Mary--fall off the boat and turn to the left--"

Mary said: "With your dry wit and humor--"
Denby said: "Oh yeah?--My personality put this thing over--"
Mary said: "Maurice Chevalier! There's a fellow with personality."
Denby said: "What's he got that I haven't got?"
Mary said: "Well, he has a straw hat--"
Denby said: "So have I--I can get it right out of my trunk."
Mary said: "--And he has sex appeal."
Denby said: "So what?"
Mary said: "Get that out of your trunk."
Denby said: "All right--don't spoil the trip with any of those jokes-- there's a nice bunch of people on this trip--nothing but class--I looked over the passenger list and they're all members of the Who's Who!"
Mary said: "Never mind the Who's Who--Before I get on this boat I want to know What's What! How about my raise? All I get out of these ocean trips is dizzy."
Denby said: "Don't blame it on the ocean!--All right, you'll get the raise!"

Mary said: "Is that one of the Who's Who?"
Denby said: "No--He's probably one of the "Here's How."  Take it easy--the ocean's pretty rough today--"

Denby said: "H'mm ... no wonder I have trouble rounding up this show--Don't you know there's a rehearsal going on?-- And you wanted a raise.--Come on--get going or you'll get it!"
Mary said: "Oh, all right--  See you later, Toots."

Mary said: "Oh, Chad--what about the rest of the show?"
Denby said: "Oh,--I was having so much fun I almost forgot--"

Mary said: "Oh, Mr. Denby, I wrote a poem about a bracelet--"
Denby said: "Good-night, folks."

Denby said: "Then, after the first number, I tell the one about the Scotchman trying to open a Pullman window--the Scotchman says to the window--"Gee you're tight."-- and the window says--"You loosen up a bit and so will I."--Good?--And then I do the one--  Oh--you don't like it, eh?"
Ned said: "Chad--Lother's on the boat, and I'm worried sick about Sally--"
Denby said: "Oh!--So that's it. Does she know he's on board?"
Ned said: "No--but I'm going to keep my eye on--"

Denby said: "What happened to you?"
Ned said: "You've got a gun, haven't you, Chad? Will you let me have it?"
Denby said: "What for?"
Ned said: "Don't ask any questions--just give it to me."
Denby said: "Easy kid--easy....  Come on--I want to talk to you."

Lother said: "You're wasting your time--she's a friend of mine."
Summers said: "Eh?... Oh."
Lother said: "He works the boats as a "come-on" man. We ought to make a fair combination and do a little business. Jack's a pretty good dealer himself."
Summers said: "There's a lot of trout in this stream just waitin' for a fly.  I've already been workin' on a young fellow from Chicago--related to one of the big packin' families--on his way to Biarritz for a good time. Likes a little game of bridge and poker."

Summers said: "That's him! That's the sucker!!"
Lother said: "Looks lonesome--Bring him over here."

Lother said: "Can you read 'em Jack?"
Summers said: "They're a cinch to read--Queen of Clubs--  --Ace of Diamonds."
Lother said: "The man that marks them is an artist--two hundred and fifty bucks for six decks--and they're worth it."
Summers said: "The country boy's about due."
Lother said: "Better unlock the door.  Sit up, darling, and be dignified."

Summers said: "Out my way in Montana we always call a bluff."
Lother said: "Well, I helped my hand so I'll have to see you."

Lother said: "How much did you lose?"
Summers said: "About twelve hundred."
Lother said: "I went for four."
Summers said: "It's a long trip and we'll get that sucker later."

Sally said: "All right--but what is there to face? It's finished."
Lother said: "You ran away because you were afraid. I don't want it to end like that."
Sally said: "I didn't want to see you again--that's my privilege."
Lother said: "It wasn't smart. Even if you'd gotten away without me --I'd have found you--no matter where you were."
Sally said: "Why don't you leave me alone?"
Lother said: "Because I want you--will always want you--no other woman'll ever take your place.  I want you more now than I did that first night--  You've forgotten all that, I suppose?"
Sally said: "I wish I could."
Lother said: "Get wise to yourself, Sally--you're no sob story."

Sally said: "You get wise to <U>yourself</U>! If you know what's good for you, you'll leave me alone. Everybody's entitled to one mistake--Well--you're mine. When the going got too rough, I pulled up stakes and quit. We stay quit!--Get that!--And what're you going to do about it?"
Lother said: "That's more like the old Sally--a little bit of fire.  How about Ned?"
Sally said: "He's all right."
Lother said: "Thanks to me."
Sally said: "You leave the kid alone."
Lother said: "A tipoff in the right quarter to take his fingerprints and--"
Sally said: "--you'd go with him!"
Lother said: "Don't kid yourself--you know how I stand back there."

Sally said: "Not because of Ned."
Lother said: "Of course not--  --but isn't it a coincidence that he's from the eighteenth precinct--where they made the squawk?"
Sally said: "You can't bluff me any more."

Sally said: "I'm crazy about the kid and I got him into it.  What do you want me to do?"
Lother said: "Just smile again and be reasonable.  I'll order dinner here--just the two of us--like old times."
Sally said: "--and you swear when you get to the other side, you'll never come near either of us again?"
Lother said: "That's a bet--but I couldn't let you walk out like that, Sally. I'd have gone cuckoo back there--just thinking about you--"

Sally said: "Don't, Lee--that's dead."
Lother said: "Let's see if I can bring it back to life."

Lother said: "Go ahead--you didn't used to be so fussy--"
Sally said: "I've lost my taste for knickknacks--"
Lother said: "Don't be a mug all your life--I'm trying to help you-- you need me more than I need you--have you figured they might pick the kid up in France and extradite him?"
Sally said: "Have you ever figured they might extradite you?"
Lother said: "I'm not so clumsy with fingerprints--"

Lother said: "I know he is. You change those clothes and then come to my cabin. I'll expect you around twelve o'clock."
Sally said: "Not a chance--I'm through."

Ned said: "Yes, Yes!"
Mckinney said: "You didn't have a gun in your hand last night?"
Ned said: "No!"
Mckinney said: "S'pose you've never thought of killing him--"
Ned said: "I wouldn't say that--  I'm glad he's dead--yes--I'd thought of killing him-- but I didn't--"
Mckinney said: "Why?"
Ned said: "Because I was yellow, I guess--"

Ned said: "I tried to borrow a gun from Chad, but--"
Mckinney said: "This is interesting--  Why didn't you tell me you gave this kid your gun last night?"

Sally said: "It's getting kind of chilly on deck. If you'll excuse me, I think I'll go to bed. Good night, Mr. McKinney!"
Mckinney said: "Good night!"

Mckinney said: "Congratulations."
Sally said: "Exciting, wasn't it? Where's Jimmy?"
Mckinney said: "He'll be back.  What would you do if anybody gave you a bracelet?"
Sally said: "Say, "Thanks very much!""
Mckinney said: "I mean if you knew it were stolen."
Sally said: "Well, of course, I wouldn't take it."
Mckinney said: "And if you liked the person, you'd naturally persuade him to give it back and go straight, wouldn't you?"
Sally said: "Sure I would--but I don't get what you're driving at."
Mckinney said: "Maybe you will after you've thought it over."

Sally said: "That's the truth--every single word!"
Mckinney said: "I sincerely hope so--"
Sally said: "Why should <U>I</U> kill him?"
Mckinney said: "For a very excellent reason from your own admission--  --I'm not saying you <U>did</U>--but I think you know more than you're telling. Years of experience have taught me to mistrust circumstantial evidence. Nevertheless, in your case there's plenty of it."

Mckinney said: "Soon as I get that bracelet back I'm going to relax. Wish the guy that borrowed it would help me out--I got to win that fifty bucks."
Sally said: "I've got a hunch you're going to win that bet, Inspector."
Mckinney said: "I hope so. Well, I guess you two can do without me. I'll be seeing you."

Mckinney said: "Next time I get a vacation I'll spend it at headquarters. Good-night."
Sally said: "He's a swell person. He told me he'd rather turn one guy straight than jug a million."

Purser said: "There you are, sir."
Mckinney said: "Thank you."
Purser said: "Thirty one's and two ten's?"

Purser said: "He's certainly good-natured."
Mckinney said: ""Smooth's" the word."
Purser said: "I mean--a lot of gentlemen would be offended if you searched them like that."
Mckinney said: "It all depends on what you're used to."

Mckinney said: "Well, I'll be a son of a sea cook!"
Purser said: "What's the matter?"
Mckinney said: "Nothin--  --I just remembered the name of a guy that owes me fifty bucks."

Ned said: "I thought I had our sailing covered up--  --and here it is."
Sally said: "Do you think Lother could have seen it?"

Sally said: "Isn't it great to be away from it all? Aren't you happy? It seems too good to be true."
Ned said: "Sure, Sis."
Sally said: "Aren't the roses beautiful?"

Sally said: "I'm all right."
Ned said: "You saw him sitting out there in front, didn't you?"
Sally said: "I was in his cabin--"
Ned said: "What!--are you crazy?"
Sally said: "I'll explain later--"
Ned said: "If he comes near you again, I'll break his neck--"

Steward said: "Everything in order, sir?  What are <U>you</U> doing here, my lad?"
Shortie said: "Telegrams."
Steward said: "Well--get a move on yer--then get back to yer station."

Shortie said: "Nothin'."
Steward said: "Let me look at it."
Shortie said: "Ain't got time."
Steward said: "Hey--you! Where you going?"

Shortie said: "I tell yuh I ain't got no bracelet--"
Steward said: "I saw him take the bracelet out of that shoe."
Shortie said: "Yer crazy!--I ain't got no bracelet."
Steward said: "Then why did you run away?"
Shortie said: "Because you ran after me."

Bailey said: "I said that's 500 to you, Holliday.  In or out?"
Doc said: "500? Sly boots, must be a peach of a hand."

Bailey said: "Oh, for Christ's sake!"
Doc said: "Ed Bailey, you look like you're Just ready to burst.  Well call me A fool but I guess I'll just have To call.  Cover your ears, darling."

Bailey said: "God damn son of a..."
Doc said: "Isn't that a daisy?"
Bailey said: "Just pick up your money and go. Sick of listening to you simper."
Doc said: "Now Ed, are we cross?"

Bailey said: "Skinny lunger, your guns don't Impress me.  Wasn't for those guns You'd be nothin'."
Doc said: "Why Ed, what an ugly thing to Say!  Does this mean you're not my Friend anymore?  You know, Ed, if I thought you weren't my friend I Don't think I could bear it."

Bailey said: "Oh, my God..."
Doc said: "Does it hurt?  A lot?  Good."

Behan said: "Newcomers, eh?  Names John Behan, I'm Cochise County Sheriff.  Just Hit town?"
Wyatt said: "Just this minute.  I'm Wyatt Earp, These're my brothers-"
Behan said: "Wyatt Earp...Dodge City, right?"
Wyatt said: "Gave all that up.  Going into business."
Behan said: "Well I'm the man to see.  Besides Sheriff I'm also tax collector, Captain of the Fire Brigade, and Chairman of the Non-partisan Anti- Chinese league.  A man of many Parts.  Got a place to stay yet?  I Also sit on the Townlot Commission.  Got a couple of Lovely cottages coming up for Rent.  Here, let me show you..."

Behan said: "So how's Tombstone treating you?"
Wyatt said: "Fine, fine.  But I was thinkin', You know what this town really Needs is a race track."
Behan said: "Actually, you know, that's not a Bad idea, send a signal we're Growing up."

Behan said: "What d'you think of the singer?"
Wyatt said: "Nice voice."
Behan said: "That's not what I meant."

Josephine said: "The man dealing faro.  Who is he?"
Behan said: "That's Wyatt Earp.  Made quite a Name for himself as a peace Officer in Kansas."
Josephine said: "A peace officer... Impressive man"
Behan said: "Yes, very.  And very married."
Josephine said: "Oh, so that's it..."

Behan said: "Well I guess you can see, never a Dull moment.  Maybe you should Stay around to see what happens Next.  Who know?  You might find a Future here."
Josephine said: "Maybe even my destiny."

Behan said: "I saw that look on your face just now. What's between you and Wyatt?"
Josephine said: "Absolutely nothing."

Behan said: "Listen, I want to talk to you."
Josephine said: "Not now.  I don't have time."
Behan said: "I saw that look pass between you And Wyatt at the fight.  Listen to Me!  You're mine!  Understand? You're my woman and I'm your man."
Josephine said: "My man?  You told Wyatt you'd Disarmed those men.  Do you Actually believe after that I Could see you as my man?  You're Just a dirty little fixer."
Behan said: "You whore!  You filthy whore!"

Behan said: "Easy.  I just wanted to tell you Things're about to start changing Around here.  Lots of so-called Hard cases and tough-nuts swagger Around this town but none of 'em's got a clue about the real play.  None of 'em."
Josephine said: "I don't understand."
Behan said: "You will after tonight.  Bet on it."

Billy said: "He said to turn loose of him."
Wyatt said: "Well I'm not so go home."

Wyatt said: "Where'd you get that horse?"
Billy said: "Beauty, ain't he?"
Wyatt said: "I asked where you got him."
Billy said: "Where do you think?  I stole him."

Wyatt said: "Look, I don't want any trouble With you but that's my horse and I mean to have him back.  One way Or another."
Billy said: "Come and get him."
Wyatt said: "Look kid, I know what it's like, I was a kid, too.  Even stole a Horse once.  But you can't--"

Curly Bill said: "What'd the Messican mean, a sick Horse's gonna get us?  Didn't make No sense."
Ringo said: "He was quoting the bible, Revelations: "Behold a pale horse And the one that sat on him was Death and Hell followed with him.""
Curly Bill said: "Well now that's a little more Like it."

Curly Bill said: "Shut up, Ike."
Ringo said: "And you must be Doc Holliday."

Ringo said: "I want them spitting blood!"
Curly Bill said: "Easy, Johnny.  Now ain't the time.  I tell you, boys, even I'm Worried what'll happen once Ringo Runs this outfit!  God have mercy!"

Ringo said: "There's no God, there's no devil, I hate the God damn world!  I want To die!"
Curly Bill said: "Easy, son.  You just need to get Your feet back under you, that's All.  Come on, boy, let's kick South.  Down to the old playground."

Ringo said: "Hey, you smell that?  Smells like Something died."
Curly Bill said: "Oh, Jesus, Johnny..."

Wyatt said: "I'm retired."
Curly Bill said: "Good.  That's real good."

Wyatt said: "Come on, you..."
Curly Bill said: "Crack me back of the head like Some stinkin' bull.  Hell, you Ain't no fightin' man, you're Just a cop."

Curly Bill said: "Feel bad about ol' Fred.  Just Can't hold back when I'm feelin' Woolly.  Still, feel kinda bad. But now we're square.  Anyway no Use for holdin' a grudge.  I Deserved a rap in the head."
Wyatt said: "Make you a deal.  My brother took Over the Marshal's office in Tombstone.  Got it in his head He's gonna make the place safe For widows and orphans.  You and Your boys stay out of his way, I'll make sure he stays out of yours."
Curly Bill said: "Fair enough.  You know I got to Admit, you got a lot of bark on You comin' up here like this."
Wyatt said: "They were all gonna jump me back There.  What ever happened to one Against one?"
Curly Bill said: "Ain't our way.  We go all on one, One on all.  Fight one of us, you Fight us all.  That's the Cowboy way."
Wyatt said: "And how come you call yourselves Cowboys?  Cowhands ride for the brand."
Curly Bill said: "Oh, we ride for a brand all right.  This brand.  How 'bout you?"
Wyatt said: "This brand."
Curly Bill said: "We're gonna get along just fine."

Wyatt said: "I'm sorry.  If there was any other-"
Curly Bill said: "I know.  Just did what you had to. That banner and stuff, that's Just Ike.  Don't worry about it."

Wyatt said: "I want you to know it's over. We're leaving and we're not Coming back."
Curly Bill said: "Well... 'bye."

Curly Bill said: "Look at that!  Yeah!  Come and get Some, boy!"
Wyatt said: "No..."

Curly Bill said: "Let me, let me, yeah!  Die, you Bastard..."
Wyatt said: "No..."

Wyatt said: "Forget it."
Dake said: "Excuse me?"
Wyatt said: "I said forget it, answer's no, I Don't want the job and that's Final.  I'm going to Tombstone and Nothin' short of dyin's gonn Stop me.  Good day."
Dake said: "But wait, you don't understand-"
Wyatt said: "No Marshal, you don't understand. I'm through with lawing, I'm Through with the whole Proposition.  Forever.  I did my Duty, now I'd like to get on with My life.  That is if you don't Mind.  Jesus.  Good day now."
Dake said: "I see, off to strike it rich, Huh.  All right, fine, wish you Luck.  Tell you this though, never Was a rich man yet didn't wind up With a guilty conscience."
Wyatt said: "Already got a guilty conscience, Might as well have the money too."

Doc said: "That's the rumor."
Ringo said: "You retired, too?"
Doc said: "Not me.  I'm in my prime."
Ringo said: "Yeah, you look it."
Doc said: "And you must be Ringo.  Look, Darling, Johnny Ringo.  The Deadliest pistoleer since Wild Bill, they say.  What do you Think, darling?  Should I hate him?"

Ringo said: "Age quod agis."
Doc said: "Credat Judaeus Apella."
Ringo said: "Ecentus stultorum magister."
Doc said: "In pace requiescat."

Doc said: "That's just my game."
Ringo said: "All right, lunger.  Have at it."

Doc said: "On three?  You call it."
Ringo said: "Here it come: one-two-"

Doc said: "Why Johnny Ringo, you look like Somebody just walked over your grave.  Oh, I wasn't quite as sick as I Made out."
Ringo said: "My fight's not with you, Holliday."
Doc said: "I beg to differ.  We started a Fight we never got to finish. Play for blood, remember?"
Ringo said: "I was kidding about that."

Ringo said: "All right, lunger.  Let's do it."
Doc said: "Say when."

Kate said: "Here, Doc."
Doc said: "Bless you, darling  Darling!  Are you mad?  You're not Wearing a bustle.  How lewd!"

Doc said: "I calculate that's the end of This town.  And let's don't bother About the luggage, darling."
Kate said: "I been having the boy at the Hotel pack us up every night Since your streak started"

Kate said: "You don't even know him."
Doc said: "Yes, but there's just something About him.  Something around The eyes, I don't know, reminds me Of... me.  No.  I'm sure of it, I Hate him."

Kate said: "That's my lovin' man.  Just can't Get enough."
Doc said: "Enough?  Never."

Kate said: "What's wrong, Doc?"
Doc said: "Nothing.  Not a thing.  I'm right As the mail."

Kate said: "How you feeling, Doc?"
Doc said: "Better."
Kate said: "That's good.  I knew it wasn't nothin'."

Doc said: "We must talk, darling.  It appears We have to... redefine the nature Of our association."
Kate said: "What's that mean, Doc?  You know I Don't understand when you talk up High like that.  You mean you Don't want to be my lovin' man no more?"
Doc said: "Not exactly..."
Kate said: "I'm a good woman to you, Doc. Don't I always take care of you? Nobody cares for you like me.  I'm A good woman."
Doc said: "Yes, I know.  You are a good woman."

Wyatt said: "Doc!  How the hell are you?"
Doc said: "Perfect, Wyatt.  Simply perfect."

Doc said: "Since when is faro a business?"
Wyatt said: "Didn't you always say gambling's An honest trade?"
Doc said: "I said poker's an honest trade. Only suckers buck the tiger.  The Odds are all with the house."
Wyatt said: "Depends how you look at it.  I Mean it's not like anybody's Holding a gun to their heads."
Doc said: "That's what I love about Wyatt. He can talk himself into anything."

Wyatt said: "Sheriff Behan, Doc Holliday."
Doc said: "Forgive me if I don't shake hands."

Doc said: "Very cosmopolitan."
Wyatt said: "I know him.  That's Creek Johnson."

Doc said: "Very instructive"
Wyatt said: "But who was the Devil?"

Wyatt said: "So now we're in the mining Business.  Turning into regular Tycoons.  Gonna call this one the Mattie Blaylock.  Mattie'll get a Kick out of that, it's her maiden Name."
Doc said: "And what a maiden, pure as the Driven snow, I'm sure."

Doc said: "So tell me, Wyatt.  I'm curious. Do you actually consider youself A married man?  Forsaking all Others?"
Wyatt said: "Well yeah.  Pretty much.  I mean I Was no angel when we met but People change Doc.  I mean sooner Or later you gotta grow up."
Doc said: "I see.  And what would you do if "she" walked in her right now? WYATT "She"?"
Doc said: "You know damn well who I mean. That dusky-hued lady Satan."
Wyatt said: "I don't know.  Probably ignore her."
Doc said: "Ignore her?"
Wyatt said: "I'd ignore her.  People can Change, Doc."
Doc said: "I'll remember you said that."

Wyatt said: "Satisfied?"
Doc said: "I stand corrected.  Wyatt.  You're An oak."

Wyatt said: "He's drunk."
Doc said: "In vino veritas."

Wyatt said: "Maybe I ought to go out there."
Doc said: "You will or you won't.  Don't look To me.  I'm going to sleep."

Doc said: "Wyatt!  Just in time.  Pull up a chair."
Wyatt said: "Been hittin' it awful hard, Doc."
Doc said: "Nonsense, I have not yet begun to Defile myself."
Wyatt said: "But Doc-"
Doc said: "I won't be pawed at, thank you Very much"
Wyatt said: "Sorry, sorry..."

Doc said: "It appears he missed an excellent Chance to keep his mouth shut."
Wyatt said: "Felt his liver go on that last One.  Get him to a doctor or he'll Be dead in a couple hours."

Doc said: "Wyatt, my God!  You're shot to pieces!"
Wyatt said: "No..."

Doc said: "I'm a man without fear, Wyatt.  I Literally don't care if I live or Die.  But even I can't fight human Instinct.  Somebody suddenly Starts shooting at me, I duck. But you... what on earth were You thinking about?"
Wyatt said: "I don't know.  It all happened so Fast.  If I'd had a chance to Think about it I guess I probably Would've been scared but... Swear To God, Doc, I just don't know."

Wyatt said: "Doc..."
Doc said: "Don't touch me, God damn it!  Just Don't touch me!  Come on..."

Wyatt said: "What makes a man like Ringo, Doc? What makes him do the things he does?"
Doc said: "A man like Ringo's got a great Empty hole right through the Middle of him and no matter what He does he can't ever fill it.  He Can't kill enough or steal enough Or inflict enough pain to ever Fill it.  And it drives him mad. Sick mad.  Cold and dirty."
Wyatt said: "So what does he want?"
Doc said: "What does he want?  He wants revenge."
Wyatt said: "Revenge?  For what?"

Doc said: "I'm sorry.  I'm sorry, Wyatt.  God, I'm so sorry."
Wyatt said: "That's all right, Doc.  Don't worry."
Doc said: "Never got to wear one of those."

Doc said: "Well hell, Wyatt.  Wyatt, I want You to meet Father Feeney.  Father Feeney's just been initiating me Into the mysteries of the great And ancient Church of Rome.  You See, it appears my hypocrisy Knows no bounds."
Wyatt said: "How you feelin', Doc?"
Doc said: "Rather an obvious question under The circumstances, don't you Agree?  A better one might be how Do you feel?"
Wyatt said: "Hurts.  Hurts pretty bad."
Doc said: "I imagine it would, yes.  So now We can add self-pity to your list Of frailties."
Wyatt said: "All right, Doc..."
Doc said: "You think I'm kidding.  You're the Most fallible, wrong-headed, self- Deluding, just generally Benighted jackass I've ever Known.  Yet, withal, even at your Worst, you're the only human Being in my entire life who ever Gave me hope."
Wyatt said: "All I ever wanted was to live a Normal life."
Doc said: "When will you wake up?  You Wouldn't know a normal life if it Bit you in the ass."
Wyatt said: "That's great coming from you."
Doc said: "I played the cards I was dealt, Wyatt.  Your problem is you're Always trying to play someone Else's.  Allow me to tell you the Truth and thus set you free: There is no happiness, Wyatt There is no normal life.  There's Only life, that's all.  Just life. The rest is relative."
Wyatt said: "Then what do I do?"
Doc said: "First you can grab that black- Haired woman and make her your own."
Wyatt said: "All right.  Then what?"
Doc said: "Run.  Take that girl and start Running.  Run and don't look back. All your life you been running And looking back and just barely Existing and calling it getting By.  This time run and don't look Back and call it living.  Live Every second, live it right up to The hilt.  Live, Wyatt...  Live for me."

High Roller said: "Hey, is that "Old Dog Tray"? Sounds like "Old Dog Tray"."
Doc said: "What?"
High Roller said: "You know, Stephen Foster.  "Oh, Susanna".  "Camptown Races", Stephen-stinkin'-Foster!"
Doc said: "I see, well this happens to be a Nocturne."
High Roller said: "A which?"
Doc said: "You know, Frederic-fucking-Chopin."

Vermillion said: "Drunks.  Crawfished a bet, called Him a liar.  I saw the whole thing."
Doc said: "Sheriff, may I present a pair of Fellow sophisticates, Turkey Creek Jack Johnson and Texas Jack Vermillion?  Watch your ear, Creek."

Doc said: "Don't touch me!"
Vermillion said: "Sorry..."

Vermillion said: "You really look awful."
Doc said: "Not half as bad as I feel."
Vermillion said: "Then why in hell're you doin' This?  You ought to be in bed."
Doc said: "Wyatt Earp is my friend."
Vermillion said: "Hell, I got lot's of friends."
Doc said: "I don't."

Doc said: "I don't believe it.  He's clean!"
Vermillion said: "What?  But I saw 'em-"
Doc said: "I'm telling you, there isn't a Mark on him."

High Roller said: "All right, I'm on fire!  Black Seven, seven stickin' spades. Let's go!"
Wyatt said: "I'm your man...  You win again.  Well played, sir. You are on fire."
High Roller said: "Told you.  I'm red hot, I'm Blazin'!  Now, red seven.  Seven Stinkin' diamonds.  Look out!  Five Thousand!  Let's go!"
Wyatt said: "Awful lot of money."
High Roller said: "Can't take the heat, get outta The kitchen."
Wyatt said: "You're the doctor.  sad news, friend."
High Roller said: "Damn!  All right, wait a minute..."

Johnson said: "Hello, Wyatt!  Hiya Doc!"
Wyatt said: "What was that all about?"

Johnson said: "Are you out of your mind?  What on Earth'd make us-"
Wyatt said: "I'll pay you 500 each in advance And I'll mount you on those."

Johnson said: "Maybe you ought to have a talk With Doc, Wyatt.  I don't know if He's gonna make it."
Wyatt said: "There's no reasoning with him."

Wyatt said: "No."
Johnson said: "What?"
Wyatt said: "No."

Wyatt said: "See how she breezed out of here. Like she had wings.  Funny thing But I can't really remember how She looked.  I can remember parts Of her clear as crystal, her Mouth, her walk, how she shut her Eyes when she laughed, little Bits and pieces, but not the Whole package.  Can't put it Together for some reason."
Johnson said: "Good God, you're really-"
Wyatt said: "Cards in spades.  I'm in love with Every second of her life.  Hell, I'll probably love her when I'm dust."

Wyatt said: "You tell Ringo... just tell him I'll be there."
Johnson said: "Wyatt, are you crazy?"
Wyatt said: "I made a promise."

Wyatt said: "But I'd do it, I'd get that one Into him.  So help me God, I would."
Johnson said: "All right Wyatt, maybe you can. But you gotta die to do it. Understand?  You gotta die!"

Johnson said: "Wyatt, I... I ain't got the words."
Wyatt said: "I know.  Me neither."

Wyatt said: "All right, what's it to be?  New Mexico's that way."
Johnson said: "Colorado's closer"
Wyatt said: "So're the Cowboys.  They're up That road right now, waiting to Jump us."

Johnson said: "There they go.  Look kinda like preachers."
Vermillion said: "Yeah.  Or undertakers."

Vermillion said: "You know, we might just pull this off."
Johnson said: "Not so sure.  Somethin' tells me It gets harder from here in.  Should've held out for more money."

Vermillion said: "Yeah, better run, you bastards!"
Johnson said: "How is he?"

Vermillion said: "Hey Creek, you ever see anything Like that before?"
Johnson said: "Never even heard of anything like it."

Vermillion said: "Wyatt, listen, you can't beat Him.  You're good and God knows You got the courage, but you Ain't in Ringo's class.  Hell, He's the best that's ever been. 'Cept maybe for Wild Bill."
Johnson said: "He's right, Wyatt.  Ringo could Put five into you before you Could even get one into him."

Vermillion said: "Praise Jesus!"
Johnson said: "I'll be dipped in shit.  I will, too."

Vermillion said: "We're the law, ain't we?  Well the Law don't ride around vermin-"
Johnson said: "It rides right at 'em.  Like McMasters said, see it through to The end."

Wyatt said: "We've never actually met.  My Name's-"
Josephine said: "Wyatt Earp, I know.  I was Beginning to think we'd never Meet.  This is fortuitous.  That Means lucky."
Wyatt said: "I know what it means."

Josephine said: "What is it?"
Wyatt said: "Easy now... That mare's in season."
Josephine said: "Oh...  Now she's starting.  How do they know?"
Wyatt said: "They know.  It's the scent.  We Better split 'em up."
Josephine said: "I have a better idea, let's run It out of them!"

Josephine said: "That was lovely!"
Wyatt said: "You know you almost got us both Killed back there?"
Josephine said: "Fun though, wasn't it?"
Wyatt said: "You'd die for fun?"
Josephine said: "Wouldn't you?  You're laughing!  I Was sure you never laughed."
Wyatt said: "I laugh sometimes"
Josephine said: "Yes, but how often?  Tell me, are You happy?"
Wyatt said: "Am I happy?  I don't know.  Happy As the next man, I guess.  I don't Laugh all day long like an idiot, If that's what you mean."
Josephine said: "You're a little touchy about it."
Wyatt said: "I'm not touchy, I just, it's a Silly question, that's all.  Am I Happy?  Are you happy?"
Josephine said: "Of course, I'm always happy. Unless I'm bored.  That blonde Woman, is that your wife?"
Wyatt said: "What about her?"
Josephine said: "Nothing... Tell me, what do you Want out of life?"
Wyatt said: "Where do you get these questions?"
Josephine said: "Just answer."
Wyatt said: "I don't know, make some money, Have some kids, you know."
Josephine said: "Doesn't suit you."
Wyatt said: "How would you know?"
Josephine said: "Just doesn't, that's all."
Wyatt said: "Well I ought to know my own mind And I'm tellin' you what suits me Is a family and kids.  That suits Me right down to the ground.  In Fact, that's my idea of heaven.  All right, what's your idea of heaven?"
Josephine said: "Room service."

Josephine said: "See?  You're laughing again.  But That's what I want.  Go places and Move and never look back and just Have fun.  Forever.  That's my idea Of heaven.  Need someone to share It with, though."
Wyatt said: "You mean Behan?  Then why are you with him?"
Josephine said: "Well he's handsome and he's Charming.  He's all right.  For Now.  Don't say it, I know, I'm Rotten.  I can't help it.  I've Tried to be good but it's too Boring."
Wyatt said: "The way you talk.  Never heard a Woman talk like that."
Josephine said: "Oh look, I haven't got time to be Proper, I want to live.  I'm a woman, I like men.  If that's Unladylike then I guess I'm not a Lady.  At least I'm honest."
Wyatt said: "Well you're different, no arguing That.  But you're a lady all right. I'll take my oath on it."

Josephine said: "What's wrong?"
Wyatt said: "I don't know, doesn't make any Sense.  I almost can't look at You.  Like it hurts."
Josephine said: "I know, me too.  What should we do About it?"

Josephine said: "You know this is adultery.  You Burn in hell for that."
Wyatt said: "Then let's make sure we get our Money's worth"

Josephine said: "I must say this certainly has Been an unexpected little Windfall."
Wyatt said: "Fortuitous even."

Josephine said: "And I don't even know your full name."
Wyatt said: "Easy to fix.  Wyatt Berry Stapp Earp."
Josephine said: "And I'm Josephine Sarah Marcus. My friends call me Josie."
Wyatt said: "Josie... No, I'm gonna call you Sadie."
Josephine said: "I hate Sadie."
Wyatt said: "Well you'll always be Sadie to me."
Josephine said: "Always?"
Wyatt said: "Getting late.  We better get back."

Josephine said: "So I assume we're regarding this As just a kind of interlude."
Wyatt said: "Look, it's too much of a tangle. I already cast my lot.  I can't go Back and I can't sneak, feel back Enough as it is."
Josephine said: "You feel bad about this?  About me?"
Wyatt said: "I didn't mean it that way."
Josephine said: "You know you don't have to sneak. You could stay with me.  I know Things, Wyatt.  Sweet things.  I Could make you so happy."
Wyatt said: "I can't, I'm sorry.  Forgive me."

Wyatt said: "No, no, get away, get away from me..."
Josephine said: "Wyatt..."

Wyatt said: "Sorry about your friend.  And I'm sorry about..."
Josephine said: "I forgave you the moment you said it."
Wyatt said: "You did.  Well... thank you."

Josephine said: "I have to go."
Wyatt said: "Wait!"

Josephine said: "Wyatt!  My God..."
Wyatt said: "Did you ever see the sun come up Over the Rockies?  It hits all of A sudden and below there's California and you swear you're Looking at heaven."

Wyatt said: "I have nothing left.  I have Nothing to give you.  I have no Pride, no dignity, no money.  I Don't even know how we'll make a Living.  But I promise I'll love You every second of your life."
Josephine said: "Don't worry, Wyatt.  My family's rich."

Joyce said: "What can I get you?"
Wyatt said: "Let me have one of those cigars.  Kinda nice in here.  You run it?"
Joyce said: "Milt Joyce, owner-operator."
Wyatt said: "Well, excuse me for askin', Milt, But isn't it kinda dead in here?"

Joyce said: "You see that bird at the faro Table?  That's Johnny Tyler.  He Barged in here one day, said he Was takin' over the game, started Slappin' customer, wavin' his Gun around, scarin' off all the High-class play.  Only trade comes In here now's just bummers and Drovers, just the dregs."
Wyatt said: "Why don't you get rid of him and Get yourself straight dealer?"
Joyce said: "Well sure, neighbor, easy to say."

Joyce said: "Those Cowboys're tellin' Everybody in town they're gonna Clean you out.  They're down in That lot right now behind the OK Corral."
Wyatt said: "Don't worry, Doc, it's not your problem. You don't have to mix up in this."

Mattie said: "Wyatt, I couldn't find a single Store that had laudanum any-"
Wyatt said: "Mattie, they're here!  Folks this Is Celia Ann but you can call her Mattie.  Or even Mrs.  Earp if you Prefer."

Wyatt said: "Come up to the fire, honey."
Mattie said: "I think I'll just lie down awhile"

Mattie said: "Long as I live I'll never Get used to that sound."
Wyatt said: "They're just lonely is all.  Hell, I howl myself sometimes."
Mattie said: "You get lonely?"

Mattie said: "No, stay.  Please stay with me."
Wyatt said: "Honey, I gotta start makin' money."
Mattie said: "Oh, all right."
Wyatt said: "Well I guess I don't have to go Right now.  I guess I could stay a little while."
Mattie said: "No, no, I don't want to keep you."
Wyatt said: "No really, I can stay a while."
Mattie said: "Just go.  It's all right.  Wyatt, Really.  Work well."
Wyatt said: "All right, well, good night."

Wyatt said: "That the bottle Lou gave you? Better go easy on that stuff."
Mattie said: "I know what I'm doing.  Where have You been?"
Wyatt said: "Out ridin'.  So... how you doin'?"
Mattie said: "I don't know.  I'm all right."
Wyatt said: "Really?  You sure?"
Mattie said: "Sure I'm sure.  What is this?"

Wyatt said: "Well, I was thinking, we've Already made a pile of money. Maybe we should just pull up Stakes and move on.  And we could Stay on the move, you know?  Just Keep going, see the world.  Live On room service the rest of our Lives.  How'd that be?"
Mattie said: "Wyatt, what're you talkin' about?"
Wyatt said: "Just thinkin' out loud.  Forget it."

Mattie said: "Thought you swore you'd never Carry that thing again."
Wyatt said: "Yeah, well, I swore a lot of things."

Wyatt said: "Mattie.  What about this?"
Mattie said: "I need it."
Wyatt said: "'Least you admit it."
Mattie said: "Admit what, I'm an opium fiend? No, Wyatt, I just said I need it. I need something to keep me warm At night."
Wyatt said: "Look, Mattie, I know you're-"
Mattie said: "You know nothing.  What you don't Know would fill a book.  Jesus, I Feel like it's when you're around I need it most.  You're never Yourself, you never relax.  Never. Everything's so stiff and dead. You always have to keep a rein on Everything, ever yourself.  Oh, You smile sometimes, I've even Seen you laugh.  But there's no Light in your smile for me, Wyatt, nothing to keep me warm. And I get cold, Wyatt.  I get so cold.  What's between you and that Jew woman?"

Wyatt said: "All right, look.  I can make it Right, I can make this up to you, Mattie.  I can, I swear."
Mattie said: "Will you go to her and tell her Right in front of me she's Nothing to you?  Right out loud so I can hear?  Tell her she's Nothing, tell her she's nobody, Just dirt?  Will you do that?"

Ringo said: "Well hello, Sherm."
Mcmasters said: "You wanted to talk?"
Ringo said: "Yeah, kinda, wanted to see if you'd join back up with us."
Mcmasters said: "That what you got me up here for?"
Ringo said: "You're a Cowboy, you're a Brother.  Come back, no hard Feelings."
Mcmasters said: "Forget it, Ringo."
Ringo said: "Isn't there anything I can say That'll change your mind?  You're Gonna stay with your new friends?"
Mcmasters said: "'Least they don't scare women."
Ringo said: "You're the boss.  One thing, though."

Mcmasters said: "Run for your lives, boys!  It's That great two-gun dog-catcher From Kansas!"
Wyatt said: "McMasters, isn't it?  Listen, you Seen a black stallion with-"
Mcmasters said: "Look, I got a rule.  I don't talk To lawmen.  Dog-catchers neither."
Wyatt said: "I'm not a lawman, I'm just a Private citizen getting' my Property back"
Mcmasters said: "Well in that case, I saw your Horse.  Billy Clanton was takin' Him up to the Cut to show him Off.  The boys're all up there Right now, branding.  And in a Mood.  Still want your property Back, Mr. Private Citizen?"

Wyatt said: "So what about you Cowboys anyway?"
Mcmasters said: "If I had to explain it you Wouldn't understand.  Just say We're brothers to the bone."
Wyatt said: "Yeah, but some of the things they Say your brothers've done..."
Mcmasters said: "There's all kinds of horses, Ain't there?  Same with Cowboys. What they do's their affair.  I Don't preach and I don't judge.  I Ain't no dog-catcher."

Mcmasters said: "No, wait.  Please.  I know nothin' I say'll fix things but I want You to know it wasn't me."
Wyatt said: "No?  Brothers to the bone, right?"
Mcmasters said: "Not anymore, not after this."

Mcmasters said: "I ain't your brother, I ain't None of your damn brothers.  Move!"
Wyatt said: "All right, run 'em off."

Mcmasters said: "Florentino!  He's getting away!"
Wyatt said: "Drop his horse."

Wyatt said: "I know that cut.  You mean there's A waterhole near there?"
Mcmasters said: "But this time they'll be ready."
Wyatt said: "We'll see about that."

Mcmasters said: "What'd you do that for?"
Wyatt said: "So he can tell the story."

Mcmasters said: "Next waterhole's Black Draw.  We Could be there by mid-morning."
Wyatt said: "They're wise by now.  Which is Next, Iron Springs?  Yeah, let's Try there, Iron Springs."

Mcmasters said: "There they are.  No herd though."
Wyatt said: "We'll go around that way, come up on foot."

Wyatt said: "I don't like it."
Mcmasters said: "Might as well hear him out. Anyways, what choice we got?  But no matter what happens, see It through to the end.  If you don't I'll curse the day I ever laid eyes on you."

Babe Brother said: "This is what it is all about, trying to keep from being out on the street."
Junior said: "Robert asks about you. When are you going to do something to help him?"

Suzie said: "I've heard some foolish things in my life."
Babe Brother said: "Harry is coming to pick me up."
Suzie said: "Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling."
Babe Brother said: "I'm busy."
Suzie said: "Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction."
Babe Brother said: "Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be."
Suzie said: "I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough.  You sit right there with your no manners self."

Babe Brother said: "Did you ever have to use this thing?"
Harry said: "That is called a crab apple switch. It's for those bad acting monkeys and just the thing for a mean dog. Now I don't know if I actually did what I did or got my life and story mixed in with other folk's stories but I seem to recall that I had to use my crab apple on a boy from back home. I was up in Memphis working on the railroad, like your daddy who had an easy job. He would sing a song that had a cadence and we would lay track. Anyway I was coming down Beale Street and I heard this music coming from a saloon. Sure enough it was Emory. My daddy taught both of us to play but Emory was natural at it. Got in a blues band and what not. He and another boy had killed a boy named Hocker sometime back and they balled the Jack leaving town. Emory had lost one eye and had a scar running down his face. Bad luck I would say. He got to drinking that corn liquor. We went to his girl's room and he wouldn't stop drinking. He started talking about the old days and he went mad. He pulled his knife and I got to mine first. The lights went out."

Babe Brother said: "Don't pick up the cards if you are not in the game. Did he die?"
Harry said: "I don't know what happened to him. He just ran out into the streets.  I got some old records I want you to hear. I like the blues sung simply, man and a guitar. Or sung by a woman who had bad luck all her life. Don't ever let anyone tell you his life's story if it is of a weary life full of sadness. When I was a boy, a man told me a story of how he lost all of his sons and I'll be damned if the same thing didn't happen to me."

Babe Brother said: "What is that?"
Harry said: "Boy, that is the real South. That is real corn liquor."

Harry said: "Never play with someone's else's cards. You always get a new deck. Look at this card. See anything?"
Babe Brother said: "It is just a regular card."
Harry said: "Son, I can take everything you got with that deck. It is marked. Now I'm going to show you how to make some money in case you get stuck somewhere."

Harry said: "Son, would you do me a favor and see if you could turn off that tap in the bathroom. My hand is too weak. And would you do me another favor? I don't like asking this but would you clean the tub for me? I have trouble bending over."
Babe Brother said: "Anytime you need someone to do something for you, just let me know."

Babe Brother said: "I could swear I heard my son call me."
Harry said: "You probably heard the wind stirring up those dead leaves over there."
Babe Brother said: "I heard his voice as clear as day. I better get back. Maybe something is wrong."

Harry said: "I don't want to wear out welcome, but you can stay in someone's heart longer than you can stay in their house. Come with us, boy. We are going to have a good time."
Babe Brother said: "This would be a bad time for me to leave."
Harry said: "We are going where the action is. Ain't that right, Okra?  Let's play for a couple of bucks unless you want to start off with two bits and work our way up.  What would you give to be rich?"

Davis said: "You know it is against the city ordinance to keep chickens or live stock."
Gideon said: "I always had chickens, ducks and whatnots."
Davis said: "Not anymore, not in the city."
Gideon said: "We grow most of our own food. The money I get from social security, my pension and my wife's work, keeps us living on the edge. What choice do people like us have."
Davis said: "Well, you just have to move further out."
Gideon said: "Now how far would further out be?"
Davis said: "I'm not here to argue, sir."

Gideon said: "My mind plays tricks on me. Is it okay if I take a bath now?"
Suzie said: "Everyone is gone. Rhonda is in the bathroom."

Gideon said: "Babe Brother and his wife are taking advantage of a situation. I hate to be mean to people but picking Sunny up when they feel like it has to come to an end. Now I'm going to ask him how come he couldn't be at your birthday."
Suzie said: "Don't bother the poor boy. It just takes some people a little longer to figure out who they are."
Gideon said: "I don't know how two brothers can be so different."

Suzie said: "Let us settle this tomorrow."
Gideon said: "Look! Don't try to get ahead by riding our backs."

Gideon said: "Your feet are cold."
Suzie said: "Go back to sleep."
Gideon said: "I asked you to wake me when Babe Brother comes."
Suzie said: "You all act like two roosters."
Gideon said: "I'm not going to let him get away with murder."
Suzie said: "You and Babe Brother are so much alike..."
Gideon said: "He ain't nothing like me. How come a man has to have sons that are day and night apart? You ought to stop protecting him."
Suzie said: "Hush."
Gideon said: "You're always taking his side."
Suzie said: "Hush."
Gideon said: "I'm trying to make him a man but you keep babying him."
Suzie said: "You're going to find yourself on the floor."

Suzie said: "You know, Babe Brother's wife just dumps greens in the pot without washing them."
Gideon said: "Babe Brother is a poor boy."

Gideon said: "Well, it's up to Suzie."
Suzie said: "It would be nice."

Suzie said: "Do you want your coat? It's cold out here."
Gideon said: "No, I'm too hot now."
Suzie said: "You better be careful. You'll get a stroke arguing."
Gideon said: "I wouldn't care if I drop dead if he learn something from it.  Son, you make me wish I was dead."
Suzie said: "Gideon, don't say things like that."

Gideon said: "Let us go back in before the night of celebration becomes a night of me killing my son."
Suzie said: "No. Before anyone moves, you two shake hands and don't carry it any further."

Gideon said: "I'm worn out."
Suzie said: "Just stay in bed and rest."
Gideon said: "I have to feed the chickens before they wake everybody up."
Suzie said: "You stay inside. I will see to them."
Gideon said: "I will appreciate that."

Gideon said: "It's good to be able to hear that."
Suzie said: "You must have been really sick."
Gideon said: "How is the garden doing?"
Suzie said: "I need to get out there and get those weeds out."
Gideon said: "How is that hen doing? I was meaning to pip her before I fell sick."

Gideon said: "What, are you having another party?"
Suzie said: "You better come sit down. You are still sick."
Gideon said: "Gal, you're talking to John Henry. When was I sick?"

Suzie said: "Since this morning."
Gideon said: "What happened to your hand?"
Suzie said: "I cut it on an old rusty knife."

Gideon said: "What did you put on it?"
Suzie said: "It's healing now."

Gideon said: "He's going to check out heaven first. He gets a round trip ticket to heaven. He gets in heaven and finds it just like back home. People dripping with sweat, working in the fields, hardly surviving. He asked a man who was getting a drink of water, "I thought the streets were paved with gold." "They are but you won't see them," he said. "Boy, you got to work day and night cause idleness is sinfulness." So he takes the other half of his ticket and takes the express to hell. He sees people stretched out on their backs kicking back, picking their teeth. "Man, this is a dream." He asked, "What's you'll doing?" They all hollered back, "Sinning." The devil was shaking hands with everyone and came up to him and said, "Please to meet you." He asked, "I thought you'll was supposed to be burning in fire." Someone said, "Man, ain't no fire down here except under that pot of chitlins." The man was going go ask the preacher back on earth..."
Suzie said: "I don't want to hear any joke about colored people being in hell. You're being irreverent."
Gideon said: "I'm almost finished. I'm about to come to the punch line."
Suzie said: "I don't want to hear any tales about colored people..."
Gideon said: "But these are white people, anybody. The punch..."
Suzie said: "I don't care to hear any jokes about people being in hell. This cut on my hand reminds me that it is nothing to laugh at."
Gideon said: "It's only a tale."

Gideon said: "This is my grandson, Sunny. He is my youngest son's child."
Harry said: "He kind of favors one of my boys when he was about his age."

Harry said: "Boy, that is bad luck to touch a fellow with a broom."
Gideon said: "He knows better. Sunny, apologize to Harry."

Harry said: "I came all the way from Detroit by bus going to Oakland. The bus stopped in Los Angeles. I had to get off and take a rest. I'll catch the last bus leaving at midnight. I'm just too tired to go on."
Gideon said: "Why didn't you catch a plane?"
Harry said: "My feet have never been on anything that wasn't directly attached to the ground."
Gideon said: "Stay until you feel better? I would like to hear all the news."
Harry said: "I'm worn out but won't you feel like you are taking in a stranger?"

Gideon said: "Man, put your boxes down and stay as long as you like. We have empty rooms since the boys got their own families and moved out."
Harry said: "Well if you're sure, I won't be a bother. Oh, I don't sleep on no spring mattress. I always make myself a pallet on the floor."

Gideon said: "Man, act like this is your home."
Harry said: "That's awful generous of you. I always ask to keep from wearing out welcome."

Gideon said: "It's the boy next door throwing at his birds. I'm just waiting on him to hit a pane in the window"
Harry said: "I'm going to wash up now. You all please excuse me."

Harry said: "Good morning."
Gideon said: "You ought to come hear our preacher. Remember old Cat Iron? Well, our preacher is just as strong."
Harry said: "Next time when I feel a little better perhaps."
Gideon said: "I was going to get up and get a hen out there for dinner, but time got away."
Harry said: "Oh, I would feel much at home if you let me get one for you. I haven't wrung a chicken's neck in a month of Sundays. You know, folks would call my daddy to kill their hogs. That used to be my trade from time to time."
Gideon said: "Well, I would appreciate that."

Harry said: "How often is your wife called to help delivery?"
Gideon said: "It was slow. Now it seems like everyone is having births at home."

Gideon said: "What could have caused this? I just changed this damn thing."
Harry said: "Everything these days is made overseas."
Gideon said: "You and Babe Brother hit it off so well."
Harry said: "Course, it is your business, but I feel obliged to tell you that maybe you have not been fair with the boy."
Gideon said: "I tried to teach him right from wrong just like I did his Junior."
Harry said: "Everyone has to follow his own plough. A man doesn't have to know how to cut a wick and clean a chimney nowadays. City people don't give a hoot and a holler about the shape of the moon nowadays. You don't plant old ways...  ... but, at the end, you find yourself doing what your father did but you have to have the land in you.  It's when you want to give the house or farm to the kids and they don't want it. You sell it to a stranger. You worked your whole life, for what?  I doubt if people nowadays have knowledge of a victory garden or seen an inch worm. All what we've experienced has no meaning."
Gideon said: "You're suppose to teach your children what you know. Junior, I don't have to worry about. Babe Brother is a different story."
Harry said: "You still call him boy. You call Babe Brother boy in front of his wife and son."
Gideon said: "My daddy called me boy up to the time he died. I was always boy to him."
Harry said: "'Course, you could be right. Your sons are alive. All my sons are dead."

Gideon said: "Haven't the years been good to Hattie?"
Harry said: "It hasn't been the years; it's been the men in her life."

Harry said: "Boy, I thought you were about to cross the river."
Gideon said: "I tell you, I feel like a ghost."

Suzie said: "Stranger my foot, it was my grandmother who helped you into this world."
Harry said: "Well, I don't want to put you out."

Harry said: "Good evening. It must be all the different time zones I crossed that makes me feel this weary."
Suzie said: "You should go back and rest."
Harry said: "No, if I rest any longer, I won't sleep tonight. May I use your bathroom to wash up a bit?"

Suzie said: "One can tell you are from back home. These people nowadays don't know what manners are."
Harry said: "Where we come from, you had to know how to act right. You had to know how to say yes sir and no sir. You had to know your place."

Suzie said: "Those days you could always find something redeeming about even the worst person."
Harry said: "You remember that boy who lost his mind, Joe? You could hear him pitching horseshoes at night in the dark. He wouldn't miss a one. Make him mad and call yourself running in the house to be safe. He would pick up a brick and say "go on in there brick and hit somebody" and it would find its mark."
Suzie said: "I was afraid to go to Marcus Bottom because of him."
Harry said: "All those places that us coloreds lived, that we used to call Bottoms, have all been changed to Drives and Heights. Everything is in what you call it, not in what it is."

Suzie said: "I have someone I want you to meet."
Harry said: "I'll be right there."

Suzie said: "Harry, you know everything."
Harry said: "You got to know everything, do everything, and be everything."

Harry said: "What's the problem here?"
Suzie said: "She has a fish bone caught in her throat. Could all of you go in the other room? Gideon, get some bread and toast it quickly and find me the cod liver oil."

Harry said: "How is everybody?"
Suzie said: "Tolerable well."

Harry said: "Ah, you young folks don't know how it is. How is Gideon today?"
Suzie said: "He wasn't able to get out of bed today."
Harry said: "I hope that it's nothing serious."
Suzie said: "He has never gotten rid of the malaria. He is usually up and at it the next day. I'm going to make him fresh chicken broth."
Harry said: "Let me earn my keep. I'll go out and get a hen and have it picked and ready for the pot. Try to make him some cow tea next time."

Suzie said: "Can you watch Gideon for a while? One of the girls is going into labor. Junior is going to drive me over."
Harry said: "You just run along. I'll fix him his soup. He will be all right."

Harry said: "That smells like fresh coffee."
Suzie said: "Let me get you a cup?"
Harry said: "Only if you can spare it."

Harry said: "How is he doing?"
Suzie said: "As long as he keeps his throat clear, he is able to get some rest."
Harry said: "I made a fresh pot of coffee. Okra and I thought you need a rest. I'll stand guard. Okra wants to talk to you anyway."

Harry said: "Good afternoon, ladies."
Suzie said: "Good afternoon to you."

Harry said: "As God is my witness, I have never done anything to that woman."
Suzie said: "You must have done something to her."
Harry said: "Since she has repented, all she does is throw stones."
Suzie said: "Hattie is a different person now."
Harry said: "I don't make no bones about where I'm going to spend eternity. I have always been wild and you know that. If you are made to feel half a man, what do you think the other half is?"
Suzie said: "I'm glad you brought that up as to who you are. I have to know who is in my house."
Harry said: "You invited me."
Suzie said: "Only if you are a good man, a friend. Are you a friend?"

Marsh said: "There is something that I always wanted to know. Tell me, how did those boys die?"
Harry said: "Now who are we talking about?"
Marsh said: "Miss Clara's boy, Emory, to start with. The Johnson's Hocker was another one..."
Harry said: "Wasn't Hocker lynched?"
Marsh said: "You know as well as I do that it was made to look like he was lynched. Now who would hang someone from a persimmon tree?"
Harry said: "What difference does it make if it's persimmon, oak tree or huckleberry bush?"

Marsh said: "Hocker's death almost caused a race riot. A lot of innocent people could have been hurt behind that."
Harry said: "Strange as it may seem, it might have cleared the waters. Sometimes the right action comes from the wrong reason."

Harry said: "I think if anybody had a hand in killing Hocker, you ought to ask or you should have asked Emory and Chick."
Marsh said: "Chick was outright killed by a mob. He killed a white man that owed him some money and when they caught up with him, they tied him behind a car and dragged him from out of the hills back to town."
Harry said: "Those boys never did have good luck."
Marsh said: "You damn right they didn't, especially Emory, my cousin."
Harry said: "Emory had made a lot of enemies. He had a big mouth."

Harry said: "A woman in family way just reminds of spring and my younger days."
Pat said: "That's nice."
Harry said: "Well, you and your husband are special. Ya, Gideon tells me you do volunteer work to help feed the poor."

Harry said: "How many people do you all feed?"
Pat said: "Last Saturday we handed out over two hundred meals."
Harry said: "Good God Almighty, bless your bones.  But the problem grows."
Pat said: "Week by week the crowds at the door keeps getting larger. We can't feed all the hungry."
Harry said: "Of course not. Have you ever heard of a man jumping in the river to save five hundred drowning people? No you ain't.  You have to take just one and fatten him up. When you spread help too thin, you , you just nickel and dime the situation. If you try to save all, all die but if you save one life, life goes on. You just have to remember, medicine that works leaves a bitter taste."

Pat said: "I don't know if we could take one in with Rhonda and me at home alone at times."
Harry said: "Oh, I wasn't pointing my finger at you. Hey, you have to think of yourself. A lot of them have all kinds of diseases and will cut your throat while you sleep. There are too many bad people out there."

Hattie said: "I couldn't believe it when Suzie called and said you were staying here. How have you been?"
Harry said: "Girl, do you still sing and dance?"
Hattie said: "No, I'm a different person now, Harry."

Hattie said: "Harry, that's not nice. I'm in church now."
Harry said: "Why run out and close the barn door when the horse is gone? I remember when you weren't saved. That was way back yonder when the Natchez Trace was just a dirt road."
Hattie said: "Some people grow up and change their ways."
Harry said: "I know your mother ain't still operating that house of hers."
Hattie said: "My mother passed on years ago."

Hattie said: "None of your business."
Harry said: "That is a boy from home, Lulla's brother."

Hattie said: "You know the saying, "your heart is in your left hand.""
Harry said: "Now I was trying to be nice, to make conversation, since we go back some."
Hattie said: "I was quoting from the Bible. If the shoe fits, wear it."
Harry said: ""Out of weariness, I spoke to my own heart; to leave it all and to die. And I gave my heart to know madness and folly.""

Hattie said: "An empty wagon makes a lot of noise and you, tappy head, you ain't worth the salt you put in greens."
Harry said: "Speaking of tappy heads, we ought to have an old fashion fish fry."

Hattie said: "Is this your house?"
Harry said: "Oh. I'm sorry. Gideon, what do you say?"

Hattie said: "In the meantime Harry can slaughter us a hog."
Harry said: "I already have, my dear."

Junior said: "I appreciate you lending me a hand. That lazy ass brother of mine was suppose to help me."
Harry said: "Well some folks are still waiting for their comeuppance. Don't take me wrong but you can't judge people by how you act. You're a caring person."
Junior said: "He should be caring. That is not too much to ask."
Harry said: "Ya, but you can't do the shuffle with one leg. You and your wife, in your spare time, work with the less fortunate. Now I'm not talking about you and what you do but some folks that always run to help the victim, deep down are attracted to pain and suffering and love to be near the dying."
Junior said: "All the people working with us are really doing it 'cause they hate to see suffering."
Harry said: "You never know what's in the heart and just because you can cry doesn't make you human."

Linda said: "You don't act like the rest of Gideon's friends. They believe if you are not hard at work, you are hard at sin."
Harry said: "Oh, I'm more modern in my ways. I don't believe in sin, though there is good and evil.  And evil is a thing you work at."

Harry said: "Not you mustn't touch. Your mama might not like you handling knives."
Linda said: "I think he wants to see your rabbit foot."
Harry said: "I let this rabbit foot do in place of my toby that I lost years ago."
Linda said: "What's a toby?"
Harry said: "You don't want to be at crossroads without one. It's a charm that old people teach you how to make. I had one for a long time that belonged to my grandmother who had it ever since she was a child.  In my travels I misplaced it. I have been looking over my shoulder ever since."
Linda said: "I thought you weren't old fashioned."
Harry said: "In some things. When we were children, there used to be an old man that came around and would snatch your soul if you didn't have something on you that didn't make a X."

Harry said: "Did you have your child at home?"
Linda said: "No. No. No. No. I had my Child at Cedars and Sinai. And that ain't no county hospital. You have to have cash or check before you come in the door."
Harry said: "Some folks take that natural stuff too far."
Linda said: "Junior's wife kept her afterbirth' in the refrigerator. That's why I do not eat over there now."
Harry said: "Country people got so many strange ways,"

Suzie said: "No, but I might have some Indian Chief Tonic."
Hattie said: "I haven't heard anyone mention Swamp Root since button-up shoes went out."

Hattie said: "You know Harry lied about how that boy Hocker got kilt. And it was Harry who saw Emory last before they found him hanging over a levee like someone would hang a hog."
Suzie said: "I remember Harry always trying to help someone. He got Lulla's daughter out of trouble. He was always running to the store for someone who couldn't leave the house."
Hattie said: "Harry always shows his good side and, like the moon, the other side is black. Back home he always did try to act like the colored gentleman. I'm telling you Harry is nothing but evil. I'm warning you -- you can't keep a wild animal as a pet around children."

Suzie said: "You know Okra asked me to marry him the other evening."
Hattie said: "Rush your mouth, girl. No, he didn't. He cannot be that big of a damn fool."
Suzie said: "I asked Harry about it. He didn't own up to it. He said he didn't know what got into Okra."
Hattie said: "He's just raffish. Harry put him up to it. Before evening sun sets, I would have his belongings back on Route 55, that old fox."
Suzie said: "I can't accuse him just dry long 80."
Hattie said: "Everybody who have been associated with Harry end up with pennies over their eyes."
Suzie said: "What must I do?"
Hattie said: "If it was left up to me, I would poison him."

Junior said: "We can't really bring another family in here with us."
Pat said: "Why not? Harry says that's the only way to do good."
Junior said: "When did you talk to Harry?"
Pat said: "Don't shout!"

Pat said: "He just leeches off your parents. He is a master at wearing out welcome."
Junior said: "Harry is the kind of guy you would love to take out in the woods and leave under a rock."
Pat said: "Where does her get the power to summon all his old raffish friends? They all smell of moth balls."

Pat said: "Now you don't have to say anything if you don't want to."
Junior said: "I want to hear what happened. My brother is a jackass and a damn fool. The both of you have been as scarce as hen's teeth."

Pat said: "You shouldn't talk about the boy's father in front of him. This is family business and we have to pull together."
Junior said: "Whether the boy hears it or not, the man is still a jackass. Everyone should have some mother wit."

Mr. Baker said: "What are you doing?"
Mrs. Baker said: "Counting the gray hairs in your head."
Mr. Baker said: "Counting the what? What does that have to do with the price of butter?"
Mrs. Baker said: "I was just trying to make conversation."
Mr. Baker said: "Where is Skip?"
Mrs. Baker said: "He is in his pigeon cage."
Mr. Baker said: "I'm sorry he got those birds."
Mrs. Baker said: "You know the man next door is near death."

Suzie said: "How are you?"
Old John said: "Tolerably well. I brought you some more rabbit manure for your roses."
Suzie said: "It is so considerate of you."

Old John said: "I didn't mean for you to pay me for that."
Suzie said: "I know you didn't but you have been so thoughtful."
Old John said: "But when your sunflowers come up, I'll pay you for them."
Suzie said: "I planted a row just for you and you don't owe me anything."

Andy said: "Wow!  Cool!"
Mrs. Davis said: "Whadda ya think?"
Andy said: "Oh, this looks GREAT, Mom!"

Andy said: "Can we leave this up 'til we move?"
Mrs. Davis said: "Well, sure, we can leave it up."
Andy said: "Yeah!"
Mrs. Davis said: "Now go get Molly.  Your friends are going to be here any minute."
Andy said: "Okay."

Mrs. Davis said: "Come on down, guys.  It's time for games!  We've got prizes!"
Andy said: "Oh, yeah!"

Andy said: "To infinity and beyond!"
Mrs. Davis said: "Oh, all this packing makes me hungry.  What would you say to dinner at, uh, oh, Pizza Planet?"
Andy said: "Pizza Planet?!  Oh, cool!"

Andy said: "Can I bring some toys?"
Mrs. Davis said: "You can bring ONE toy..."
Andy said: "Just one?"

Andy said: "Mom!  Do you know where Buzz is?"
Mrs. Davis said: "No, I haven't seen him."

Mrs. Davis said: "Andy!  I'm heading out the door."
Andy said: "But Mom, I can't find him!"
Mrs. Davis said: "Well, honey, just grab some other toy!  Now c'mon!"
Andy said: "Okay..."

Andy said: "I couldn't find my Buzz.  I know I left him right there."
Mrs. Davis said: "Honey, I'm sure he's around. You'll find him."

Andy said: "Can I help pump the gas?"
Mrs. Davis said: "Sure!  I'll even let you drive."

Andy said: "Yeah?!"
Mrs. Davis said: "Yeah -- when you're sixteen."
Andy said: "Yuk, yuk, yuk -- funny, Mom."

Mrs. Davis said: "Next stop..."
Andy said: "Pizza Planet!  Yeah!!!"

Andy said: "Mom, have you seen Woody?"
Mrs. Davis said: "Where was the last place you left him?"
Andy said: "Right here in the van."
Mrs. Davis said: "Oh, I'm sure he's there.  You're just not looking hard enough."
Andy said: "He's not here, Mom.  Woody's gone."

Mrs. Davis said: "I looked everywhere, honey, but all I could find was your hat."
Andy said: "But what if we leave them behind?"
Mrs. Davis said: "Oh, don't worry, honey, I'm sure we'll find Woody and Buzz before we leave tomorrow."

Mrs. Davis said: "Everybody say, "Bye, house.""
Andy said: "Bye, house."

Andy said: "Hey!  Wow!"
Mrs. Davis said: "What?  What is it?"
Andy said: "Woody!  Buzz!"
Mrs. Davis said: "Oh, great, you found them.  Where were they?"
Andy said: "Here!  In the car!"
Mrs. Davis said: "See?  Now, what did I tell you? Right where you left them."

Andy said: "Which one can I open first?"
Mrs. Davis said: "Let's let Molly open one."

Woody said: "Aach! -- Oh, hi, Bo."
Bo Peep said: "I wanted to thank you, Woody, for saving my flock."
Woody said: "Oh, hey - it was nothing."
Bo Peep said: "Whadda ya say I get someone else to watch the sheep tonight?"
Woody said: "Heh, heh...oh yeah, uh, I..."
