Kirk said: "General Korrd's military strategies were required learning when I was a cadet at the Academy. When they put me out to pasture, I hope I fare better than Korrd."

Kirk said: "What is it? You look like you've seen a ghost."
Spock said: "Perhaps I have, Captain. Perhaps I have."

Kirk said: "Spock, what is it? Do you know this Vulcan?"
Spock said: "I cannot be certain."
Kirk said: "But he does seem familiar?"
Spock said: "He reminds me of someone I knew in my youth."

Spock said: "I do not often think of the past."
Kirk said: "Who is it he reminds you of?"
Spock said: "There was a young student, exceptionally gifted, possessing of great intelligence. It was assumed that one day he would take his place amongst the great scholars of Vulcan. But he was a revolutionary."
Kirk said: "What do you mean?"
Spock said: "The knowledge and experience he sought were forbidden by Vulcan belief."

Spock said: "He rejected his logical upbringing and embraced the animal passions of our ancestors."
Kirk said: "Why?"
Spock said: "He believed the key to self-knowledge was emotion, not logic."

Spock said: "When he encouraged others to follow him, he was banished from Vulcan, never to return."
Kirk said: "Fascinating."

Spock said: "Klingon vessel now entering quadrant. Bird of Prey. Estimating 1.9 hours until her weapons come to bear."
Kirk said: "Damn.  Let's go."

Spock said: "Their equipment is primitive but effective. I recommend we land at Coordinate 8563."
Kirk said: "That puts us pretty far away from Paradise City."
Spock said: "To land any closer would risk detection."
Kirk said: "Mr. Sulu. Execute."

Spock said: "At footspeed I estimate the journey to Paradise City at 1.2 hours."
Kirk said: "We don't have 1.2 hours."

Kirk said: "Spock."
Spock said: "Yes, Captain?"
Kirk said: "Be one with the horse."
Spock said: "Yes, Captain."

Spock said: "Exactly 15.5 seconds."
Kirk said: "An eternity during which we'll be vulnerable to Klingon attack. Korrd-you tell him."

Spock said: "You must allow us to act."
Kirk said: "Let me do something."

Kirk said: "Damnit, Spock. God damnit!"
Spock said: "Captain, what have I done -"
Kirk said: "What you have done is betray every man on this ship."
Spock said: "Worse. I have betrayed you. I do not expect you to forgive me."
Kirk said: "Forgive you? I ought to knock you on your goddamn ass!"
Spock said: "If you think it would help."

Kirk said: "You stay out of this!  Why, Spock? Why? I.. All you had to do was pull the trigger."
Spock said: "If I had pulled the trigger, Sybok would be dead."
Kirk said: "I ordered you to defend this ship."
Spock said: "You ordered me to kill my brother."
Kirk said: "Look, the man may be a fellow Vulcan, but that doesn't..."
Spock said: "No, no, no, Captain. You do not understand. Sybok also in a son of Sarek."

Kirk said: "You mean he's your brother brother?  You made that up!"
Spock said: "I did not."
Kirk said: "You did too. Sybok couldn't possibly be your brother because I happen to know for a fact that you don't have a brother."
Spock said: "Technically, you are correct. I do not have a brother."
Kirk said: "There, you see? See?"
Spock said: "I have a half brother."
Kirk said: "I gotta sit down."

Spock said: "Exactly. That is correct. Sybok's mother was a Vulcan princess. Upon her death, Sybok and I were raised as brothers."
Kirk said: "Why didn't you tell me this before?"
Spock said: "I was not disposed to discuss... matters of a personal nature. For that, I'm sorry."
Kirk said: "He's sorry, See, he's sorry. Everything... that makes everything all right. He's sorry, everything's..."

Kirk said: "There's got to be a way out of this place."
Spock said: "This is a new brig, Captain. It is escape-proof."
Kirk said: "How do you know?"
Spock said: "The designers tested it using the most intelligent and resourceful person they could find. He failed to escape."
Kirk said: "This, er, person... didn't by any chance have pointed ears and an unerring capacity for getting his shipmates into trouble, did he?"
Spock said: "He did have pointed ears."

Spock said: "Is it possible?"
Kirk said: "Is what possible?"
Spock said: "That he's found it. Sha Ka Ree. The reason Sybok left Vulcan."

Spock said: "There Sha Ka Ree is fabled to exist."
Kirk said: "But the center of the galaxy can't be reached. No ship has ever gone into the Great Barrier. No probe has ever returned."
Spock said: "Sybok possessed the keenest intellect I have ever known."
Kirk said: "Spock! My only concern is getting the ship back. When that's done and Sybok is in here then you can debate Sha Ka Ree until you're green in the face. Until then, you're either with me or you're not."
Spock said: "I am here, Captain."
Kirk said: "That's a little vague, Spock -"

Kirk said: "You're right. I'm a little out of practice.  Uh....that's an "s.""
Spock said: "A "t.""
Kirk said: ""a"... "n"...uh, "d"... end of word."

Kirk said: "New word. "b".. "a"... um..."
Spock said: ""c."... "k.""

Spock said: "There is an emergency sending apparatus in the forward observation room."
Kirk said: "The only problem is, it's up there. We're down here."

Spock said: "I believe I have found a faster way."
Kirk said: "Hmmm?"
Spock said: "Uh-uh."

Spock said: "It would appear we are too heavy."
Kirk said: "It must be all those marsh melons."

Kirk said: "Spock... the booster rockets."
Spock said: "If I activate them now, Captain, we will be propelled upward at an unbelievable rate."
Kirk said: "Fire the rockets!"

Kirk said: "Spock."
Spock said: "The emergency channel, open."
Kirk said: "To anyone within the sound of my voice: This is Captain James T. Kirk of the Federation Starship Enterprise. If you read me, acknowledge. Acknowledge."

Spock said: "...mark two."
Kirk said: "Mark two. Request emergency assistance. Acknowledge."

Kirk said: "Spock... don't."
Spock said: "It's all right, Captain.  Proceed."

Kirk said: "What is this?"
Spock said: "I believe we are witnessing my birth."

Kirk said: "Spock?"
Spock said: "Welcome aboard, Captain."

Kirk said: "Spock, I thought I was going to die."
Spock said: "Not possible. You were never alone."

Kirk said: "Maybe he's not out there, Bones. Maybe he's right here... in the human heart  Spock?"
Spock said: "I was thinking of Sybok. I've lost a brother."
Kirk said: "Yes. I lost a brother once. I was lucky. I got him back."

Sybok said: "I must have your starship."
Kirk said: "You staged all this to get your hands on my ship?"

Sybok said: "Who are you?"
Kirk said: "James T. Kirk, Captain of the Enterprise."
Sybok said: "But I thought Captain Chekov..  I see. Very clever, Captain.  Spock, it would appear that you've been given a second chance to join me. What do you say?"

Sybok said: "No! No reply. Remain on course."
Kirk said: "Sybok, listen to me. In order for this craft to enter the landing bay, Enterprise must lower the shields and activate the tractor beam. To get us inside and re-raise the shields will take-"

Sybok said: "What are you doing?"
Kirk said: "In order to lower and raise the shields as quickly as possible, we're going to forego the tractor beam and fly her in manually."

Sybok said: "We must change our course at once."
Kirk said: "I'll take you to the bridge."

Sybok said: "I trust your message was received?"
Kirk said: "You can't expect us to stand by while you take the ship into the Great Barrier."
Sybok said: "What you fear is the unknown. The people of your planet once believed their world was flat. Columbus proved it was round. They said the sound barrier could never be broken. It was broken. They said warp speed could not be achieved. The Great Barrier is the ultimate expression of this universal fear. It's an extension of personal fear.  Captain Kirk, I so much want your understanding. I want your respect. Are you afraid to hear me out?"
Kirk said: "I'm afraid of nothing."

Sybok said: "Sha Ka Ree. "The Scource." "Heaven." "Eden." call it "Qui'Tu." To the Romulans, it's "Vorta Vor." The Andorian word is.. unpronounceable. Still, every culture shares he common dream of a place from which creation sprang. For us, that place will soon be a reality."
Kirk said: "The only realty I see is that I'm a prisoner on my own ship. What is this power you have to control the minds of my crew?"
Sybok said: "I don't control minds. I free them."

Kirk said: "Spock...  What have you done to my friends?"
Sybok said: "I've done nothing. This is who they are. Didn't you know that?"

Kirk said: "No... I didn't."
Sybok said: "Now learn something about yourself."
Kirk said: "No. I refuse."

Kirk said: "Wait!  You know we'll never make it through the Great Barrier."
Sybok said: "But if we do, will that convince you that my vision was true?"
Kirk said: "Your vision?"
Sybok said: "Given to me by God.  He waits for us on the other side."
Kirk said: "You are mad!"
Sybok said: "Am I? We'll see."

Kirk said: "About the ship..."
Sybok said: "The ship needs its Captain."
Kirk said: "No special conditions?"
Sybok said: "No conditions."
Kirk said: "What makes you think I won't turn us around?"
Sybok said: "Because you, too, must know."

Sybok said: "What have I done?"
Kirk said: "Kirk to Enterprise. Listen carefully..."
Sybok said: "Spock..."

Blind Man said: "Hey!  You there!"
John said: "You want something, old man?"
Blind Man said: "Don't call me old man.  Ain't you got no respect, boy?"
John said: "You want something?"
Blind Man said: "Yeah I want something.  I want you to run over to that machine and get me a pop."
John said: "You can't do that yourself?"
Blind Man said: "Hell no, I can't do that myself. I'm blind.  Can't you see that?"
John said: "I'm sorry, I didn't--"
Blind Man said: "What'd you think I was doing out here with these glasses on?  Sunnin' myself?"
John said: "I don't know.  I thought you were keeping the sun from your eyes."
Blind Man said: "I ain't got no eyes.  You want to see?"
John said: "Christ no!"
Blind Man said: "Lost my eyes on Okinawa.  Lost them fighting the war.  Fought the war and lost my eyes just so you could come around here and make fun of me."
John said: "I said I was sorry."
Blind Man said: "Don't be sorry.  Just run over there and get me my pop before I die of thirst."
John said: "Yeah, sure.  You got change?"
Blind Man said: "Change?  You want my change?  I fought the war and lost my eyes just so I could give you my change?"
John said: "All right, old man.  Christ."

Blind Man said: "Get me a Dr. Peppa!  I don't want no Pepsi.  Pepsi ain't nothing but flavored water."
John said: "Yeah, yeah."

Blind Man said: "Don't forget to open it for me.  I can't be opening my own bottle."
John said: "Christ!"

John said: "I think you'd better give your pooch a sip.  He looks sick."
Blind Man said: "That's 'cause he's dead."

John said: "Oh, Jesus."
Blind Man said: "I hope you wasn't pettin' him none, was you?"
John said: "What the hell are you keeping a dead dog around for?"
Blind Man said: "He's only just dead.  What was I supposed to do with him?  I can't take him away anywhere.  And nobody wants to take him for me.  Do you?"
John said: "He no!"
Blind Man said: "See.  Ain't nothing I can do but keep him here beside me.  That's where he belongs anyways.  Me and Jesse, that's my dog, not anymore, but me and Jesse we been pals since the war when I lost my eyes.  He was just a pup then . . ."

John said: "You sure seen a lot for a blind man."
Blind Man said: "Just 'cause I ain't got eyes doesn't mean I can't see."
John said: "That a fact?"
Blind Man said: "I can see just fine.  For example: You're a young man who thinks he's got someplace to be."
John said: "Maybe I do."
Blind Man said: "Or maybe you just think you do.  You can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, there you are."
John said: "I think I've heard that before."
Blind Man said: "What do you want for free?"
John said: "You sure got a lot of philosophy, old man."
Blind Man said: "That's 'cause I've done a lot of living."
John said: "Maybe one day I'll get to sit on a corner and spout wise."
Blind Man said: "Think you'll live that long?"

Blind Man said: "Ain't you got a little something for the infirm?"
John said: "I'm a little short. I'll catch you next time."
Blind Man said: "I won't hold my breath."

John said: "The day wasn't so bad.  We all got through it all right."
Blind Man said: "Ain't over yet.  Night is part of day; separate, but equal.  Night is when you let your guard down; when you see things in the shadows and hear things in the dark."
John said: "You're a hell of a pessimist, old man."
Blind Man said: "Night is when you want to sleep, but the dry heat keeps you tossin' and turnin'.  It's when you wish the sun was bakin' high in the sky so you could see what it is you're afraid of."
John said: "You afraid of the dark?"
Blind Man said: "Afraid of it?  Boy, I live in the dark.  People are afraid of what they can't see.  I can't see nuthin', so it's all the same to me. Kiss from a beautiful woman, a lick from a dog.  The kiss of death. It's all the same."
John said: "You don't fear death?"
Blind Man said: "We was born to die, boy.  From the minute you take your first breath you got a death sentence hanging over your head.  You just don't know where, or when, or how.  Don't make sense worryin' about the particulars."
John said: "We're all just floating along like twigs in a stream, so enjoy the ride.  Is that it?"
Blind Man said: "More or less."
John said: "Not this twig, friend.  I got plans."
Blind Man said: "We all got plans.  I planned on seeing all my life.  I know you didn't plan on straying into town."
John said: "No and I don't plan on sticking around either.  I don't guess I'll be seeing you again.  Take it easy."
Blind Man said: "Same back at you."

John said: "Any parting words of wisdom?"

Grace said: "I picked them out for you, Jake.  I thought you would like the colors."
Jake said: "Uh-huh"

Jake said: "What the hell you looking at, girl?"
Grace said: "Nothing, Jake.  Absolutely nothing."

Grace said: "What's the matter?"
Jake said: "You didn't hear something?"
Grace said: "How could I?  I was sleeping."
Jake said: "There's someone in the house."
Grace said: "I don't hear anything.  You were dreaming.  Or maybe the wind blew something over."
Jake said: "The wind isn't blowing."

Grace said: "Jake, what is that?"
Jake said: "What does it look like?"
Grace said: "When did you buy a gun?"

Grace said: "Oh my God, Jake, no.  If it is someone they'll go away.  Or call the police.  Don't go out there."
Jake said: "What are you afraid of?  I'm the one's got the gun.  Stay here."
Grace said: "Jake.  No.  No!"

John said: "Can I give you a hand, beautiful?"
Grace said: "I'm just going to my car."
John said: "That's right on my way."

Grace said: "My mother told me never to accept offers from strangers."
John said: "My name is John.  Now I'm not a stranger anymore.  See how easy it is for us to get to know each other, beautiful?"
Grace said: "Do you have to call me that?"
John said: "I don't know your real name."
Grace said: "Maybe I don't want you to."
John said: "Maybe, but if you didn't I think you would have kept on walking."
Grace said: "You're pretty full of yourself, aren't you?"
John said: "My cup runneth over, beauti--"
Grace said: "It's Grace."
John said: "May I carry your package, Grace?"

John said: "Jesus."
Grace said: "You sure you can manage?"
John said: "I got it."
Grace said: "Do you want me to carry your pack for you?"

John said: "No, I've got it."
Grace said: "What happened to your hand?"
John said: "Accident."
Grace said: "You should be more careful."

Grace said: "It's very nice of you to help me. That package is kind of heavy, and it's so hot."
John said: "No trouble at all, really."

John said: "Wasn't nothing."
Grace said: "Oh, this isn't my car.  It's down a ways.  I should have parked closer. I just didn't think it would be so heavy.  I could drive up."
John said: "That's all right.  I got it."

John said: "It's nothing.  Really."
Grace said: "I just got tired of looking at the old drapes.  Had them long as I can remember."
John said: "That a fact?"
Grace said: "I saw these in the Penny's catalog, and I just knew I had to have them. You ever seen something and just knew you had to have it?"
John said: "Yes, I have."
Grace said: "'Course they cost a little more than I should really be spending.  But, damn it, I don't hardly ever do anything nice for myself.  I deserve nice things."
John said: "I . . . can't . . . argue . . ."

Grace said: "Thank you, John."
John said: "You're welcome, Grace."
Grace said: "You're not from around here, are you?"
John said: "Why you say that?  Just because I help a lady with her package?"
Grace said: "You don't have that dead look in your eyes like the only thing you live for is to get through the day."
John said: "I just drove in this morning."
Grace said: "Drove into Sierra?  What for?"
John said: "Didn't have a choice.  My car overheated up the road."
Grace said: "Good luck it didn't happen a few miles back.  Maybe they never would have found you.  Day like today you'd be dead for sure."
John said: "Yeah, my luck.  I get to be stuck out here in this hole in the desert."
Grace said: "Least you can leave."
John said: "Not until my car's fixed.  I don't know how long that's going to take."
Grace said: "And here I've made you all hot and sweaty."

Grace said: "Where you coming from?"
John said: "All over.  Chicago, Miami, Detroit. Just lately Albuquerque."
Grace said: "You've been around."
John said: "I guess I've got wander in my blood."
Grace said: "Where you headed?"
John said: "I don't know.  I have to make a stop in Vegas.  Business to finish.  Then maybe I'll head to Santa Barbara.  I might be able to pick up some work there."
Grace said: "You just travel around, no direction, no steady work.  You must like taking chances."
John said: "If you're going to gamble, might as well play for high stakes."
Grace said: "What happens if you lose?"
John said: "I pack up and go somewhere else."
Grace said: "Somewhere else.  I've never been anywhere else.  Just once.  Years ago.  Went to the state fair.  It was nice, but it wasn't nothing."
John said: "I couldn't stay in this place.  I wouldn't.  I'd just pick up, do whatever I had to do, and get out."

John said: "That's good.  Cools you right off.  I saw you watching me."
Grace said: "I'm sorry.  I didn't mean to."
John said: "I didn't say it bothered me."
Grace said: "Did you like it; me watching you?"
John said: "I guess.  I've got an ego same as any man."
Grace said: "Good, 'cause I liked what I saw."

John said: "Nice place you got here."
Grace said: "Thank you."

John said: "Must get kind of lonely for a woman living by herself in a big house."
Grace said: "I guess it must."
John said: "What do you do anyway?"
Grace said: "A little of this, a little of that. Mostly I tell fortunes."
John said: "Where'd you learn to do that?"
Grace said: "From my father.  He was the tribe's Shaman."
John said: "A medicine man?"
Grace said: "Those are white words, not ours."
John said: "Nice house for a Shaman's daughter. You must be good."
Grace said: "Come here."

John said: "My face tell you all that?"
Grace said: "It tells me what every face tells me.  Everybody has a past, they have a pain, and they have something they want.  What is it you want?"
John said: "The same thing you do."

Grace said: "There.  All done.  Lift me down."
John said: "What?"
Grace said: "Lift me down."

Grace said: "You can let go of me now.  I'm safe.  How do they look."
John said: "Like you."
Grace said: "Beautiful?"
John said: "Like they're made of polyester."
Grace said: "I like them.  I was sick of looking at this room.  I think they add a little life."
John said: "Nothing like a little liveliness."

Grace said: "No more drapes to hang.  Now what should we do?"
John said: "I have ideas."
Grace said: "Such as?"

John said: "All right, Grace.  No more games."
Grace said: "Games?"
John said: "You flirt with me, then you run cold.  You lead me on, then slap me down.  I don't go for being jerked around."
Grace said: "Really?  And what game did you want to play?  You carry my box for me, and I fall into bed with you?"

John said: "I think I can find my own way back to into town."
Grace said: "Maybe I like to find out about a man first.  Maybe I like to know what he's made of."
John said: "I'm just flesh and blood, baby. That and a few memories of bad women; just like most guys.  But you already know that.  You read my fortune.  Thanks for the lemonade."

Grace said: "You never did answer my question."
John said: "Still playing?"
Grace said: "That's not an answer.  What is it you want?"
John said: "You know what I want."
Grace said: "Maybe I just want to hear you say it."

John said: "Damn it, Grace!  Tell him."
Grace said: "If he says that's what happened, Jake, it must be true."

John said: "Doesn't the heat bother you?"
Grace said: "Yeah, but I like the sun.  I grew up on a reservation.  The sun, the desert; they were like a religion to us.  Jake's the same way.  He loves the desert.  I guess we're alike that way.  That's about the only way."
John said: "You love him?"
Grace said: "No."
John said: "Did you ever?"
Grace said: "Depends on what you call love.  When I was growing up I had nothing.  I learned to want everything.  I wanted more than Sierra anyway. Jake was my ticket.  He's not much; he's older than me, different than me, but he's got more money than half this town put together.  I courted him.  I let him think he was courtin' me, but I reeled him in like a fish on a line.  I wanted him.  I wanted what he could give me, and I would've done anything to get him.  Is that love?"
John said: "I'm guessing no."
Grace said: "Yeah, I guess you're right."
John said: "And I take it things didn't much work out the way you planned."
Grace said: "I'm still here, aren't I?  See this?"

Grace said: "All this nothing?  I've spent my life in this stinking desert.  It doesn't get to Jake like it got to me.  He doesn't mind being out here. He doesn't mind being nothing but a land broker.  Big fish in a small pond, he says.  More like a little fish in a dried up watering hole."
John said: "You could just leave him."
Grace said: "I don't know how."
John said: "You just walk away."
Grace said: "It's not that easy.  Maybe you can take chances; maybe you can wander around like some stray wherever you please.  I can't.  I don't want to be alone.  I need to know I'm going to be taken care of."
John said: "You need a meal ticket is what you mean.  Some guy you can latch onto just long enough for him to get you out of here."
Grace said: "Is that so bad?  It's not like I wouldn't try to make him happy.  For awhile, anyway.  I mean, I would . . . do things for him.  I guess I'm no good that way.  I guess I tried to sucker you along like that.  Do you hate me for it?  I wouldn't blame you if you did.  But maybe it's like you said:  You just got to do whatever it takes to get out."
John said: "Whatever it takes."

Grace said: "How far is it to California?"
John said: "From here?  I don't know.  Far.  Far enough."
Grace said: "Have you ever been there before?"
John said: "Yeah."
Grace said: "Is it pretty?"
John said: "Beautiful.  Beautiful beaches.  Blue water and clear skies as far as you can see."
Grace said: "Take me with you."
John said: "I can't."
Grace said: "Please.  I won't hang on you.  As soon as we get there you can dump me.  I don't care.  I just want to get out of here."
John said: "Grace, I can't.  I can't even get out of here myself.  I need a hundred-fifty bucks to get my car back from that crazy mechanic."
Grace said: "I know where we could get the money. A lot more than one-hundred-fifty dollars."
John said: "Where?"
Grace said: "Jake."
John said: "You think Jake's going to give me money just so I can take you out of here?"
Grace said: "He doesn't give it to us.  We take it."
John said: "From?"
Grace said: "He's got money.  In a floor safe in the living room.  I've never seen it, but he talks about it all the time.  More like brags.  He loves his money.  Wouldn't think of spending some of it on me."
John said: "You live pretty good."
Grace said: "Yeah, a bird in a gilded cage."
John said: "How much money has he got?"
Grace said: "Near as I can figure must be about a hundred-thousand."
John said: "One-hundred-thousand!?  That son-of- a-bitch lied to me."
Grace said: "Lied?  What do you mean?"
John said: "I . . . nothing.  Just something he said.  So if the money's in a safe we'd have to get the combination--"
Grace said: "It's not a combination lock.  It takes a key.  He keeps it on him all the time.  I mean all the time.  It scratches up against me when we do it."
John said: "If the key's on him, to get the key we'd have to . . ."
Grace said: "We'd have to kill him."

Grace said: "John?  John where are you going?"
John said: "I think this heat is making me crazy.  I was crazy to come back here, I'm crazy for listening to anyone in this town, and I'd sure as hell be crazy if I spent another minute in this place."
Grace said: "John, please--"
John said: "I don't know what I was thinking, but I can't do it."
Grace said: "What are you talking about?"
John said: "Kill someone.  I can't do it."
Grace said: "Is it so bad?  It would be quick. He wouldn't even have to feel it."

John said: "Shit!"
Grace said: "It's not like he's a young man. He's had time to live."
John said: "Jesus Christ!  Listen to yourself! I can't do it, Grace.  I can't do it."

Grace said: "I thought you would be on your way to Vegas by now.  Is there something you wanted?"
John said: "I wanted to talk."
Grace said: "I don't think we have anything to talk about."
John said: "What about us?"
Grace said: "There is no us, remember?"
John said: "Except I can't get you out of my head, Grace."
John said: "I've thought about you every second since I left.  I can still taste you on my lips."
Grace said: "Stop it."
John said: "Why?  Am I making you hot, or does the truth scare you?"
Grace said: "Because I know you're full of shit."
John said: "I mean it, Grace.  I'm getting out of here, and I want to take you with me."
Grace said: "I thought you couldn't leave.  I thought you couldn't get your car."
John said: "I could if I had Jake's money."
Grace said: "Is that what changed your mind?  The money?"
John said: "I don't give a damn about the money. I want you, and I want to get us out of this shithole.  There's only one way to do that."
Grace said: "Are you sure?  About me, I mean?"
John said: "I came back for you; this morning I came back.  Before I even knew about the money. You're what I want."
John said: "The only reason I stormed off is because you sort of spooked me talking about Jake.  But I've had nothing but time to think about it. It keeps coming back to you and me and us getting the hell out of here. But we've got to get the money, baby.  We get the money, I get the car, then we get the hell out."
Grace said: "You said you couldn't kill anybody."
John said: "We don't have to kill him.  Just knock him out and tie him up 'till we get away."

John said: "Grace . . . Grace?"
Grace said: "After dark.  I'll leave the back door unlocked."

John said: "Why the hell didn't you do anything?"
Grace said: "What was I supposed to do?"
John said: "You could have hit him, or kneed him in the balls."

John said: "Where's the safe?"
Grace said: "I don't know."
John said: "You don't know?  Jesus Christ! Don't you think you should have found out before we killed him?"
Grace said: "I'm not sure where it is.  Not exactly.  I never saw it.  I just heard him talk about it."
John said: "Oh, that's great.  We killed Jake because you heard him talk about some money that you've never seen. That's fucking brilliant!"
Grace said: "Don't yell at me!"

John said: "Nothing.  There's no safe under here."
Grace said: "There has to be!"
John said: "There isn't!  There's nothing under here but more floor.  Jesus fucking Christ!  We killed a man for nothing but floor."

Grace said: "It's got to be here.  I heard him talk about it.  He bragged about it. Six steps out, three left."
John said: "This is good.  This is real good. This is so good they might not even charge us with murder when they catch us.  They'll probably just lock us up for being idiots."
Grace said: "If it isn't here, why would he wear that stupid key?"
John said: "You're calling Jake stupid?  You!?"
Grace said: "Don't yell at me!  I know it's here! I know it!"

John said: "There's easily a hundred-thousand in there.  More than that."
Grace said: "I told you.  I knew it was there. Didn't I tell you?"

Grace said: "If you want."
John said: "We're going all the way.  Together."

John said: "Let's go in the bedroom."
Grace said: "No."

Grace said: "Let's do it here."
John said: "What about him?"
Grace said: "Let him watch.  I want him to know what he's missing."

John said: "You got a suitcase?"
Grace said: "Never needed one.  I've never been anywhere.  I've got a backpack."
John said: "Get it, and put the money in it. Pack up anything else you want to take with you."
Grace said: "Where are you going?"
John said: "To get my car."
Grace said: "Wait.  What about . . . him?"
John said: "Put some clothes on him.  When I get back We'll load him in the trunk and dump him in the desert.  It'll takes days for anybody to find him."

Grace said: "John!?  What the hell's the matter with you?"
John said: "I . . . nothing.  I just stubbed my toe on a rock.  Hurt like hell . . . that's all."
Grace said: "I got the money all packed.  I put the jeep in the garage.  Figure that way people will think maybe me and Jake went away.  Might buy us some time."
John said: "Yeah.  Good thinking."
Grace said: "Had push it in.  Funny thing; it wouldn't start."
John said: "Funny thing."

Grace said: "John . . .?"
John said: "Grace!  Just . . . let me handle this.  Sheriff, I'm telling you there's nothing in that trunk.  If that's not good enough for you, then I'd be happy to open it.  Just as soon as you get yourself a search warrant."

Grace said: "Sheriff Potter, please.  I can't go to jail.  I wanted no part of it."
John said: "You liar!  You wanted him dead.  You seduced me into killing him!"

John said: "One-hundred-thousand dollars.  A little more."
Grace said: "Damn you!  What did you do that for? He can't prove anything."
John said: "No, you just wanted me to keep my mouth shut so I could go to a hanging alone."

Grace said: "That's all talk.  He's got nothing on us.  He let you kill Jake."
John said: "Not me.  Us."
Grace said: "It doesn't matter.  He was there and he let it happen.  He can't take us in."
John said: "Give him the money."
Grace said: "What?"
John said: "You heard me.  Count it out."
Grace said: "He can't prove anything, John.  He can't turn us in."
John said: "He can kill us.  I don't know about you, but my life is worth thirty- thousand dollars."

Grace said: "I shot him."
John said: "You killed him!"
Grace said: "He was going to take the money."
John said: "Thirty-thousand, that's all.  We would have been free and clear.  You didn't have to kill him."
Grace said: "It's our money.  He had no right to take it."

John said: "You're crazy, you know that!? You're fucked up!?"
Grace said: "Just drive."

John said: "Jesus, Grace.  Did you have to kill him?"
Grace said: "He was going to--"
John said: "I know.  He was to take the fucking money."
Grace said: "You're tense.  What are you all uptight about?"
John said: "You killed a man for no reason!"

Grace said: "Is that the kind of girl you think I am?  What can I do to make you relax?"
John said: "You could give me the gun."

John said: "Well, nothing."
Grace said: "Now what?"
John said: "Now we dump Jake, split the money, then you're on your own."
Grace said: "But you said we could be together."
John said: "Are you kidding?  I'm not going down with you for killing a cop."
Grace said: "What difference does it make?  You killed Jake."
John said: "<u>We</u> killed Jake.  And it's a big difference.  You kill an old man, that's one thing.  Nobody cares about an old man.  You kill a cop and they never stop looking for you. Never."
Grace said: "He was a crooked bastard.  He would have killed us."
John said: "The police don't know that.  And it's going to be hard to explain it to them with a noose around your neck.  I'll take you as far as California.  If we can even make that.  After that I'm cutting you loose."
Grace said: "But I want to say with you,"
John said: "Why?  So when the cops catch up with us you can try and sell me out again?  You take your hald of the money and run.  You might want to try Mexico.  With all that dough you'll live like a queen."
Grace said: "I don't want to go to Mexico, John. I want to be with you.  Don't you think I care about you?"
John said: "I think you're a lying, back stabbing bitch.  But it's nice to know you care."

Grace said: "John!"
John said: "Grace!"

Grace said: "Are you all right?"
John said: "I think I busted my leg."
Grace said: "Can you climb back up."

John said: "I can't make it.  Grace?  Grace!?"
Grace said: "I'm here."
John said: "Grace, listen to me.  In the trunk of my car is a rope.  It should reach down here.  Got get it, throw it down and I'll climb up."
Grace said: "I'll get it."

Grace said: "John!  Can you hear me?  Are you still there?"
John said: "Where the hell am I going to go?"
Grace said: "John, you have to throw the keys up to me."

Grace said: "John, throw me the keys."
John said: "What for?"
Grace said: "The trunk.  It's locked."
John said: "It's not locked.  I left it open when I took out Jake's body."
Grace said: "It's . . . it's locked."
John said: "You closed it, didn't you, Grace?"
Grace said: "I was going to back the car to the ridge and pull you up."
John said: "Bullshit, Grace.  You were going to drive off and leave me here."
Grace said: "No.  I swear it."
John said: "And you're not one to lie, are you?"
Grace said: "Throw me the keys and I'll pull you up."
John said: "Why don't you come down and get them so I can wring your pretty little neck?"

Grace said: "John, if you don't throw me the keys, then I'll just walk away. Walk away and leave you here."
John said: "Walk to where?  We're fifty miles to the nearest town.  It's going to be over one-hundred degrees today.  How far do you think you're going to get?"
Grace said: "Someone will find me."
John said: "Yeah, they'll find you.  Dried up and twice dead."
Grace said: "You idiot!  You'll kill us both!"
John said: "At least I'll have company when I die.  Ain't that right, Jake?"
Grace said: "For Christ's sake, John!  Throw me the keys!"
John said: "What do you say, Jake?  Should we trust her?  No?  I didn't think so."
Grace said: "Fuck you!  Do you hear me, John!? Fuck you!  John . . . John!?"

John said: "Who the hell are you?"
Jake said: "I'm her husband."
John said: "Husband . . .?"
Jake said: "Now who the hell are you, and it better be good, or God help me I'll break you in half."
John said: "I . . I was helping your wife.  I met her in town.  She needed a hand with her drapes.  That's all."
Jake said: "Didn't much look like you were hanging drapes."
John said: "I swear to you that's all that happened.  I haven't so much as set foot in your bedroom."
Jake said: "A lot that means."
John said: "Grace, tell him."

Jake said: "I have half a mind to--"
John said: "Is this what it's all about?  You sucker me up here so you can watch the two of us beat the shit out of each other over you?  Forget it.  You want to take my head off, Mister, I won't even try to stop you.  I deserve it for being an idiot.  But if you're not, I think I'll be on my way."

Jake said: "What happened to your hand?"
John said: "Accident."
Jake said: "You've got to be--"
John said: "Yeah, I know.  More careful."
Jake said: "I guess we've never been introduced proper.  Jake McKenna."
John said: "Jake McKenna.  That's a solid name."
Jake said: "I'm a solid man."
John said: "John Stewart."
Jake said: "What brings you to Sierra?"
John said: "My car overheated.  I pulled in to have it fixed."
Jake said: "Where you headed?"
John said: "I've got to make a stop in Vegas, then I'm heading to Santa Barbara."
Jake said: "Live there?"
John said: "Got work.  I know a man who's got a boat.  Wants me to sail it for him."
Jake said: "You a sailor man?  That'd be the life.  Drive across the country, step on a boat and just sail away. A man could pretty well disappear like that.  Just sail away until all he was was a memory.  I guess a little place like this would just be a dot on a map to you after awhile."
John said: "I hope so.  Listen, Mr. McKenna, about your wife:  If I had known she was married--"
Jake said: "It wouldn't have made a difference to you, now would it?  Not a wit. Do you know why?  Because you're a man without scruples."
John said: "Wait a second--"
Jake said: "Ah, I can smell it on you."

John said: "Hey!"
Jake said: "That's the sweat of a man who hasn't an honest bone in his body.  Don't be offended, lad.  A man who's got no ethics is a free man.  I envy you that.  Beside, I can hardly blame you.  That Grace has a mind of her own, and a body to match, don't she? Eh?"

Jake said: "She does at that.  I knew when I married her she was a free spirit. A woman with her looks and a man my age; what was I to expect?  But you see a woman like that in a town like this and you don't think, you do. So, I married her.  What are you to do, eh?  Women."
John said: "Can't live with them, and you can't shoot 'em."

Jake said: "I bet she led you on good, didn't she?  Taking you up to the house with that smile of hers.  Bet she wiggled her ass in your face more than once.  Then me busting in like some wild bear.  Bet you had a fire going under you."
John said: "Like you don't know."
Jake said: "Mad like a dog in heat, I bet you were.  I can tell you got a temper on you."

Jake said: "Would you?"
John said: "Would I what?"
Jake said: "Would you kill her?"

John said: "Why would I kill her?"
Jake said: "Because I'm sick and tired of her little games.  Because you could do it and drift away on your boat and no one would ever see you again. Because I've got a fifty-thousand dollar life insurance policy on her, and I would be more than happy to give the man who does her in a good chunk of it."

John said: "I'm not a murderer, Mr. McKenna."
Jake said: "How do you know if you've never tried?"
John said: "This is a joke, right?  You just want to rattle me.  Right?"

Jake said: "Good Lord.  What happened to you?"
John said: "Just ran into a little trouble."
Jake said: "Another accident?  You've really got to be more careful.  Can I get you a drink?"
John said: "No."
Jake said: "Hungry?"
John said: "No."
Jake said: "I'm surprised to see you.  I thought you'd be halfway to Vegas by now."
John said: "I had a problem getting my car back."
Jake said: "You just seem to attract trouble, don't you?"

John said: "Nice office you've got."
Jake said: "I do all right.  Real estate isn't a bad game such as it is around here. The trick is to underestimate the price when you buy it, and overvalue when you sell.  You can turn a few dollars that way."
John said: "Isn't that illegal?"

Jake said: "Now what can I do for you?"
John said: "I was hoping we could talk."
Jake said: "Talk?  About what?"
John said: "About things.  About your wife."

Gekko said: "So whatta you got for me, sport? Why are you here?"

Bud said: "Chart break-out on this one here...uh Whitewood-Young Industries...low P.E. Explosive earnings. 30% discount from book. Great cash flow. Coupla 5% holders. Strong management."
Gekko said: "It's a dog, what else you got, sport, besides connections at the airport?"

Gekko said: "...rings a bell somewhere. So what?"
Bud said: "A comer. 80 medium-body jets. 300 pilots, flies northeast, Canada, some Florida and Caribbean routes... great slots in major cities..."
Gekko said: "...don't like airlines, lousy unions..."
Bud said: "There was a crash last year. They just got a favorable ruling on a lawsuit. Even the plaintiffs don't know."

Gekko said: "How do you know?"
Bud said: "I know...the decision'll clear the way for new planes and route contracts. There's only a small float out there, so you should grab it. Good for a five point pop."

Bud said: "My home number's on the back..."
Gekko said: "Bud Fox, I look at a hundred ideas a day. I choose one."

Gekko said: "Hi sport."
Bud said: "Nice to see you again Mr. Gekko."

Gekko said: "See this? Can you believe it? Two inch screen..."
Bud said: "...I can't even see it..."
Gekko said: "...for my kid Rudy -- 3 years old, electronics freak, got a liquid crystal display 'stead of an electronic beam. We're going into a new age pal. So how's business today."
Bud said: "Bluestar was at 21 and an eighth when I left the office. It might spin up to 25 by the bell..."
Gekko said: "Teldar's shooting up. Buy any for yourself? Bet you were on the phone two minutes after you got out of my office."
Bud said: "No sir, that would've been illegal..."
Gekko said: "Sure...relax sport, no one's gonna blow a whistle. Here, is this legal?...you wanna put it in my account?"

Bud said: "Mr. Gekko -- thank you for the chance. You won't regret this, you're with a winner."
Gekko said: "...put the rest of it in a money market account for now. I want to see what you know before I invest it...and save the cheap salesman talk, it's obvious."
Bud said: "Excuse me sir."

Gekko said: "...come on sport, you gotta try harder, I need some exercise for chrissake..."
Bud said: "Mr. Gekko, I don't think I can...go on."
Gekko said: "...finish out the game, Bud, push yourself..."

Bud said: "Nice club, Mr. Gekko..."
Gekko said: "Yeah... not bad for a City College boy. Bought my way into this club and now every one of these ivy league schmucks is sucking my kneecaps...I just got on the Board of the Zoological Society, cost me a million; that's the thing with WASPS -- they like animals but they can't stand people!"
Bud said: "Uh, Mr. Gekko, we took a little loss today. We got stopped out on Tarafly...  ...about 50 thousand."

Gekko said: "I guess your father's not a union representative on that company."
Bud said: "What? How do you know about my father?"
Gekko said: "The most valuable commodity I know of is information. Wouldn't you agree on that?"
Bud said: "Yes..."

Gekko said: "Know the name?"
Bud said: "'Course. Larry Wildman. One of the first raiders."
Gekko said: "Sir Larry Wildman. Like all Brits he thinks he was born with a better pot to piss in... bribed an old secretary of mine to open bar mouth and stole RDL Pharmaceuticals right out from under me. Wildman the white knight."
Bud said: "I remember that deal. You were involved?"

Gekko said: "Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport.  ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world...  Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired..."
Bud said: "I don't understand."
Gekko said: "Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture..."
Bud said: "Follow him? Mr. Gekko I...  It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?"
Gekko said: "Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that?  I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business..."

Bud said: "What about hard work?"
Gekko said: "What about it? You work hard. I'll bet you stayed up all night analyzing that dog you bought. And where'd it get you?... my father worked hard too like an elephant pushing electrical supplies. And he dropped dead at 49 with a heart attack and a tax bill and the bank pissed on his grave and took the house; my mom ended up working in a dish factory... Wake up pal, if you're not inside you're outside. And I'm not talking a $200,000 a year working Wall Street stiff flying first class and being "comfortable", I'm talking rich pal, rich enough to fly in your own jet, rich enough not to waste time, 50-100 million, a player Bud -- or nothing. You had what it takes to let through my door. Next question: You got what it takes to stay...??"

Bud said: "I got all I could get which was 750,000 shares plus 5000 March 50 calls. Average price of $47 a share And $4 per contract for the call. I just wish I could've got more."
Gekko said: "Don't expect to get it all, sport, you'll burn out. First rule of business is never get emotional about stock, clouds the judgment. Where do we stand?"

Gekko said: "I'll be right there, fix them a drink."
Bud said: "...we have 37.2 million invested. At this point, we're up 3.1 million and some change. If it goes to 75 bucks we can clean close to 12 mill."
Gekko said: "You're walking between the raindrops kid. I expect Sir Larry is choking on his royal chamber pot by now."
Bud said: "My firm needs your signature on these option agreements tonight, sir, otherwise we could take a real bath tomorrow."
Gekko said: "...Can't it wait? I'm good for it.  ...Awright. Come out, get the directions from Natalie and hurry up."

Bud said: "Sorry, Mr. Gekko."
Gekko said: "Allright. Wait here..."

Bud said: "I guess I'll head back..."
Gekko said: "Stick around... Larry, one of my "gang" -- Bud Fox."

Bud said: "The break up value is higher. It's worth 80."
Gekko said: "But we don't want to be greedy now, so let's let him have it at $72."

Gekko said: "He's right. I had to sell. The key to the game is your capital reserves. You don't have enough, you can't pee in the tall weeds with the big dogs."
Bud said: ""All warfare is based on deception..." Sun Tzu says, If your enemy is superior, evade him, if angry, irritate him, if equally matched, fight... if not, split and reevaluate."
Gekko said: "You're learning, sport..."

Gekko said: "Money never sleeps pal. When I came in in '69, they traded six hours a day, now the clock don't stop, London's deregulated, the Orient is hungrier than us. Just let the money circle the world, sport, buying and selling, and if you're smart it comes back paying. I just made $800,000 in Hong Kong gold. It's been wired to you -- play with it. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good. I showed you how the game works, now school's out."
Bud said: "Mr. Gekko, I'm there for you 110%."
Gekko said: "You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, sport, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it... My wife tells me you put a move on Darien. Here's some inside info for you. That Euroflash GQ guy she's going with's got big bucks but he's putting her feet to sleep. Exit visas are imminent. So don't lose your place in line.  Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment.  ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on."
Bud said: "...Gordon."
Gekko said: "Yeah, I'm gonna make you rich, Bud Fox. I'm gonna make you rich enough you can afford a girl like Darien. Remember, power is the best aphrodisiac. This is your wake-up call. Go to work."

Gekko said: "Got him at an auction in Kentucky."
Bud said: "How much?"
Gekko said: "Close to two million.  But this sucker can go all the way to Devon and the nationals."

Gekko said: "The art of which is deception. Spread the buy orders through different accounts and you won't get burned..."
Bud said: "I think I got some friends that won't mind making some easy money..."

Gekko said: "Mixed emotions, Buddy: like Larry Wildman going off a cliff in my new Maserati. Men as smart as myself have got their asses handed to them on a sling with the airlines, fuel could go up, unions are killers..."
Bud said: "Yeah aren't you forgetting something Gordon: rule one, capital reserves. This company has $75 million cash in an overfunded pension. That buys us a lot of credibility...  ...and the beauty is you already own close to two percent of this sucker..."

Bud said: "Gordon what I want--and I never asked you for anything--is to be your co-pilot on this. I want to take this airline, turn it around, and make it work. It's gonna make us a fortune!"
Gekko said: "I'm talking to a stockbroker who wants to run an airline. It's gonna take me two years and 2000 headaches to turn Teldar Paper around, what do I need this dink airline for? I'm up to my ass in more nuts than a fruitcake."
Bud said: "Gordon, I worked at Bluestar, I know my way around, I have friends there...inside."
Gekko said: "What does that mean?"
Bud said: "The three unions. It's 43% of Bluestar's operating budget, the hourly cost of a flight crew is $850 an hour, that's the real hidden value G.G., if you can negotiate that out, get a crew down to $350-400 an hour a run, this airline is gonna be the hottest thing since Texas Air..."
Gekko said: "What makes you think you can?"
Bud said: "I can talk to these people Gordon, they trust me...and my father can be a big help in getting cuts."
Gekko said: "Alright... Susan, get Buckingham on the box. I want him to look at it. And tell Jock Taylor at Thwick, Jensen...  So sport, the falcon has heard the falconer...tell me more..."

Bud said: "And I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Gekko, and his lawyer, Mr. Salt."
Gekko said: "A pleasure to meet you, Mr. Fox."

Bud said: "Now, wait a minute, Dad..."
Gekko said: "Sure. What's worth doing is worth doing for money. It's a bad bargain where nobody gains. And if this deal goes through, we all gain."

Gekko said: "I didn't know we had a meeting schedule for this morning."
Bud said: "I'm sorry, this can't wait."

Gekko said: "What the hell do you want?"
Bud said: "I found out about the garage sale down at Bluestar. Why?"

Gekko said: "Last night I read Rudy the story of Winnie the Pooh and the Honey pot. Know what happened: he stuck his nose in that honey pot once too often and got stung."
Bud said: "Maybe you ought to read him Pinocchio. You told me you were going to turn Bluestar around. Not upside down. You used me."
Gekko said: "You're walking around blind without a cane, sport. A fool and his money are lucky to get together in the first place."
Bud said: "Why do you need to wreck this company?"
Gekko said: "Because it's wreckable. I took another look and I changed my mind."
Bud said: "If these people lose their jobs, nowhere to go. My father worked at Bluestar for twenty-four years. I gave 'em my word."
Gekko said: "It's all about bucks, kid, the rest is conversation...  Bud, you're still going to be president. And when the time comes, you'll parachute out a rich man. With the money you're going to make, your father won't have to work another day in his life."
Bud said: "Tell me, Gordon--when does it all end? How many yachts can you waterski behind? How much is enough?"
Gekko said: "Buddy, it's not a question of enough. It's a zero sum game, sport. Somebody wins and somebody loses. Money itself isn't lost or made, it's simply transferred from one perception to another. Like magic. That painting cost $60,000 10 years ago. I could sell it today for $600,000. The illusion has become real. And the more real it becomes, the more desperately they want it. Capitalism at its finest."
Bud said: "How much is enough Gordon?"
Gekko said: "The richest one percent of this country owns half the country's wealth: 5 trillion dollars. One third of that comes from hard work, two thirds of it comes from inheritance, interest on interest accumulation to widows and idiot sons and what I do -- stock and real estate speculation. It's bullshit. Ninety percent of the American people have little or no net worth. I create nothing; I own. We make the rules, Buddy, the news, war, peace, famine, upheaval; the cost of a paper clip.  We pull the rabbit out of the hat while everybody else sits around their whole life wondering how we did it...  ...you're not naive enough to think we're living in a democracy are you, Buddy? It's the free market. You're one of us now...take advantage of it. You got the killer instinct, kid, stick with me. I got things to teach you..."
Bud said: "Obviously..."

Gekko said: "Believe me, Buddy, I was gonna discuss this with you at the right time. Look, why don't you calm down and come to the apartment for dinner tonight. Bring Darien..."
Bud said: "...I can't make it tonight."
Gekko said: "Are you with me Buddy?"

Bud said: "Gordon, it's two minutes to close. What do you want to do?! Decide."
Gekko said: "Dump it."

Gekko said: "Hello Bud."
Bud said: "Gordon."
Gekko said: "You sandbagged me on Bluestar.  I guess you think you taught the teacher a lesson, that you can make the tail wag the dog, huh?"

Bud said: "Hello again, I been holding these drinks for us for the last three weeks."
Darien said: "Excuse me."
Bud said: "Grand Marnier. A romantic and tragic drink."
Darien said: "Oh yes, I remember you."
Bud said: "Destiny took us apart, but I knew it would bring us back together."
Darien said: "Aha. Poet or philosopher?"
Bud said: "Stock broker. As in: never have so few done so little for so much. So what do you see in this?"

Darien said: "I'd give anything to have this in my house, even for a week."
Bud said: "...few thousand dollars down the drain if you ask me."
Darien said: "Oh really?  Well, I guess you can kiss that career as an art appraiser goodbye, because we paid over four hundred thousand for it at the contemporary picture sale last June."
Bud said: "You could have a great beach house for that."
Darien said: "Sure you could, in Wildwood, New Jersey. If you sold this,  you could have a pretty nice penthouse on Fifth. But you wouldn't have much left over for decoration."
Bud said: "Boy, I thought Gordon was a tough businessman, but somebody's really taking him to the cleaners here."
Darien said: "Not really. I'd say that Gordon is one of the most astute collectors around. He has a great eye and he only buys the best. Like this rug for instance, a silk Tabriz, the finest of its kind. The day after he bought it in London, a dealer representing the Saudi Royal Family offered him twice what he paid. It absolutely makes the room. See how this little bit of celadon in the border is picked up in the cushions oh the sofa... although...  I don't know if I would have used that tea dipped linen for the upholstery - too dingy. And it's a sacrilege having that Pre-Columbian pot in the center of the coffee table. Some dope might use it as an ashtray."
Bud said: "I gather you're a decorator."
Darien said: "You got it, a great spender of other people's money."
Bud said: "Well, if you're that good, you could probably do wonders at my place."
Darien said: "Where is it?"
Bud said: "Upper West Side."
Darien said: "Oh really. Home of the exposed brick wall and the  houseplant."
Bud said: "Oh it's just a rental. I'm moving to the East Side soon. I've got a couple of deals brewing with Gordon.  but that's just conversation... what about real things? Like dinner. The two of us. Friday. Cafe. Santo Domingo."

Darien said: "What if I have a previous engagement?"
Bud said: "Break it."
Darien said: "I guess this must be destiny alright. My first yuppie apartment and...  my first yuppie."
Bud said: "You may call me a yuppie... It's Mister Yuppie to you."

Bud said: "So. See you Friday."
Darien said: "You really do believe in destiny?"
Bud said: "Only if I want something bad enough."

Bud said: "Devon? He looks like Seattle Slew. What about the Triple Crown?"
Darien said: "He's not a racehorse, Bud, he's a jumper."
Bud said: "How would I know? I once bet a horse. He went out at ten to one and came in at quarter to five."

Darien said: "If I could have anything... this would almost do."
Bud said: "Yeah, almost..."

Darien said: "So, how did your conference go with Gordon?"
Bud said: "The conference, oh yeah. Fine. We reached an agreement and decided to divide up the world between us."
Darien said: "You have modest wants. I like that in a man."
Bud said: "And what do you want?"
Darien said: "...a Turner, a perfect canary diaiaond... a Lear jet... world peace... the best of everything..."
Bud said: "Well, why stop at that?"
Darien said: "I don't."
Bud said: "You're not trouble by any chance. Are you?"

Darien said: "...isn't it perfect!"
Bud said: "...too perfect...let's not even eat. Let's just watch it and think about it."

Bud said: "You know, the elevator man couldn't believe I paid $300,000 to have my walls looking like this, he's got them for free in Brooklyn."
Darien said: "I'll bet he's got an opinion on the stock market too. This apartment is already ahead of its time. I call it the "demolished" look. They've already heard about it at House and Garden and they're coming next week to photograph it before it gets... lived in. Is that alright? I'd love to have it in my portfolio."
Bud said: "Sure... But your fee... considering you're way over budget, should be negotiable."

Darien said: "Let's get things straight, Bud. I'm not going to take a cut. I worked hard and you can't decorate a room in New York for less than $100,000. Curtains alone..."
Bud said: "I'm kidding, I'm kidding, we're still young, Darien. So what's money anyway when everybody's making it, it's all relative. After all, this is not the house in Connecticut, this is just a crash pad good for a couple of years...before we slip our two lovely kids, Yuppie and Fruppie into the Lycee Francaise."
Darien said: "You got it all charted out don't you, like a stock projection."
Bud said: "That's right -- one with high yield, rich assets and no downside..."

Darien said: "Do you think you're ready?"
Bud said: "It's not me I'm worried about...You know Darien, the only reason we haven't slept together is because we both know we will -- and not knowing when was the only surprise left. You owe me, I want you, what else is there...but you, me, the world.  ...right here...make love to me...now...  Stop me if I'm going too far."
Darien said: "I'll let you know."

Bud said: "Bud, I hate to tell you this but you're a genius!  Darien...lightning has struck! The lightbulb has been invented. Edison, Da Vinci, Einstein are watching..."
Darien said: "...are you going to trade all night again? You got to go to work in a couple of hours."
Bud said: "You think I'm gonna broker the rest of my life... I'm going to be a giant, Darien, an entrepreneur in the Italian 15th century sense of the word -- a mover, shaker."

Bud said: "I love you, baby. Did I tell you that sometime in the last 24 hours?"
Darien said: "Get in bed. Y'ever hear of the sixty hour work week? You're turning into a yuppie Frankenstein, you love money so much."

Bud said: "Sure, why not, money's the sex of the 80's. I never had it like you when I was growing up, baby, it wasn't the upper east side."
Darien said: "You're so naive Bud, you don't even know. Your dad took care of you. I might've been rich when I was a kid...but my father lost all his money...in the seventies, in the stock market, at the track. He was a lousy gambler..."
Bud said: "...that changes all my plans, I thought you were loaded..."
Darien said: "So did I, till I hit 19 and found I had all the royal habits and no throne. Mom got by but I had to go to work just like you. Only the skills I had were shopping and making friends. So...that's why I do what I do, what makes you tick, Buddy?"
Bud said: "Fear. The fear of being poor I guess, just like you, Darien... But that's all gonna change sweetheart. I'm catching the express...  ... and you're going along for the ride."

Darien said: "I'm sorry. I was afraid something like this could happen."
Bud said: "Talk about being bent over the sink of life and being dry humped. I handed it to him on a silver platter. I told my father and those people..."
Darien said: "Buddy, it's not your fault, and it's not your decision."
Bud said: "I'm not gonna let it happen Darien."

Darien said: "Don't cross Gordon. He'll crush you. You've worked hard to get where you are. If Gordon doesn't buy Bluestar someone else will; and who's to say they won't do the same thing."
Bud said: "At least I wouldn't be pulling the trigger."

Darien said: "Are you mad! Why are you doing this! We're so close, the town is going to be ours. Don't throw away your future Bud!"
Bud said: "I can stay with the brokerage firm. And you're doing fine. We can survive without Gordon Gekko."
Darien said: "I'm not looking to just survive. I've been doing that all my life."
Bud said: "What the hell's that supposed to mean?"

Bud said: "You really mean that?  What'd he promise you? To take you public? I guess without Gordon's money and seal of approval, I'm not such a hot investment anymore. You're just the best money can buy, Darien..."
Darien said: "You're not exactly pure Bud, you went after Gekko with the same vengeance you went after me. Look in the mirror before..."
Bud said: "I'm looking...and I sure don't like what I see."

Darien said: "You may not believe this Bud but I really do care for you. I think we could've made a good team...but that's how it goes..."
Bud said: "Get the hell out!"

Darien said: "Hi."
Bud said: "Why?"
Darien said: "I figure a guy who's made some mistakes should be able to understand a girl who's made some of her own..."

Carolyn said: "How you doing Buddy?"
Bud said: "Great Carolyn, doing any better would be a sin..."

Carolyn said: "Morning Buddy, you look happy."
Bud said: "Any better and I'd be guilty."
Carolyn said: "You were never that innocent sugarpie."
Bud said: "...how do you know? You wish..."

Carolyn said: "Bud! Where you been the last two days?"
Bud said: "...Janet get my father on the phone and the two other union reps, urgent..."

Carolyn said: "He had a heart attack, hon, but he's okay, he's at the hospital..."
Bud said: "Oh Christ!"

Bud said: "You got a look in your eye, Mr. Mannheim... You got something for the small fry..."
Mannheim said: "Jesus, can't make a buck in this market, country's going to hell faster than when that sonofabitch Roosevelt was around... too much cheap money sloshing around the world. The biggest mistake we ever made was letting Nixon get off the gold standard. Putney Drug--you boys might want to have a look at it."

Bud said: "Sleep with me and the secrets of the West are yours."
Mannheim said: "Now that's a crap company, sure you'll make money on the takeover rumor, but what's being created. Nothing. No substance behind it."
Bud said: "Old values. Buy."

Bud said: "Mr. Mannheim, got a sure thing.  Anacott Steel."
Mannheim said: "No such thing Bud - 'cept death and taxes. Not a good company anymore, no fundamentals. What's going on Bud? Do you know something?  Remember there're no short cuts son, quick buck artists come and go with every bull market but the steady players make it through the bear markets.  You're part of something here, Bud. The money you make for people creates science and research jobs. Don't sell that out."
Bud said: "You're right, Mr. Mannheim, but you gotta get to the big time first, then you can be a pillar and do good things."
Mannheim said: "Can't get a little bit pregnant, Bud."
Bud said: "It's a winner Mr. Mannheim, trust me -- buy."

Mannheim said: "You're on a roll kiddo. Enjoy it while it lasts -- 'cause it never does."
Bud said: "...just kickin' ass and taking names, Mr. Mannheim."

Carl said: "I thought this was an informal meeting. What's he doing here?"
Gekko said: "Harold, you don't mind strolling around the block a couple hundred times, do you?"

Gekko said: "Frankly, Carl, I can't see giving much more. If you have any suggestions I'll be glad to listen."
Carl said: "There came into Egypt a Pharoah who did not know."
Gekko said: "I beg your pardon. Is that a proverb?"
Carl said: "No, it's a prophecy. The rich have been doing it to the poor since the beginning of time. The only difference between the Pyramids and the Empire State Building is that the Egyptians didn't have unions.  I know what this guy is about-- greed--he's in and out for the buck and he don't take prisoners. He don't give a damn about Northstar or us ..."

Gekko said: "Fine, if you don't want us, stay with the scum in present management--dedicated to running you and Bluestar into the ground."
Carl said: "...that "scum" built this company up from one plane in thirty years, they made something out of nothing, and if that's a scum I'll take one over a rat any day..."

Gekko said: "What do you say we go get a suite at the Carlyle? Caviar? Champagne? Celebrate, just like the old times Sunshine."
Darien said: "Those days are over, Gordon. They were over a long time ago."
Gekko said: "Can't blame me for trying. You look as beautiful as that painting I just bought."

Gekko said: "So what's the problem Sunshine? You look like Black Thursday. Bad case of puppy love?"
Darien said: "It's not puppy love, Gordon. Anyway, Buddy and I are splitting up."
Gekko said: "Sorry to hear that. I thought the kid had staying power."
Darien said: "It's over you, Gordon."
Gekko said: "You told him about us?"
Darien said: "No, are you crazy? And I don't want him ever to know. Do you understand?..."

Darien said: "I want to ask you a big favor, Gordon. Please drop the Bluestar deal."
Gekko said: "Now tell me, why would I want to do that?"
Darien said: "Because I don't want to see him hurt."
Gekko said: "Don't worry Sunshine. Bud and I had a little talk. We came to an understanding.  I want you to go back to him. Soothe him. Help keep his head straight. Okay?"
Darien said: "I can't...and I won't."
Gekko said: "Come on, we both like Buddy. But this bleeding heart puppy love act is over the top... It doesn't fit."
Darien said: "Maybe it does. Don't patronize me Gordon."
Gekko said: "You and I are the same, Darien. We're smart enough not to buy into the oldest myth running: love... A fiction created by people who got nothing to keep them from jumping out of windows."
Darien said: "You're really twisted, Gordon. You're incapable of giving to anybody because deep down inside you there's a poverty that every last dollar in the world won't fill."
Gekko said: "Ooh ooh, tough talk from a scared little girl all wrapped in a pretty grown-up package. Does this mean you're ready to cut the umbilical cord and step out into the world on your own? Because, Darien, if you're through with me, you're through with everything I'm a part of."

Gekko said: "Yeah, Billy, who's your buyer?... No, not interested.  Ollie, start calling a the institutions, start with Marx at Janson Mutual, then Reardon. Get me that California retirement money, baby! And we're on our way!"
Ollie said: "You got it, G.G."

Gekko said: "He respond to the offer? What? What the hell's Cromwell doing giving lecture tours when his company's losing 60 million a quarter? I guess he's giving lectures on how to lose money...if this guy opened a funeral parlor, no one would die, this turkey's totally brain dead...Well Christmas is over and business is business.  Keep buying. Dilute the sonofabitch. Ollie I want every orifice in his body flowing red."
Ollie said: "He's flowing, Gordo. Piece of cake."

Ollie said: "... just got 250,000 shares at 18 1/4 from Janson, think I'll pull twice that at 18 1/2 outta the California pensions. We got close to half a million shares in the bag."
Gekko said: "Hey, the Terminator! Blow 'em away Ollie."
Ollie said: "And, I'm pretty sure we got the Beezer Brothers out of Tulsa coming in with us and I'm working on the Silverberg boys in Canada."

Ray said: "With a thirty-five inch bustline in a wet T-shirt with no bra..."

Ray said: "Sit down, Lombardo."

Sam said: "Yeah, well, you fixed that.  What the hell happened, anyway?"
Ray said: "The bitch shot me, is what happened."

Ray said: "Hey, what did you want me to do, die?"
Sam said: "Well, shit, you're the cop, they don't teach you to disarm people, shoot them in the leg or something?  You weren't supposed to kill her for Christ's sake."

Ray said: "Did you become squeamish about these things before or after you bludgeoned little Suzie Toller to death with a wine bottle?  Jesus, man. It couldn't have worked out better. They're convinced Kelly whacked Suzie. I can't talk 'em out of it.  We should be celebrating.  This thing worked out just like you said, only better."

Sam said: "Come on, man.  I'll make a sailor out of you yet."
Ray said: "Yeah, or get me drowned."

Sam said: "Jesus, man... You okay?"
Ray said: "That how you planned it?  You take cut Suzie, get me to hang it on Kelly, then dump me in the ocean..."

Suzie said: "How much is about six and a half million divided by three?"
Sam said: "Jesus.  Two million one hundred thirty-three thousand three hundred thirty-three and change."

Suzie said: "Sam..."
Sam said: "Put Kelly on too."

Suzie said: "But I.."

Suzie said: "Yeah, right."

Suzie said: "But then it is better this way, don't you think?  No loose ends."

Suzie said: "What?"

Sam said: "What's wrong?"
Suzie said: "Fuck the winch.  I wanna drive."

Suzie said: "Trust me, the guy's dirty.  He'll like it.  Especially the part about offing me.  Now get out of here.  Go make yourself a new friend."

Sam said: "How..."

Sam said: "I think there's some things you do, you don't want to see yourself doing them."

Sandra said: "What?  You're going to drive off without even saying hi?"
Sam said: "Hi, Sandy."
Sandra said: "Why don't you come in, have a drink?"
Sam said: "Can't.  Got a passenger."

Sam said: "I can't, Sandy.  I've got to run."

Sam said: "Sorry, Sandy.  I've got plans."

Artemus said: "J. S. Bach."

Artemus said: "Aha!"

Jim said: "Starting with a screw?"

Jim said: "What about the explosive?"

Artemus said: "Uh... how long ago was this?"

Artemus said: "I thought all you needed were your fists and your gun."

Jim said: "I find most criminals slip up somewhere..."

Jim said: "You really enjoy yourself, don't you?"

Artemus said: "I'd love to stop him, but have you noticed the hundred armed men?"
Jim said: "There's only seventy-eight."
Artemus said: "Oh, well, then let's kick some ass!"

Artemus said: "It was in your book."
Jim said: "Well, hell, maybe we do have a chance."

Jim said: "Are those just button buttons or...?"

Artemus said: "My hat is off to you, sir."
Jim said: "Thank you."

Artemus said: "God in heaven, what is that?!"
Jim said: "That's... that's the criminal mind about to stomp our sorry butts!"

Artemus said: "My God!  He's so excessive!"
Jim said: "Where have you been?"

Artemus said: "All right, all right... It'll be okay.  I mean, eventually it'll just run out of steam."

Artemus said: "But it only has six legs."

Pemberton said: "He's not giving up?"
Artemus said: "Well, see, he had this little wagon when he was a kid..."

Artemus said: "Time for you to get off, Ma'am."
Pemberton said: "Like hell!  I'll see it through! Ram the bastard!"

Miguelito said: "A new friend?"

Cassandra said: "You most certainly do."

Cassandra said: "You must excuse the Doctor.  No one has ever beaten him at his little game."

Cassandra said: "Have you taken a wrong turn, Mr. Tyler?"
Jim said: "You tell me."

Cassandra said: "You've... done... this... before."

Cassandra said: "She's perfectly safe."

Cassandra said: "My.  It's gotten longer."
Jim said: "You bring the best out in a man."
Cassandra said: "I try.  Please, if you promise to protect me, I'll testify against him. I'll give you an ironclad case."

Cassandra said: "Fine, I'll stop."

Jim said: "Look, I'm Captain James West..."
Doyle said: "Well, Captain, then the answer is your train is still here."

Jim said: "My friend?"

Doyle said: "Would you be thinking... ramming speed, sir?"
Jim said: "I would, Mr. Doyle!  Are you game?"

Grant said: "Don't try to bamboozle me, Colonel. Has another scientist been kidnapped or not?"
Richards said: "Well, yes sir.  A Professor Morton, but with just a little more time, sir, I can assure you a breakthrough on this case..."

Grant said: "Listen, in two days I'm embarking on a tour of the western territories.  And I want to know at least one problem is being handled competently in my absence."
Richards said: "Of course, sir, that's why I've assigned a new man.  And he's no ordinary Marshal.  He's quite sophisticated.  Three college degrees.  A master of disguise. Speaks French..."
Grant said: "French?"
Richards said: "Yes sir."
Grant said: "French?  Damn it, I want my own man on this case.  Somebody I trust. Somebody who doesn't mind breaking up the furniture!"

Richards said: "Why surely, Mr. President, there must be some mistake.  I mean..."
Grant said: "A mistake?  To assign this case to the man who blew up all the bridges on the Chattanooga River and single- handedly trapped Jackson's entire cavalry?  How is that a mistake?"

Jim said: "Mr. President, good to see you again, sir.  Sorry about all that."
Grant said: "That'll be all, boys."

Jim said: "Good work.  Really."
Grant said: "This is Colonel Richards."
Jim said: "Nice to finally meet you, sir."

Jim said: "But what would anyone have to gain from all this...?  Unless it were a foreign power."
Grant said: "Exactly.  Any number of nations would love to cripple our scientific growth.  And what better way to tip the scales in their favor than by killing off the greatest minds this country has produced."

Grant said: "We find ourselves at the dawn of the Golden Age of Science.  And it is the God-given destiny of this glorious nation to carry the torch that lights the way!"
Jim said: "Nicely said, sir."
Grant said: "Part of some speech they wrote for this trip I'm taking."

Grant said: "Goddamnit!  What am I doing?  What's happened to all my cigars?  Colonel Richards here has had a dozen agents on these cases for over a year.  No arrests, no leads, no clues..."
Jim said: "And?"
Grant said: "And now the job's yours."

Jim said: "... well, of course you can.  Mr. President, what a surprise.  What brings you here?"
Grant said: "On my way to Denver..."

Jim said: "Where'd he say he was going to do this?"
Grant said: "He didn't.  That's your job.  I'm taking you off that other case until you've nabbed this lunatic. Good luck.  Nice train.  But mine's nicer."

Jim said: "I admire a man with a sense of humor."
Miguelito said: "When you're three and a half feet tall, sir, life turns you into a comedian whether you like it or not.... Come with me, won't you?"

Jim said: "I must compliment you on Miss Thompson... an exceptionally charming assistant."
Miguelito said: "Thank you.  I confess to a preoccupation with acquiring precisely that which the world says I cannot have."

Miguelito said: "Very good, sir!  I think my guest might be a sharpshooter by trade."
Jim said: "No, sir... just a businessman."
Miguelito said: "Really?  Must be a dangerous business."
Jim said: "I deal with some tough customers."

Miguelito said: "Sir... I believe you have only two barrels."
Jim said: "How embarrassing.  Did I hold up three fingers?"

Jim said: "Why don't we just cut this routine short?  Whatever you do to us, we're not going to talk."
Miguelito said: "Talk?  About what...?  Oh!  About who you are and all that?"

Miguelito said: "... And do give me some room, Voltaire.  You're breathing on my head!  I hate it when you breath on my head!"
Jim said: "Dr. Loveless?"

Jim said: "You're not that big."
Miguelito said: "Restrain yourself, Voltaire.  He's just the sort of coward who would shoot an unarmed giant."

Miguelito said: "Still alive.  Hmm.  I suppose that doesn't bode well for poor Bruno."
Jim said: "He had a pressing engagement."
Miguelito said: "Philistine."

Jim said: "You got that right.  Now get up. We're walking out of here."
Miguelito said: "Has it penetrated that adrenaline- addled skull that you are surrounded by seventy-eight of my loyal followers?  You are in my domain!"
Jim said: "Has it penetrated yours that I'm holding a gun on their leader?"

Jim said: "The U.S. is my jurisdiction."
Miguelito said: "Exactly!  You are on foreign soil. You are a representative of the occupying forces.  Or haven't you checked a map lately?!"

Miguelito said: "These lands were taken by force from Mexico in the illegal War of American Aggression."

Miguelito said: "I've even printed my own currency."
Jim said: ""Emperor Miguelito...?""

Jim said: "Well, your highness, what makes you think we'll ever sign a treaty with you?"
Miguelito said: "Because I am holding all the western territories hostage, Mr. West!  A town a day will disappear!  Willard was merely a test run, a stroll in the park.  Next, I level all of Albuquerque!  Yes, that's right.  Only yesterday I learned what you undoubtedly already know: your own President will be there.  What an added bonus! The gods are shining on me!  After tomorrow every American citizen will rise up and demand I be given back my humble little empire!"

Back where I come from, we have men who are called heroes.  Once a year, they take their fortitude out of mothballs and parade it down the main street of the city.  And they have no more courage than you have.  But! They have one thing that you haven't got! A medal!  Therefore -- for meritorious...."

Christmas said: "You new?"
Bond said: "Yes. Viktor Davidov, Miss...?"
Christmas said: "Doctor. Jones. Christmas Jones. No jokes, Ive heard them all."
Bond said: "Dont know any doctor jokes."
